IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on a novel therapeutic strategy for castration-resistant prostate cancer. These studies will establish new avenues of investigation to develop improved therapeutics to treat this deadly disease and to greatly improve patient outcome. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NCI's mission of fostering creative discoveries and innovative research strategies for protecting and improving health and reducing the burdens associated with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental health problems in childhood are highly prevalent and impairing, placing an immense social and economic burden on society. Parent-child relationships in the early years of life play a critical role in promoting child mental health, with critical and coercive relationships increasing the risk of mental health problems across the lifespan. Our project includes the creation and systematic evaluation of an innovative technology-based therapy system that employs artificial intelligence to monitor and responsively administer dynamic (i.e., as needed) supports to families in real-world settings in order to promote positive family relationships and improve child mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have discovered Kidney Injury Molecule-1 (KIM-1), a protein that kidney proximal tubule cells express when they are injured. If KIM-1 is expressed over longer periods of time it leads to progressive kidney failure. KIM-1 acts to increase re-uptake of many noxious molecules that the kidney filters including albumin with bound fatty acids. Our goal is to understand how this uptake leads to organ failure so that we can develop strategies to prevent progression of chronic kidney disease, reducing side effects such as cardiovascular disease and the need for hemodialysis or transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Adolescence is a period in which the brain networks that support goal-directed decision-making undergo pronounced reorganization. It is also the typical age of clinical onset for most forms of mental illness. This project will leverage recent advances in computational modeling, which enable the quantification of parameters that govern learning and decision-making, in order to characterize the neurocognitive decision-making phenotype of adolescents and to relate this phenotype to psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Delineating an anterior cingulate-claustrum-parietal cortical circuit underlying cognitive control and attention No treatments targeting the alleviation of cognitive dysfunction exist for psychiatric patients, and numerous clinical trials have failed likely due to the use of targets not validated from circuits specific to affected cognitive domains. To address this challenge, the circuits underlying cognitive control and attention in patients need to be delineated with evidence that they are pharmacologically manipulable. By combining contemporary neuroscience techniques with the 5-choice continuous performance test that is consistent with challenges used in humans, we will determine the neural circuitry underlying cognitive control and attention to delineate the mechanistic underpinnings and pharmacological effects on these circuits that drive behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop and characterize autofluorescence lifetime microscopy for label-free imaging and quantification of cellular metabolism and mitochondria function in living cells with high temporal and spatial resolution. Advancements in quantitative metabolic assays will reveal new insights into the fundamental effects of anesthetics on mitochondria and cell metabolism, reduce the side-effects and toxicities of anesthetics, ensure optimal care for patients with metabolic disease including neurodegenerative disorders, and characterize potential confounding effects due to anesthesia in pre-clinical and clinical studies of metabolism and metabolic defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The developing mouse brain is a foundational experimental model for investigation of the origins of cell types in the mammalian brain and for studies of neurodevelopmental diseases. During development, the astonishing diversity of cell types present in the adult brain is thought to be established through sequential changes in gene expression during cellular maturation and differentiation, and further refinement with emerging brain connectivity and function. To gain a deeper understanding of this highly complex process, we aim to combine multiple single- cell genomics technologies to generate a comprehensive cell atlas of the developing mouse brain, intended to serve as a first-of-its-kind foundational resource to the neuroscience community for the study of mechanisms of mammalian brain development and neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Communication between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and mitochondria is essential to maintain glucose homeostasis and whole-body energy balance. However, our knowledge on the regulatory elements that control the crosstalk between these two organelles, especially the regulation of mammalian mitochondrial protein import machineries and cellular respiration by the ER in health and disease, is very limited. Therefore, the goal of this proposal is to define mitochondrial-ER signaling pathways that control cellular function and energy expenditure in brown adipocytes during diet and thermal stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project narrative  Diabetes is a risk factor for cerebral ischemia and heart disease. For patients undergoing intensive therapy to manage diabetes, a major side effect is the development of low blood glucose levels (hypoglycemia). Our results indicate that exposure to recurrent hypoglycemia increases the risk of cerebral ischemia in diabetic rats. We propose to determine the mechanisms by which prior exposure to hypoglycemic episodes causes an increased risk of cerebral ischemia and cerebral ischemic damage in patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biology has become a powerful interdisciplinary and revolutionary technology, uniquely poised to transform human health and medicine, yet the majority of experiences that K-12 learners have with the life sciences are still rooted in traditional procedural and prescriptive approaches. To better prepare young people to engage in the research or applied sides of modern biomedicine, we need to engage students from a diversity of backgrounds - especially those from marginalized communities - in a 21st century approach to biology that emphasizes authentic science practices based in open-ended exploration and creativity. Our proposed project, Adapting and Scaling the Biotinkering Approach through a Community of Practice (CoP) Model, will create the community and culturally responsive types of informal learning experiences society needs to provide inspirational entry points for a more diverse next generation of biotech and biomedical innovators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Molecular knowledge on how to revert cellular aging can provide breakthrough therapies to combat diseases, such as cancers and other aging-related degenerative diseases. We obtained unique insight that telomere length – a key aging hallmark – is restricted by a nuclear organelle undergoing phase separation. By targeting phase- separation, we are developing a telomere-boosting chemical that can revert cellular aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cutaneous metastatic breast cancer (CMBC) develops in up to 24% of patients with metastatic breast cancer and has limited treatment options due to the extent and recurrence of tumors and treatment toxicity. Photodynamic therapy (PDT) uses a photo-sensitive drug (REM-001) and directed light to treat tumors with minimal effects to surrounding tissue. This trial will test a reduced dose of PDT on patients with CMBC who cannot undergo surgery or radiation therapy, to confirm that it produces therapeutic effects for their symptomatic lesions while minimizing the duration of post-treatment healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (Project Narrative) In LMIC, up to 20% of maternal deaths are due to suicide and in South Asia, is a leading cause of death among women of reproductive age. This research project explores engaging peer-volunteers in suicide detection and prevention in rural Pakistan, where findings will inform how task-shifted models for mental health care can successfully integrate suicide prevention practices, ultimately saving lives and improving community- based mental health services. Public health impacts may be substantial as results can be applied not only in similar South Asian contexts, but also in low-resourced settings in the US and abroad, where the suicide burden remains high.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuronal loss in the locus coeruleus (LC) better predicts the onset and severity of symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) than Aβ/neurofibrillary tangles or cell loss in any other brain region. We have previously demonstrated the vulnerability of the LC to aging and stress, and our preliminary data shows faster LC- norepinephrine (NE) functional decline among blacks, possibly related to lifetime experience of discrimination. This innovative study will test whether loss of LC-NE function better predicts cognitive impairment than current ATN biomarkers, particularly among blacks, suggesting a novel approach to racial-dependent strategies for diagnosis and therapeutical interventions in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the number one cause of cancer death in the United States and metals are a major cause of the disease. Our study focuses on how hexavalent chromium, a metal with widespread exposure known to cause lung cancer, causes chromosome instability, a hallmark event in lung cancer. Our findings will transform our understanding of how metals cause chromosome instability and lung cancer, which may spur new potential treatment targets, new approaches to reduce and prevent metal-induced lung cancer, and new insights to better determine and manage safer exposure levels for this major public health concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Structural models provide uniquely detailed information that is used to understand cellular processes in health and disease and to design more effective drugs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The genetic regulation of the shape and size of internal organs and whole body is crucial during development, regeneration, and homeostasis. This project will develop a novel integrated systems biology approach to elucidate mechanistically the molecular pathways and their coordination that control large-scale tissue growth dynamics in living organisms. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While great strides have been made in the diagnosis and treatment of pediatric cancers, much remains to be done. The cure of children with cancer is often achieved with unacceptable side-effects, and for many cancer subtypes of pediatric cancer, current therapy is inadequate. The best hope for reducing the burden of pediatric cancer is the training of committed researchers by an experienced and accomplished faculty that is involved in diverse aspects of basic and clinical research directly relevant to tackling these challenging problems in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) are a poorly understood class of genes that are subject to frequent deregulation in lung adenocarcinoma, suggesting a potential wealth of unexplored therapeutic targets. We have developed innovative approaches to model the aberrant expression of lncRNA in cell and animal models of lung adenocarcinoma, providing a unique opportunity to study the contributions of lncRNAs to the development and treatment of this aggressive disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Significant MRI scanner-dependent bias in diffusion acquisition inadvertently corrupts derived tissue diffusivity metrics increasing likelihood of false findings and inflating cost for multi-center clinical oncology trials employing this noninvasive quantitative imaging technology. The goal of the proposed renewal academic industrial partnership is to integrate bias correction tools developed during the parent project into ongoing clinical oncology trials to eliminate cross-scanner variability errors and improve accuracy of diffusivity-based cancer biomarkers. Ultimately, this will advance diagnostic, prognostic and treatment monitoring based on quantitative diffusion imaging toward more effective clinical management of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Light chain amyloidosis is a complex disease involving both the clonal expansion of a diseased plasma cell and the toxic deposition of destabilized, amyloidogenic immunoglobulin light chains as toxic oligomers and amyloid fibrils on peripheral target tissues such as the kidney and heart. Current treatments for light chain amyloidosis use chemotherapeutics to ablate the underlying diseased plasma cell population; however, a large population of patients are too sick from severe amyloid pathology on the kidney or heart to tolerate chemotherapy, necessitating the development of new strategies to reduce amyloid toxicity and improve peripheral target tissue function to treat this patient population. Here, we are establishing new multi-tissue strategies that reduce peripheral immunoglobulin light chain toxicity to provide new opportunities to reduce kidney and heart toxicity and allow chemotherapeutic access to the underlying diseased plasma cells in this currently untreatable patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Substance use and substance use disorders (SUD) have significant adverse health and social effects, generate considerable costs to the healthcare system and society, and are among of the most critical public health concerns in the United States. However, the identification, assessment, and treatment of patients with substance use and SUD are very sub-optimal in general medical settings (e.g., primary care, emergency departments, adolescent medicine, obstetrics/gynecology), where the majority of such patients are seen. The University of Pittsburgh Collaboration in Addiction Training Scholars (PittCATS) Program will support promising junior faculty for 3-5 years, provide them with comprehensive mentored career development experiences, and launch them on productive careers as independent investigators and leaders in substance use and SUD research in general medical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Frontotemporal lobar degeneration with TAR DNA-binding ~43kDa (TDP-43) inclusions (FTLD-TDP) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) share common pathological features but can present with heterogeneous clinical features including dementia (FTLD-TDP), motor neuron dysfunction (ALS), or both (ALS-FTD). The overall aim of this proposal is to leverage genotype and transcriptomic approaches to understand the underlying molecular mechanisms that contribute to the observed clinical heterogeneity across these sporadic TDP-43 proteinopathies. Disentangling this heterogeneity may help inform the development of therapeutic targets to attenuate the course of these devastating neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the Medical Scientist Training Program at Columbia University's Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons is to provide outstanding training in rigorous, responsible biomedical research that will benefit human health, integrated with exceptional training in modern principles and ethical practice of medicine and patient care. A longstanding challenge for modern medical practice is rapidly applying cutting-edge scientific discoveries into better diagnosis and treatments for patients. Training contemporary clinician-scientists in a highly integrated MD-PhD dual-degree program that places great emphasis on diversifying the trainee pool and retaining program graduates into long-term research careers would, therefore, be of substantial benefit to the health and well-being of the nation's populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our training program in human genetics offers pre-doctoral students the opportunity to learn and apply human genetics science in a highly collaborative and collegial environment rich in resources that can stimulate human genetics research. BioVU, the biobank at Vanderbilt University, for example, has more than 250,000 subjects and past human genetics students have been unusually productive because of the opportunities in conducting human genetic studies in these data. Our students receive a broad-based education and have traditionally pursued a wide range of research in human genetics and professional careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposed research aims to leverage novel technology that enables mesoscale neural activity measurements and identify emergent mesoscale features that control the expression of innate (instinctual) behaviors such as aggression, mating, and fear responses. The experience-induced behavioral plasticity observed in these behaviors can lead to mental disorders, including uncontrolled aggression, sex offenses, and generalized anxiety, affecting more than 20% of the human population. The high-resolution studies proposed here will generate novel theories and approaches towards identifying neural substrates that can be targeted to resolve or ameliorate conditions of great scientific, medical and societal significance.

PHR: Narrative We have recently uncovered a novel role for cholinergic basal forebrain glutamatergic neurons in body weight control. This project focuses on elucidating the underlying neurocircuits for the action of glutamatergic neurons in the control feeding and body weight control. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain microvascular dysfunction promotes impairments of neurovascular coupling (NVC) leading to cognitive dysfunction that precedes Alzheimer's disease (AD). Mitochondria are cellular energy sensors and our pilot studies observed alteration of cellular bioenergetics in brain microvessels in aged mice and mouse model of AD. Notably, we observed sex dependent alterations of microvascular bioenergetics during aging and in response to peroxynitrite. We propose that sex dependent peroxynitrite activity alters the microvascular bioenergetics leading to impaired NVC and cognitive function in AD. We believe that selectively targeting the peroxynitrite could benefit the sex-dependent microvascular bioenergetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults diagnosed with sarcopenia (e.g., loss of muscle mass, strength, and function) or frailty, are typically prescribed at-home resistance-based exercises to maintain and enhance physical function. Such prescriptions rely on self-report patient compliance to confirm whether the exercises are conducted and whether their exercise fidelity is sufficient to promote functional recovery. Herein, we propose to optimize the BandPass system, a Bluetooth-enabled resistance exercise band, patient app, clinician dashboard, and a cloud-based infrastructure that automatically senses the continuous force exerted during exercises to enable remote monitoring, compliance checking, and exercise classification while helping to overcome the current gaps of clinically tailored home exercise programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Postpartum depressive (PPD) symptoms are common among women following the birth of a child and increase the risk for developmental delays and behavioral problems in children. This research study will test the preliminary effects of a novel social media-based parenting program on measures of responsive parenting and child development among women with PPD. Findings from this research can inform public health interventions targeting women with PPD symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with hearing impairment and central neurological disorders have difficulty keeping track of speech and other complex sounds, particularly in challenging noisy environments. We seek to understand how populations of neurons in auditory cortex change their activity as the brain adapts to noisy environments. These experiments will provide insight into basic function of the healthy brain that can inform treatment of hearing disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Viruses and host are locked in an evolutionary conflict, yet our understanding of host defenses that restrict viral replication and viral countermeasures are poorly understood. This knowledge gap is driven primarily by host factors being redundant in host genomes and the efficient inactivation of these pathways by successful viruses. We overcome these obstacles to identify new virus-host interfaces and to define their function in host defense and in cellular physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: NARRATIVE Cellular senescence, a biological response to exposure to stress, including chemotherapy, is believed to prevent cancer progression. However, some phenotypes associated with cellular senescence, including invasion and metastasis, result in cancer progression. We propose test the investigate how senescence promotes cancer progression, and to identify novel therapeutic means to prevent breast cancer progression following exposure to chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the mechanisms contributing to immunological non-response to antiretroviral therapy (cART) in HIV-1 infected subjects by defining the bidirectional interaction between the gut microbiome and gut immune cells, in particular B cells. Specifically, we will dissect the clonal architecture and bacterial reactivity of intestinal IgA1 and IgA2 responses and their functional crosstalk with a) the gut microbiome; b) other elements of the mucosal immune system; and c) measures of viral persistence in the gut mucosa before and during cART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The computational enzyme modeling community is continuously seeking resources for a better understanding of enzyme structure, function and enzymatic reaction pathways, which will greatly advance drug design and enzyme bioengineering. Artificial Intelligence will be employed to facilitate computational modeling of two enzyme systems: 1) Chorismate mutase enzymes, which catalyze pericyclic rearrangement reactions to produce aromatic amino acids in bacteria, are a potential target for designing antibiotics; and 2) Cytochrome P450 which is a superfamily of enzymes that play key roles in the metabolism of drugs and other xenobiotics. Rigorous and automated quantum mechanics and molecular mechanics (QM/MM) and QM-clustering modeling design will be generated by data mining and machine learning techniques from existing and appreciative knowledge; and the output of this project will be systematic and well-formatted data as well as data mining and machine learning models which can generate computational protocol of these two enzymes, which potentially can be transferred to the study of other enzyme systems.

PROJECT_TITLE: Data Mining and Machine Learning Guided QM/MM and QM-Cluster Modeling of Enzymatic Reactions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While chemists have made great progress in the ability to synthesize important molecules for biomedical applications, there are many useful transformations that remain impossible using current methods. Here we take cues from nature's expert use of hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) to deliver two new of these aspirational reactions, modular radical hydrogenation and transpositional functionalization. We anticipate that these catalytic chemical transformations will unlock the ability to make previously-inaccessible bioactive molecules and make an impact on human health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Groundbreaking research and discovery in the life sciences in the 21st century are more interdisciplinary than ever. To expedite scientific advances in the “omics” era, it is critical to train the next generation of quantitative health science students who are strong in statistical genetics and genomics, computational biology, big data computing, reproducible research, with good knowledge in molecular biology, genetic epidemiology and genomic medicine, and who have strong skills in communication, grant and paper writing, teamwork, collaboration, and leadership.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Clinical research comes in many different shapes and sizes, and a robust trial innovation network must accommodate all trial types, which no single organization can do alone. Our TIC will be Engaging Cooperative Sites for Trial Acceleration, Trust, Innovation, and Capability (ECSTATIC). Led by Drs. Gordon Bernard, Wesley Self, and Christopher Lindsell, each seasoned in leading and collaborating with multisite clinical trial networks, we will embrace and draw on diverse expertise from 6 CTSA-aligned coordinating centers, the national Biostatistics, Epidemiology, and Research Design (BERD) group, health equity experts, and Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to build, test, and share new resources that will enhance and accelerate rigorous, reproducible research and improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Three-dimensional (3D) chromatin organization (chromatin interactome) plays a critical role in genome function and gene regulation. In this R35 grant application, I will develop model-based methods for imputing and normalizing chromatin chromatins at single cell resolution, identifying cell-type-specific long-range chromatin interactions, and predicting putative target genes of GWAS variants associated with complex human diseases and traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE and Relevance to Public Health Our proposed work will estimate total body creatine pool size by D3-creatine dilution, a novel and previously validated method that provides a direct and accurate estimate of total muscle mass from a single, fasting urine sample. Our objective is to measure total muscle mass (via the D3-creatine dilution method) in the Framingham Heart Study (FHS) and determine its association with genetic and non-genetic risk factors, and their relation with falls, injurious falls and fractures in two large, community-based cohort of older adults, FHS and the Osteoporotic Fractures in Men (MrOS) Study, thus providing new and important public health insights.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Minimally invasive surgeons are limited to a surface view of the intraoperative field as provided by real- time video. By adding ultrasound, this project will develop a new augmented reality visualization technology that will allow surgeons to see hidden structures such as tumors and blood vessels below the organ surfaces. The anticipated clinical benefits of augmented reality visualization are shorten procedure times, fewer complications, reduced blood loss, and expanded use of minimally invasive surgeries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with serious mental illness are grossly overrepresented in populations experiencing incarceration and homelessness, representing the culmination of health inequities and unmet mental health and social needs. This mixed methods K23 proposal aims to address important gaps in our understanding of the effects of incarceration on homelessness and downstream mental health and social service use by quantitative analysis of an existing linked administrative database, archival research, and direct ethnographic observations of individuals with SMI in jail. The proposed research responds to NIMH Strategic Priority 4 by strengthening the public health impact of NIMH supported research, particularly Priorities 4.1, 4.2, and 4.4, and the NIMH Division of Services and Intervention Research area of high priority to “Identify new targets for innovative intervention (development/refinement) and service delivery models through research that examines the burdens from mental illness as well as the current use, benefits, safety, costs, and unmet needs for mental health care.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney stone disease is increasingly common, causes significant co-morbidities and has a vast economic impact in adult patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Our preliminary data indicates that kidney stone disease may increase the rate of ADPKD progression. Based on this finding we will address the link between kidney stones and disease severity in ADPKD, and investigate whether frequent use of antibiotics poses a risk for kidney stone disease in individuals with ADPKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current study will determine the role of infant autonomic regulation of attention in the unfolding of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). This work will inform developmental models of ASD wherein disrupted autonomic regulation of attention has proximal effects on real-world interactions that may interfere with learning and have cascading effects on long-term outcomes. Findings will lead to new models for earlier intervention that enrich early experiences and enhance learning opportunities from the first months of life, ultimately improving lifelong outcomes for individuals with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This application’s long-term goal is to generate novel, efficacious strategies to combat challenging to treat multi-resistant bacterial infections. This study focuses on elucidating complex inter- and intraspecies bacterial interactions to uncover crucial insights about mechanisms bacteria use to synergize and compete in a human-like environment. These interactions using human-relevant microenvironments have not been addressed before.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed study is designed to target processing speed, a cognitive domain related directly to social functioning, which in turn, represents a vulnerability factor for psychosis. We have developed a new remotely-delivered intervention combining targeted cognitive training exercises and group support to directly impact processing speed, and at the same time, boost motivation and engagement in adolescents at risk for schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. New methods are needed to kill the deadly antibiotic-resistant opportunistic pathogen, Pseudomonas aeruginosa. R-pyocins are a group of lytic antimicrobials that target the outer lipopolysaccharide core and have been shown to be effective at killing susceptible P. aeruginosa isolates under laboratory conditions, however whether resistant isolates might be similarly susceptible under conditions that more accurately mimic those ongoing during infection is not known. We propose to test the R-pyocin susceptibility of a panel of P. aeruginosa isolates under conditions relevant to the cystic fibrosis lung environment and in an acute murine respiratory model of infection to provide the much-needed justification for further consideration of R-pyocins as potential antibacterial agents to treat P. aeruginosa infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. More than 20% of all Americans suffer from an autoimmune disease, like Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) or Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). Tissue and organ damage in these diseases are caused by cells of the immune system, which produce inflammatory mediators, and antibodies, which recognize and bind to self-tissues. The immediate goal of this proposal is to understand how B lymphocytes are activated to produce destructive antibodies with the long-term goal of identifying new therapeutics that can block production of these destructive antibodies in autoimmune patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The purpose of the Predoctoral Training Program in Genetics is to optimally prepare students in their PhD training in Genetics, to meet the challenging problems of genetics, genomics, bioinformatics and personal medicine, and to become leaders in the direction of new trends in Genetics research. Our mission for society is to generate scientists that can be at the forefront of Genetics research, who can in turn contribute to training and collaborating with physicians and other allied health professionals, and who can educate all members of society, who will increasingly need to understand genetic aspects of their own family's health care and individualized genomes. Because this need is among people from all walks of life, we emphasize diversity in our PhD students; with the pervasive implications of the individualized genome, including both the promises and the dangers of exploiting the information therein, the need to train competent PhD students is paramount.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Integrative Training Program in Developmental Process trains researchers in typical and atypical patterns of behavioral and brain development, with the goal of understanding how early achievements in that process (for example, motor development, language learning, sleep patterns) set the stage for and support later achievements (for example, in sustained attention, behavioral control, school success). By understanding how development builds on itself and the potential multiple pathways to healthy developmental outcomes, we may foster healthy outcomes in children facing challenges from poverty, from sensory-motor disabilities, and from developmental disorders such as autism.
PROJECT_TERMS: Developmental Process;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Integrative Developmental Process

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: While a majority of studies show the pain-facilitating aspect of injury-related glial/immune activity, a potential loss of inhibitory/protective neuroglial interactions in the development of persistent pain has been largely overlooked. We propose to analyze inhibitory glial/immune activity related to nerve injury and whether disrupted immune homeostasis in the brain descending circuitry contributes to the development of chronic pain. Exploring protective/homeostatic glial activity will fill the gap in our understanding and help to develop therapeutic strategies that emphasize inducing homeostatic glial activity to restore normal neuronal activity, instead of simply blocking glial activity for pain management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Modern biomedical technologies, including rapid single-cell and whole tissue sequencing, high- content mass spectrometry, and modern imaging, are allowing systems-level analyses of complex diseases, such as cancer, heart disease and diabetes. Interpreting the large and complex data sets produced by these techniques requires use, and often development, of novel computational approaches. The Curriculum in Bioinformatics and Computational Biology at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill provides the graduate training needed to develop and apply computational methods for biomedical research with the goal of developing novel therapeutic strategies for treating complex diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The development of alternative therapies for myocardial infarction is a necessity because of the large patient population. Innovative new approaches are needed, capable of application immediately following heart attack, to control deleterious processes leading to poor cardiac function following initial survival. This proposal seeks to develop new biomaterial based therapeutic platforms for treating acute myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Based on formative research with targeted populations, this UG3/UH3 application will develop and evaluate a theoretically based digital dental health promotion program designed to engage lower income, Black/African American, Latinx, and white non-Hispanic 7th and 8th grade students. The school-based, web-based intervention will address existing dental health disparities by providing access to the program to all students via school internet and digital devices. The long-term goal of this project is to facilitate healthy dental care habits for adolescents by reducing persistent oral health disparities and preventing oral disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Statement/Project Narrative Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is a common complication of cirrhosis and associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. Furthermore, due to the worldwide pandemic of multidrug-resistant organisms, the efficiency of antimicrobial therapy, the current standard of care, continues to deteriorate; hence, the development of novel management strategies is imperative. This proposal aims to advance our understanding of SBP pathophysiology through elucidating the role and significance of peritoneal macrophage, with the ultimate goal of defining novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Anemia is the most common blood disorder affecting more than two billion people worldwide, and occurs when red blood cells are reduced or when red blood cells do not function properly. Iron is essential to form hemoglobin, a protein within red blood cells that delivers oxygen to body tissues. Our studies reveal a novel iron-dependent mechanism for regulating red blood cell numbers that will provide new insights into the pathophysiology of blood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii is a cause of highly recalcitrant diseases in hospitals that compromise our ability to deliver health care to patients. This application proposes to study a unique two- protein system that is the global control center for both antibiotic resistance and pathogenicity in the bacterium. This research will uncover how the system modulates envelope synthesis to respond to antimicrobial stress, facilitate disease, and cause antibiotic failure, and will form a base for the development of strategies for lowering the defenses of the pathogen to enhance the treatment of nosocomial disease.

PHR: Mismatch negativity (MMN) is an auditory neurophysiological measure that correlates with the severity of cognitive impairment in schizophrenia. This project will develop animal models of MMN for use in early screening of novel therapeutic candidates for treatment of schizophrenia. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life adversity, including in utero and early childhood, may lead to lifelong physical and mental health, substance use, and behavioral problems. This longitudinal, population-based cohort study aims to elucidate the early and middle childhood health and healthcare outcomes of exposure to parental opioid use in early life. Results will shed light on the intergenerational effects of America's opioid crisis and inform the development of policies and early interventions for improving the wellbeing of children affected by parental opioid use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The overarching hypothesis of this project is that reassortment of segmented viruses plays a major role not only to drive their diversification and evolution, but to dramatically alter their ecology and transmission dynamics. Specifically, we aim to 1) develop mathematical models of the intracellular life cycle for a family of segmented viruses to quantify for the first time their viral replication dynamics and reassortment frequencies, and 2) develop standardised sequencing protocols and novel phylogenetic methods to quantify the evolutionary and epidemiological implications of reassortment for Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV). A biobank with clinical and field samples from CCHFV endemic regions in Turkey and Tajikistan will be set up in this project. Clinical and field data will be leveraged to ensure our methods and results have the potential to inform public health strategies, predict outbreak risk and contribute to the One Health approach for the prevention and control of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Intraepithelial lymphocytes are a subset of T cells that reside in the host epithelium and play pivotal roles in barrier maintenance and protection. We propose to elucidate a novel function of small intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes in the host defense against rotavirus, a major enteric viral pathogen in children. Our results will facilitate the rational design of novel therapeutics and vaccine design for enteric viruses, thereby reducing rotavirus infection-related diarrhea and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Exosomes are nanoscale vesicles circulating in our body, and the potential of exosome-based diagnosis and therapies has been widely recognized. However, we have limited information about how exosome generation is regulated and how its molecular contents are determined. In this Project, we will investigate the role of cellular metabolism in exosome biogenesis, which will deepen our understanding of exosomes and facilitate their use in clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotic resistant bacteria already cause over 2.8 million illnesses and 35,000 deaths every year, with antibiotic misuse incurring up to $42 billion in avoidable costs per year in the US alone. Urinary tract infections (UTIs) in particular are the most common human bacterial infection accounting for 25-50% of antibiotic prescriptions with resistance rates among causative bacteria now exceeding 20% for commonly used antibiotics. The most important action to slow the spread of these resistant infections is improving antibiotic prescribing and stewardship, which this project seeks to improve through novel machine learning and data- driven methods to measure and predict effective antibiotic choices for urinary tract infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A key step in the treatment of invasive bacterial infection is the selection of antibiotics that are capable of killing the causative pathogen. Yet, many patients fail to improve despite treatment with antibiotics that have proven in vitro activity against the invading bacteria. The objective of this proposal is to understand the bacterial and host factors underlying antibiotic failure during invasive Staphylococcus aureus infection of bone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  αβT lymphocytes recognize host cells that have been altered by infections or malignancies, and these vital lymphocytes are dependent upon force applied to their surface αβT cell receptors to tune recognition acuity. These forces arise from T cell motions locally (internally) or as T cells traffic through the host tissues (externally). By characterizing the biological and structural features of this force-dependent process, we shall be uniquely positioned to understand and ultimately manipulate T cell activation, fostering activation in patients with infectious diseases or cancers and inhibiting activation in patients with autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative  The mosquito disease vector, Aedes aegypti, is troubling because it spreads viruses that cause diseases such as dengue, yellow fever, and Zika, which infect >100,000,000 people/year. The goals of the proposed research are to define members of two classes of receptors that mosquitoes use to find humans, clarify mechanisms through which they sense repellents, and to improve a promising approach for suppressing populations of Aedes aegypti. These studies could lead to the design of new traps, deterrent devices and genetic control strategies to reduce mosquito-borne disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE & PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT This high-impact application has critical ramifications for prostate cancer management and provides a paradigm-shifting diagnostic and therapy approach by exploiting the newly discovered biological function of PSMA, particularly for castrate resistant prostate cancer patients, who are in dire need of new therapy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Epilepsy is a highly prevalent neurological disorder and it is frequently associated with psychiatric and neurologic comorbidities, such as difficulty with memory that degrade the quality of life. We have identified novel anti- inflammatory drug-like compounds that target the EP2 receptor, the major mediator of inflammation driven by cyclooxygenase 2, and validated proof-of-concept in cellular and animal models of epilepsy. We now propose to do additional lead-optimization studies to develop a preclinical candidate for advancement into IND enabling studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT 1: PROJECT NARRATIVE Project 1 will apply innovative scientific methods and a community-based research approach to characterize the presence of multiple regulated and unregulated/unmonitored drinking water contaminants, and advance understanding about the perinatal health effects of drinking water contaminant mixtures in some of California’s most vulnerable communities. Knowledge generated from this work, including the effects of drinking water exposures on birth outcomes, tap water sampling results for contaminants of current and emerging health concern such as PFAS, nitrate, arsenic, and hexavalent chromium, will benefit affected communities through novel and ethical report-back to participants, communities, and agency decision-makers that informs public health strategies and elucidates solutions to prevent and reduce harmful drinking water exposures among community water system and domestic well users in California.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In contrast to growth charts for height and weight, there is no accepted reference standard to anchor measures of individual differences in brain anatomy from magnetic resonance imaging studies, which has hampered neurodevelopmental investigations of the psychosis spectrum. Leveraging a successful multi-site imaging consortium, this proposal will use recently validated computational approaches to generate brain chart models for a rich set of brain morphological features across neuroanatomical scales. These charts will be used to identify heritable brain profiles, in the form of developmental imaging phenotypes benchmarked by brain chart norms, that are associated with evolution of psychosis spectrum symptoms.

PHR: PROJECT 2: NARRATIVE Childhood immunizations are a cornerstone of public health prevention with enormous health and societal benefits. This study will investigate if prenatal and early childhood exposure to metals and PFAS, two common environmental contaminants, influence the developing immune system and response to childhood immunizations. Findings from this study will inform public health prevention strategies and risk assessment of multiple contaminants.

PHR: PROJECT 3: PROJECT NARRATIVE To remediate mixed contaminant sites including per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances (PFAS) and other highly halogenated compounds, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), polybrominated biphenyl ethers (PBDEs), and chlorinated solvents, we need new approaches that are selective and highly reactive. This project will apply molecular biology, protein engineering, and high-throughput assays to identify aerobic and anaerobic microbial enzymatic-radical systems that can treat multiple classes of pollutants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT 4: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to develop new approaches to remediate highly halogenated and hydrophobic contaminants that are resistant to oxidation including hexachlorobenzene, hexabromobenzene, polychlorinated biphenyl (PCBs), polybrominated biphenyl ethers (PBDEs), per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances, and chlorinated solvents. We will investigate new techniques that exploit novel radical species capable of dehalogenating recalcitrant contaminants, determine conditions that minimize the formation of toxic transformation products, and develop kinetic models that can be used by field engineers. We also will characterize the major transformation products produced during the treatment process and their environmental fate and potential for remediation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: CORE A: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Administration Core (AC) will provide leadership and support to address complex challenges related to Superfund contaminants including: characterizing mixed and early-life exposures and perinatal health effects in disadvantaged communities; understanding interactions among mixed exposures at hazardous waste sites and in health impact assessment; and, developing novel methods for in situ remediation and remediation of persistent chemicals. Thus, the AC will ensure program relevance by responding to all four SRP mandates, and the needs of stakeholders—including those tasked with advancing California’s Human Right to Water Law—and the Research Translation Coordinator will provide timely information and tools (remediation technology, data and analytics) to stakeholders, end-users, communities, and organizations. Our proposed infrastructure and strategy will efficiently leverage the diverse expertise and resources of Center investigators, stakeholders and collaborators, to ensure improved public health and environmental protection through regulatory and policy change.

PHR: Project Narrative Our center (University of Alabama at Birmingham and University of Alabama) will join other centers from the consortium in enrolling pregnant women and their infants in a comprehensive prospective, longitudinal and multimodal data collection. We will examine variability in outcomes and the effect of substance exposure in utero as well as other experiences in development and the interaction with genetic, biological and endocrine system. Our center, has extensive experience in participating in similar multicenter studies and, will be able to enroll dyads of mothers and their infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to public health This project will develop a nondestructive assay for prostate cancer prognostication based on quantitative histomorphometric analysis of 3D pathology datasets of prostate specimens (biopsies and surgical excisions). This project will demonstrate that computational 3D pathology is superior to computational 2D pathology (including existing clinical nomograms) for distinguishing between aggressive and indolent prostate cancers, and therefore has value for guiding treatment decisions by urologists and oncologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: CORE B (CEC): PROJECT NARRATIVE The Community Engagement Core - Water Equity Science Shop (CEC-WESS) will expand its impactful work to address California’s water equity challenges by leveraging the biomedical and water quality engineering expertise of Berkeley’s Superfund Research Center to advance the priorities of community-based non- governmental organizations (NGOs) and agency stakeholders working to advance CA’s Human Right to Water law. We will build upon WESS member Community Water Center’s online Drinking Water Tool by integrating new data layers that identify multiple drinking water threats, create community-informed metrics of drinking water quality and accessibility among domestic well communities to track agency progress on Human Right to Water implementation, and develop digital tools and an online portal (“What’s In My Water?”) for water justice organizations to integrate and visualize water quality data from multiple sources, and domestic well users to interpret their water testing results and learn how to protect themselves from harmful contaminants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  ROLE OF SERPINB3 IN GLIOBLASTOMA CANCER STEM CELLS Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common primary malignant brain tumor, and a population of cancer stem cells (CSCs) allows the tumor the tumor to quickly regrow after aggressive standard-of-care treatment. The objective of my project is to determine the mechanism through which GBM CSCs signal through junctional adhesion molecule-A (JAM-A) via Serpin B3, a serine/cysteine protease inhibitor that interacts with JAM-A and has been shown to signal through TGF-β in other cancers. The successful completion of this proposal will further our understanding of the signaling networks used by GBM CSCs for their self-renewal, identify new therapeutic targets and provide essential training toward my development as a physician scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: CORE C: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Data Management and Analysis (DMAC; Core C) will provide support across all projects and cores for all aspects of the Center data, including platforms for storing and sharing data, data quality control, implementing common data structures to make sure they correspond to relevant standards, consultations for design issues, oversee analyses with existing methodology and development of new methodologies for novel intersections of data and scientific questions not currently addressed. We will collaborate with project leaders to present searchable pre-analysis plans as well as shareable data constructed according FAIR standards (https://www.go- fair.org/fair-principles/). Critical to the success of the Center will be our close cooperation of Center researchers and the implementation of existing cutting-edge machine learning methodology, with the goal of translation of these new tools to the wider research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: CORE D (RESEARCH EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING COORDINATION CORE): NARRATIVE Berkeley SRP Trainees are critical to achieving the goals related to the central theme of our Center: “Systems approach to address the complex problems associated with Superfund contaminants.” These complex problems require diverse perspectives and skills; cross-disciplinary knowledge and interdisciplinary research to provide relevant knowledge and tools to reduce contamination and adverse health effects; and communication and leadership skills to work in multidisciplinary teams and with diverse communities and stakeholders to effect regulatory and policy change. The Research Experience and Training Coordination Core (RETCC) will recruit Trainees from diverse backgrounds, provide a holistic training experience beyond each trainee’s main field of focus or expertise to increase trainee understanding and engagement, foster interdisciplinary skills and mindset, increase social and cultural awareness, and strengthen professional development and career skills to address current problems and prepare future leaders in environmental health science and engineering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco taxes are widely used and demonstrably effective in decreasing tobacco use and attendant diseases; however, the impact of taxes is complicated by an evolving and complex tobacco marketplace. This project will examine the effects of four novel tax proposals on tobacco product purchasing, including specific examinations of how these proposals interact with tobacco-related socioeconomic disparities and regulation designed to limit the nicotine in conventional cigarettes. The findings of this project will inform tobacco regulation to reduce health inequities and improve overall public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The autoimmune disease, Sjögren’s syndrome, affects almost 1% of the population, while one of its principal characteristics is a debilitating dry eye disease associated with inflammation of the tear-producing lacrimal gland. Our research links accumulation of a protease, cathepsin S, in the lacrimal gland and its subsequent altered transport between membranes in lacrimal gland acinar cells, to the development of Sjögren’s syndrome- associated dry eye. Here, we explore the mechanisms underlying the increased expression and altered membrane sorting of cathepsin S in Sjögren’s syndrome-associated dry eye, and test the effects of drugs targeting protein phosphatase 2A and PIKFYVE to reduce this disease in murine models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Emotion-regulatory failures are central to mood and anxiety disorders, which afflict over 20% of the adult population in the United States and are challenging to treat. Extant evidence implicates altered function of the lateral prefrontal cortex (LPFC) in these disorders, but the specific contributions of LPFC to adaptive emotion remain poorly understood. The proposed studies harness a combination of state-of-the-art brain imaging analyses and methods that permit causal inference to uncover the roles of distinct LPFC regions in emotional responding and regulation, thereby advancing the development of a model that can be applied to optimize treatment for individuals who suffer from mood and anxiety disorders associated with LPFC dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is a significant public healthcare burden in the USA, with approximately 400,000 heart failure- related deaths occurring yearly. As a promising treatment for end-stage heart failure, the left ventricular assist device (LVAD) is used to help a failing heart pump blood; however, with complications, such as bleeding, stroke, thrombosis, and driveline infection. To mitigate these problems, we propose to develop a novel magnetic levitated LVAD by adopting expandable stented inlet and slippery hydrophilic (SLIC) coatings to improve hemocompatibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Circular ribonucleic acid (circRNA) molecules are enriched in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCC) but their potential functions remain unclear. Through our study of human papillomavirus (HPV) circRNAs, we have developed novel approaches and tools to study circular RNA in HNSCC. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the most common cause of severe vision loss among older individuals. Variations in multiple genes strongly affect the risk of developing AMD but a substantial portion of the genetic architecture of risk, progression, response to treatment, and in different genetic ancestries remains unexplained. The International AMD Genomic Consortium (IAMDGC) addresses these gaps and seeks to develop a complete understanding of the genetic underpinnings of AMD as a pathway to better treatments and preventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary cilia are small projections found on many human cells involved in receiving and interpreting signals from other cells. Misactivation of Hedgehog signaling, one type of ciliary signaling, causes cancers, including basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma. We are investigating the mechanisms by which Hedgehog ciliary signaling occurs in embryonic development and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Cryptococcus neoformans is a pathogenic fungus that causes fatal meningoencephalitis in immunocompromised individuals including HIV/AIDS patients worldwide. In this project, mechanisms involved in regulating cryptococcal IRIS will be studied using a murine model that reproduces key aspects of cryptococcal IRIS of HIV/AIDS patients. Understanding the mechanisms involving in regulating cryptococcal IRIS of HIV/AIDS patients is fundamental for developing therapeutic strategy for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent genomic studies have uncovered many novel putative oncogenes and tumor suppressors of B-cell lymphomas, but these remain to be functionally validated and characterized. Among the most common and co- occurring genomic alterations is a mutation in the MYD88 gene (MYD88L265P), and a large deletion of chromosome 6 (Chr6q deletion), which are exceptionally frequent among two important subtypes of B-cell lymphomas, lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (LPL) and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of activated B-cell type (ABC-DLBCL). Therefore, the studies proposed here to study the molecular mechanisms by which MYD88L265P mutation, Chr6q deletion and other LPL/ABC-DLBCL-associated genomic alterations induce lymphomagenesis will significantly move the field forward to provide discoveries which improve diagnosis, evaluate prognosis and lead to the development of novel and more effective therapies as well as cellular and organismal models to treat these and other types of B-cell lymphomas.

PHR: Project Narrative Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Suicide is the 2nd leading cause of death in adolescents, but our ability to predict and prevent suicidality is remarkably limited. MicroRNAs are important transducers of environmental effects on gene expression. We will test if microRNAs are associated with suicidality, by using brain-derived plasma exosomal microRNAs from peripheral blood, and examine if they can be used as ‘‘molecular tools’’ to identify suicide and depression risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of our proposal is to achieve equitable access to state-of-the-art genomic medical care to sick newborns in community centers that predominately care for low-income and racial/ethnic minority populations through the creation of a virtual genome center (VIGOR). VIGOR will provide a venue for physician and family education, genomic expert consultation, reanalysis of unsolved sequencing data, and access to cutting edge therapeutic innovation, thereby facilitating institutionalization of genomic best practices in community settings, and not just highly specialized referral centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to describe the neurobiological and behavioral processes underlying a critical dimensional phenotype of depressive illness, Angry Hostility, which refers to the tendency to experience anger, hostility, and irritability following negative experiences and to respond in an aggressive, overly hostile manner. We will examine whether this phenotype is associated with specific patterns of abnormal brain function and behavior in emotional contexts. Findings will help us to identify neurobiological targets that we could use to develop more effective, individually tailored treatments for adults with depression who have high levels of Angry Hostility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mexican American families share similar elevated risks for obesity and obesity-related conditions, such as type 2 diabetes. Because negative family interactions and relationships (e.g., poor communication, high conflict, low emotional closeness) are associated with obesity treatment outcomes, this study tests a behavioral weight management intervention that provides relationship skills counseling to mothers and adult daughters. The goal is to improve family interaction patterns to buffer challenges and strengthen collaboration for eating and physical activity behaviors that support long-term weight management and thus provide an effective obesity treatment approach to address a major public health concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Many patients for whom the results of genetic testing change medical management are not currently getting such testing. Utilizing that infrastructure, we propose a highly innovative study using implementation science to study nudges in the electronic health record (EHR) to influence both clinicians and patients to increase the use of genetic testing in clinical care, building upon the infrastructure that we have already built to deliver genomic medicine in the EHR. Further, we plan structured dissemination of all existing and planned protocols and EHRbased algorithms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Relevance: Twin epidemics are now affecting Americans: the decades-long HIV pandemic, in which over 675,000 have died and approximately 1.3 million are currently living with HIV; and the recent opioid crisis, killing approximately 130 people a day and with 2.1 million people having an opioid abuse disorder. There is a considerable intersection between the populations affected by HIV and opioids, as well as a common site of damage, the brain. New single-cell technologies can provide new insight into the effects of HIV and opioids on specific brain cells. We will combine these with virologic studies on the brain to yield insight in ways to prevent and/or treat damage to the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL CENTER NARRATIVE The central theme of the proposed Program is to define specific aspects of environmental, microbial and mammalian biomolecular responses to environmental contaminants (dioxin and dioxin-like compounds) that act as ligands for the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR). Emphasis will be on two major areas: (a) characterize specific biological, physical and chemical criteria governing the environmental fate of AhR ligands; and (b) develop state of the art remediation technology to reduce toxicity of AhR ligands.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dioxin-like halogenated aromatic hydrocarbons (DLC) are ubiquitous environmental contaminants that suppress antibody responses. A population of white blood, termed CD5+ B cells, is exquisitely sensitive to suppression by DLC and accounts for impairment of antibody responses. This project uses human white blood cells to elucidate the mechanism by which DLC suppress antibody responses in CD5+ B cells and also proposes to use the percentage of circulating CD5+ B cells as an indicator of human sensitivity to immune suppression by DLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Program Narrative We have discovered a new complex regulatory element called the DR/DQ-super enhancer (DR/DQ-SE) that regulates the expression of the major histocompatibility complex class-II (MHC-II) proteins, which are critical for initiating and sustaining immune responses associated with a significant number of human diseases including infection, autoimmunity, and cancer. Here, we seek to elucidate the molecular and biochemical properties of the DR/DQ-SE and determine how and when it functions. Completion of our studies will shed new insight into how genes are organized and regulated, human variation impacts immunity, as well as how the immune system could be manipulated for control of many diseases and improved immunization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A person’s daily life events are linked by semantic and causal relations into a complex network; the proposed studies examine how human memory and its underlying cortical dynamics are influenced by the structure of these “event networks”, as well as what changes when people choose what they want to do and learn, as opposed to being passive observers. These factors are relevant to mental health: for example, cause-effect beliefs are strikingly disordered in schizophrenia. Achieving an improved understanding of how the brain encodes real-world events, and reconstructs them from memory when needed, will ultimately help guide the development of better treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thyroid hormones regulate cellular energy metabolism throughout the body and chemical disruption of this function in humans causes neurological, hearing, and vision dysfunction in children, as well as metabolic disorders and cancer in adults. Due to the complex nature of the thyroid system, the way many Superfund chemicals disrupt thyroid function is unclear. We propose to bioengineer thyroid and liver microtissues and use them along with computational modelling to understand how these chemicals cause toxicity, test chemicals and their mixtures for their ability to disrupt thyroid signaling, and translate our findings to determine how chemical exposures might affect human populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) is a sensor protein for environmental pollutants such as 2,3,7,8- tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin and related compounds. These chemicals have been linked to adverse outcomes, including non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and this project will investigate the link between AhR activation and changes in cholesterol homeostasis in TCDD elicited hepatotoxicity and the progression of NAFLD. Given that ~20 million Americans suffer from NAFLD, investigating the link between AhR activation and the progression of NAFLD is of national importance.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Prostate cancer patients on drugs that block testosterone action ultimately become resistant to therapy and follow a downhill course with poor outcomes. One mechanism of resistance is a process called lineage plasticity, in which cancerous cells acquire a new identity. In this proposal, we will use complementary biological and computational tools to determine how exactly cells become plastic and resistant to drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some anaerobic bacteria are capable of breathing dioxins. We aim to leverage this capability to develop integrated methods for economical clean-up of dioxin-contaminated sites. Key advancements include reduction in time to clean-up and toxicity, development of biomarkers indicative of the rates, and establishment of decision- making tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Project 5 directly addresses NIEHS Superfund Mandate #4 for the development of “basic biological, chemical, and physical methods to reduce the amount and toxicity of hazardous substances” [22]. Project 5 will help USEPA understand whether activated carbon (AC) is an effective soil/sediment amendment to sequester PCDD/Fs in forms that eliminate their mammalian bioavailability and toxicity, and thus protect human and ecosystem health. Project 5 will test a cause-and-effect relationship for the rates at which AC can reduce or eliminate mammalian bioavailability by measuring a multi-year time series for a) the rates at which AC amendments accumulate PCDD/Fs and b) the mammalian bioavailabilities of PCDD/Fs from these same soils.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The present proposal is directed to develop a non-hormonal agent that could be used as an oral and reversible contraceptive for males. The goals of the project are: 1) to develop a lead and a backup compound that can selectively inhibit the sperm specific NKAα4 to block sperm function, and that will be ready for testing on mice; and 2) to perform preclinical investigational new drug (IND)-enabling studies, which will allow moving these compounds forward for their use as male contraceptives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Representing ~3% of the U.S. population, non-elderly disabled Medicare beneficiaries (henceforth “disabled beneficiaries”) account for ~25% of overdose deaths and hospitalizations related to prescription opioids. To identify overprescribing without directly restricting patient access, the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) required Medicare Part D plans to incorporate a set of opioid safety edits into their drug utilization review systems, effective January 1, 2019. Our project seeks to inform policymakers about the implications of the 2019 Medicare Part D safety policy for an understudied, high-risk population of disabled beneficiaries who are prescribed long-term, high-dose opioid therapy, which will further enable policymakers to develop clinically and culturally nuanced policies and practices tailored to the disabled population, the racial/ethnic minority patients and rural patients, and the evolving pandemic/post-pandemic environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to expand our existing close collaboration with the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services through a novel set of engagement activities that will listen to three Michigan communities affected by dioxins, empower them to make informed prevention decisions through health education interventions, and evaluate the impacts of those engagements. We will innovate on our previous work by leveraging the state of the science on trust, risk, and community engagement to optimally position the engagements to build trusting relationships between the Department and Michigan communities. We also propose to disseminate what we learn to our wider Center and the entire Superfund Research Program to better position them to build trust with the various individuals and groups impacted by their work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Role of BCL10 somatic mutations in lymphomagenesis and response to BCR-targeted therapies PROJECT NARRATIVE: C1/BN2 lymphomas, a newly discovered aggressive lymphoma, are characterized by somatic mutations in the BCL10 gene, which are rare in other lymphoma subtypes. Elucidation of the structural, biochemical and functional changes induced by BCL10 somatic mutations will advance our knowledge of the underlying molecular mechanisms by which different BCL10 mutations drive lymphomagenesis and inform the design and preclinical development of new treatment strategies.

This training program is uniquely co-directed by an academic institution - Northeastern University and a non-academic institution - Silent Spring Institute, a science-based/community-based participatory research environmental non-profit organization. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is relevant to public health and cancer prevention because it will provide comprehensive data on the influence of Facebook food advertisements on Black and White adolescents' eating behaviors, and increase mechanistic knowledge of communication strategies that influence the number of calories purchased and consumed by adolescents. Once such knowledge is gained, there is potential for significant advances in the development of interventions seeking to establish lifelong cancer-prevention dietary habits among adolescents. The project is relevant to the mission of the National Cancer Institute because it aims to identify factors in the new media ecosystem that may contribute to behaviors that increase risk for diet-related cancers, and it provides a new framework for understanding how the participatory social media ecosystem affects cancer prevention behaviors among youth who are targeted with unhealthy food and beverage advertisements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This project will clarify epigenetic mechanisms by which tuberculosis (TB) subverts immune homeostasis and increases the risk of post-TB mortality. The information gleaned will have practical applications, such as the identification of mechanisms and drugs that can reverse detrimental epigenetic scars, restore immune homeostasis, and decrease post-TB mortality. This information is necessary for the establishment of therapies to revive host immunity and thereby improving treatment efficacy and lowering TB mortality.

PHR: Project Narrative The predoctoral Neuroscience Training Program at the University of California, Berkeley seeks to educate future leaders in neuroscience research by providing broad neuroscience training from molecules to mind, including both basic and disease-related research, with a major focus on advanced methods. Our program combines flexible coursework, rigorous research training, substantial quantitative and professional skills training, and supportive advising. Our goal is to fuel paradigm shifts in how we study the brain, and to educate scientists who can translate basic discoveries into solutions for human neurological diseases.
