IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human skin diseases are thought to result from abnormal immune cells that reside in diseased organs. Experiments in this grant application will discover how specific immune cells are able to take up residence in skin early in life and how errors in this process can lead to skin diseases later in life. Our results may help establish new therapeutic approaches for patients with Atopic Dermatitis as well as other inflammatory skin diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Relevance to public health: The development of a focused ultrasound treatment for Skin and soft tissue abscesses will improve patients’ lives because it is minimally or noninvasive, has less procedural pain, can be performed in an out-patient setting, and is fast and convenient. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A critical step towards a broader use of mesenchymal stem cells in therapeutic tissue regeneration is to optimize approaches to maintain stem cell pools that enable healing and replacement of dead terminally differentiated cells in these new tissues or organs. This project is centered on the study of mechanisms regulating the generation and maintenance of neurovascular stem cell niches when dental pulp stem cells are used for tissue regeneration. Optimized approaches that support the function of these specialized stem cell niches will contribute to improving the long-term outcomes of stem cell-based therapies for tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury is one of the most common kidney pathologies and a common cause of chronic kidney disease leading to dramatically reduced life expectancy. To date there are no clinically proven therapies for treating acute kidney injury. This application identifies dicarboxylic medium chain fatty acids that protects the kidney against acute kidney injury and has significant therapeutic potential to treat the ever-growing number of acute kidney injury patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Dysfunctional inflammatory response to modified lipids and bacterial metabolites leads to unresolved and chronic inflammation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We explore the world around us through 3D body movement, but most neuroscience research focuses on more restrained movement. In this planning project, we will integrate 3D behavioral tracking and wireless neurotechnology with our experimental and theoretical expertise in animal behavior. We will study how different areas of the brain work together to encode movement, and enable a future project to understand the fundamental question of how the brain coordinates movement of the entire body in 3D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Histotripsy is a new method of non-invasive surgery using focused ultrasound. This proposal seeks to improve the procedure by developing optimized methods for correcting wavefront aberration caused by varying speed of sound in different abdominal tissue layers overlying the target. By correcting aberration, the range of targets in the body and population of patients which can be treated with histotripsy will be greatly expanded.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal has direct public health relevance since it proposes novel strategies to prevent and treat heart failure which is a major public health problem with a worldwide prevalence of 38 million. By identifying the underlying mechanisms of heart failure, our studies should allow rational development of effective therapeutic approaches to prevent myocardial fibrotic remodeling and heart failure. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of heart diseases worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For children with cleft palate, failed surgeries and corresponding speech issues result in pervasive communication disorders that limit participation in society and are accompanied by a financial burden for families. This study will quantify anatomy and speech production before and after palate repair surgery for infants with cleft palate to identify mechanisms for surgical selection and early speech monitoring. Results of this research will provide essential information about patient-specific intervention and help us move toward understanding speech development and advancing treatment outcomes in individuals with repaired cleft palate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Family and friend caregivers of patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT) confront substantial psychological and caregiving burden as they provide support for patients during a prolonged transplant hospitalization, manage complex medications and weekly outpatient medical appointment schedules during an intense post-transplant recovery period, and cope with the uncertainty of the patient’s long-term prognosis. Despite the immense physical and psychological burden placed on these caregivers, interventions to address the needs of this vulnerable population are lacking. This proposal seeks to assess the efficacy and potential for scalability and implementation of a psychosocial intervention (BMT-CARE) to provide caregivers of patients undergoing HCT with the skills to effectively cope with the patients’ illness with the goals of improving caregivers’ quality of life, mood, burden, and self-efficacy, patient-reported psychosocial outcomes, and patients’ and caregivers’ health care utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to improve treatment outcomes for patients with external locally advanced cancer that causes airway obstructions. These patients are not candidates for surgery and have no effective treatments. We propose that patients will benefit from a promising combination of interstitial photodynamic therapy with low dose radiotherapy that preliminary data show to safely ablate tumor and improve survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with severe fatty liver disease-non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) are at higher risk for adverse hepatic outcomes, including scarring of the liver and liver cancer. In this application, we propose to examine potentially critical cell signaling pathways (Sirtuin and TGF-β) and their roles in liver inflammation, and cancer development. Our study will provide critical new insights and potential treatment targets for fatty liver disease, and liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of acquired resistance to EGFR-targeted cancer is a key clinical obstacle in the treatment of lung cancer and hence, strategies to effectively delay and/or overcome acquired resistance are highly desirable and urgently needed in the clinic. We are particularly interested in revealing the mechanisms underlying the acquired resistance through fully understanding the biology of EGFR inhibitors in sensitive and resistant cells or tumors. This proposal will primarily focus on the critical roles of hTERT/telomerase modulation in EGFR-targeted cancer therapy and on developing effective strategies to delay and overcome acquired resistance through targeting hTERT/telomerase or telomere.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pattern in which neurons are interconnected is a powerful determinant of how the brain functions, and experience-dependent changes in these connection patterns likely underlie learning and memory. However, the fundamental rules that link circuit connectomes to information processing are unknown, and it is unclear how activity during experience specifically modifies the connectivity within a neural network to allow memories to be later retrieved or how this process is pathologically altered in human neurological disorders. This research will identify the relationship between connection patterns at the cellular level and network function at the circuit level to reveal fundamental principles that govern information processing, memory formation, and retrieval.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Aging is a risk factor for many chronic conditions including Alzheimer’s disease related dementias (ADRD) and impacts patient outcomes after traumatic brain injury (TBI). Aging can be chronologic aging (time since birth) or biological aging that may differ substantially from chronological age for some individuals. Another risk factor in addition to aging for ADRD is TBI particularly severe TBI. This project brings together epigenetic aging and TBI by investigating the effect of epigenetic age acceleration present acutely after TBI on patient outcomes after severe TBI. This knowledge could assist in improving long term outcomes for individuals who have suffered a severe TBI including mitigating risk of ADRD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public policies are crucial tools for influencing consumer behaviors and health outcomes. This study will develop novel causal approaches for estimating the effect of public policies under complex real-world settings such as spillover, substitution, and sociodemographic and geographic diversity. These new causal approaches will be used to assess the effect of the Philadelphia beverage tax on consumer purchasing behaviors, consumption, and individual-level health outcomes and provide guidance to policymakers designing future policies in different demographic and contextual settings.

PHR: Project Narrative Neuroendocrine prostate cancer (NEPC) is the most lethal form of the disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 2.05 million children in the US are diagnosed with autism, and the majority of them do not achieve language outcomes within the typical range even when they receive timely early intervention. Given the strong link between early vocabulary and later language outcomes, this project seeks to understand whether autistic children can learn novel words from infant-directed speech, a common way language input is provided to young children. The project is relevant to NIH and NIDCD’s mission as findings have the potential to provide insights into the type of language input that fosters language development in autistic children and inform parent-training intervention programs for autistic children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is the most effective psychological treatment for anxiety and obsessive compulsive related disorders, yet approximately half of patients with these disorders who receive CBT fail to achieve sustained clinical remission. No reliable biomarker of CBT non-response exists. This study will determine whether early changes in a specific biomarker, self-focused attention, will represent a sensitive predictor and potential mechanism of CBT non-response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mechanisms and pathways that operate during the onset and progression of obesity and type 2 diabetes (T2D) are not fully understood. We will take advantage of emerging observations that modifications on ribonucleic acids (RNA) functionally impact metabolic tissues and recent development of enabling methods that sequence RNA modifications with base resolution precision. We seek to map and investigate functionally important RNA modifications in metabolic cells from humans with obesity and type 2 diabetes with the long- term goal of gaining new insights into the pathophysiology of this chronic disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The skin surface serves as a barrier against invading microbes and environmental chemicals. The proposed research will investigate microbial enzymes and host cell signals that disrupt the skin barrier and drive inflammatory responses. The goal of this research is to understand how these enzymes and signals trigger skin inflammation and produce knowledge essential for the development of new therapies for inflammatory skin diseases such as atopic dermatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Supporting mobility at the same age as their peers, can have positive effects on the social, emotional, and even cognitive development of children with Down Syndrome, who typically are delayed in meeting developmental milestones. Our research aims to find out if two specific mobility aids, partial bodyweight support and powered wheelchair that can be used in both sitting and standing positions, are effective in helping young children with Down syndrome develop their mobility skills and engage in play. We will use wearable sensors and machine learning methods to measure if children with Down Syndrome move around more while using the mobility aids and how their bodies respond to the devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Structural biology is the field of science that focuses on understanding the structure, function, and interactions of biological macromolecules, such as proteins and nucleic acids, and their complexes. It involves the use of various experimental techniques, including X-ray crystallography, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, cryo-electron microscopy, and computational modeling to determine the 3D structures of these molecules. The information obtained through structural biology studies can help researchers to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying biological processes including pathogenesis in disease, and can be used to develop new drugs and vaccines by targeting specific molecules and their interactions. This application seeks funds to support the continuation of two laboratory-based short intensive courses on Macromolecular Crystallography and Cryo-Electron Microscopy at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, New York. Both courses are designed for scientists with a working knowledge of macromolecular structure and function, but who are new to these twin methodological pillars of structural biology. Trainees include advanced graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and young faculty from throughout the United States and abroad.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma is an inflammatory disease of the airways that affects more than 300 million people worldwide and is increasing in incidence. This research will focus on understanding how allergen-specific CD4+ memory T cells that reside in the lung and orchestrate the response to the most common cause of allergic asthma, house dust mite, behave in response to subsequent allergen exposure. These studies will provide novel mechanisms to develop therapies that prevent and inhibit allergen-induced asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Individuals with Down syndrome develop oral inflammatory diseases, like gingivitis and periodontitis, at an accelerated rate. Despite the knowledge that oral inflammation and other co-occurring conditions are accelerated with age, there are a lack of studies attempting to investigate or target the underlying biology of age. This proposal investigates whether inflammaging, a low-grade chronic inflammation during age, is hyperactive in the gingival tissues of individuals with DS, all while completing an updated epidemiological inquiry on the current oral health landscape in individuals with DS, and a basic scientific inquiry into whether existing DS mice models can mimic accelerated oral inflammation. The proposal stands to enable the pursuit of an innovative strategy to improve oral health in people with DS by targeting aging biology, all while training a dentist-scientist to develop as an independent investigator to conduct rigorous clinical and translational research career in DS-related research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The growing use of genetic testing across adult cancer diagnoses is driving the development of precision oncology: a new paradigm for personalizing cancer treatment and prevention based on genetic testing results. We pioneered the Georgia-California Genetic Testing Linkage Initiative, which linked industry-provided germline genetic testing data to Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results program cancer registry records, and are now markedly expanding the initiative to include all adults diagnosed with cancer in Georgia and California from 2013-23 and genetic testing results through 2025. We will use this unique data infrastructure to determine whether the management of genetic testing results is effectively personalized to patient clinical factors and whether cancer mortality varies by genetic testing results, across cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative MIF is a prognostic biomarker of human CVD, including AAA, and a pleotropic cytokine that promotes CVD development. The discovery of CD74 as the MIF receptor suggests the requirement of more than one MIF receptor. During the search for novel MIF receptors, we found that the “airway epithelial cell-specific” chloride channel accessory protein-1 (CLCA1) acts as decoy MIF endogenous inhibitor that may help slow AAA growth by blocking MIF inflammatory activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal for this project is to disentangle the longitudinal associations between genetic obesity risk factors, parental feeding practices, child obesogenic appetitive traits and adiposity gain during the preschool years. Through repeated measurements from 2.5 through 5 years of age, this research will advance our understanding of the etiology of child obesity to guide future targeted obesity prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Center for Solutions for ME/CFS is dedicated to advancing the science of ME/CFS and advocating for the ME/CFS community through research that focuses on identifying genetic and environmental factors that contribute to disease and finding biomarkers that enable diagnosis and clinical management. In this second cycle of the Center, we will pursue complementary projects that examine samples collected in temporal proximity to variation in disease severity and prospectively, prior to diagnosis. We will test for antibody evidence of infections that may trigger initiation or exacerbation of symptoms; measure levels of small molecules in blood, saliva, and feces for clues to dysfunction at the cellular level, and sequence the genomes of people with ME/CFS to look for factors that influence risk for disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) have “good days” and “bad days”. In this project people, with ME/CFS will report good and bad days using a smartphone application that will prompt a coordinator to make a site visit convenient for the patient and collect clinical information as well as biological samples for comprehensive analyses. Results will be used to identify factors associated with improvement or deterioration of health status that are anticipated to lead to new insights in strategies for intervention in ME/CFS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Influenza virus infection involves interaction with sialic acid-containing glycans in the respiratory tract. We will develop efficient methods for assembling a new glycan array of multi-antennary glycans commonly found on the respiratory tract to detect influenza variants. Using glycoengineering, we will also develop homogeneous antibodies and conjugates against influenza variants with improved efficacy.

PHR: Project Narrative Public Relevance: Nearly 300,000 individuals in the United States have a spinal cord injury and close to 60% are at the cervical level. This grant application explores a novel combinatorial approach to restore breathing, by promoting axon growth of respiratory pathways and applying respiratory training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will investigate the role of vCA1 feedback on neural representations of environment and odors in the main olfactory bulb, a circuit critical to sensory perception and memory. Mice are one of the major model organisms for studying olfaction, and many circuits principles are conserved across evolution, making them critical to understanding neurodegenerative and neurological disorders like Alzheimer’s Disease, Parkinson’s and COVID. This proposal will improve our understanding of the functional coupling between brain regions involved in sensory perception and those involved in learning, emotion, and memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: ▪ PROJECT NARRATIVE ▪ Metastatic bone disease of the proximal femur has traditionally been treated with internal fixation; however, preliminary data suggests treating these lesions with resection and endoprosthetic reconstruction may yield better outcomes. While promising, data supporting the use of resection and endoprosthetic reconstruction is limited, and clinical practice would benefit from a definitive trial that clearly defines the optimal surgical treatment for patients with metastatic bone disease of the proximal femur. We propose a two-year planning period for the Proximal FEmur Resection or Internal Fixation fOR Metastases (PERFORM) randomized controlled trial during which we will finalize the trial protocol, establish the trial infrastructure, and prepare the participating clinical sites for initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Our laboratory has identified a role for glycolysis in transflammation and studies proposed here will characterize the dependency of acetyl-CoA metabolism on innate immune activation and identify the epigenetic effects of acetyl-CoA during transdifferentiation in vivo. Further, we will confirm the role of glycolysis in transdifferentiation using an established mouse model of peripheral artery disease. Completion of these studies will provide a novel pathway utilized by cells undergoing fate determination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Nontumor cells aid tumor cell growth and help tumor cells evade the immune system. We find that by inhibiting a protein called p38MAPK in these non-tumor cells, we can reduce metastatic tumor growth. Because there are many different types of nontumor cells in a growing metastatic tumor and we do not know which ones assist incipient tumor cell growth and survival, the goal of this work is to identify the cells, learn how they help tumor cells grow and use that information to design more potent anti-tumor therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases result in the accumulation of aggregated proteins within the ER impairing its function therefore, it is important to understand how these damaged regions of the ER are cleared by autophagy (ER- phagy). We have proposed a model in which actin assembly at ER-endosome contacts in yeast displaces the cortical ER from the plasma membrane to promote its interaction with the autophagosome assembly machinery. We will conduct a genetic test of this model, order intermediates on the ER-phagy pathway and explore the relevance of our findings to mammalian ER-phagy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the past two decades, researchers have generated molecular proﬁles of Down syndrome individuals and controls and have posted these proﬁles in public repositories so that others can reuse them. However, reuse is difﬁcult because researchers must be familiar with how to process each type of data, and they must deal with inconsistencies in terminologies used to describe research subjects. We will undergo a curation effort to address these problems on behalf of the Down syndrome research community and develop novel computational methodologies for combining such datasets in a way that addresses systematic differences between datasets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Pathological alterations in neuronal signal transmission are a hallmark of many neurological disorders, including neurodegeneration, autism, and schizophrenia. In the present project, we dissect molecular mechanisms that underlie the release of chemical signals from neurons. Our results will provide detailed insight into neuronal communication, which forms a foundation for studying how such communication fails in brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Our immune system has evolved to combat diseases via diverse and multifaceted mechanisms; however, certain immune cells can become self-destructive and promote disease conditions such as autoimmune, cancer, cardiovascular, inflammatory, and central nervous system disorders. The proposed purchase of a flow cytometer will allow a comprehensive analysis of immune and diseased cell populations, extracellular vesicles, and cell surface and intracellular proteins to identify functional and dysfunctional cell characteristics and forward our understanding of the role of the immune system in human disease as well as advance research capabilities in Puerto Rico.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Dopamine is important for normal brain function, and defects in dopamine transmission are associated with many brain disorders. We will dissect mechanisms through which dopamine controls movement, reward processing and reinforcement learning. Our results will likely revise central models in the field on dopamine function, and generate new understanding on actions of drugs of abuse in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RO1 (Renewal Application) Narrative Understanding biomarkers of cognitive decline in Lewy body diseases Lewy body disease (LBD) patients differ widely in the extent and the time course with which their underlying alpha-synuclein (aSyn) pathology affects cognition, with dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) individuals affected cognitively at onset, while Parkinson’s disease (PD) individuals develop cognitive decline at least one year, or, in some cases, many decades, later. This RO1 renewal application will investigate the contribution of host characteristics – reflected by biomarker signatures – to cognitive heterogeneity in the LBD. We will also investigate the contribution of “proteinopathy” characteristics – reflected by species of aSyn detected by two conformation-selective antibodies – to cognitive heterogeneity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our visual experience depends on the ability of retinal photoreceptor cells to transmit responses based on light excitation to downstream neurons in the visual circuitry. Perturbations in synaptic communication between the photoreceptors and their downstream partners will lead to a variety of blinding diseases. Here we propose experiments that will uncover the molecular mechanisms allowing photoreceptors to organize their synaptic contacts with downstream retinal neurons, which we expect will provide insights into strategies to treat blinding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We propose glia have core brain circuit remodeling roles in experience-dependent critical periods, a process impaired in heritable intellectual and autism spectrum disorders. We discovered multiple interacting genes involved in glial infiltration, engulfment and phagocytosis, which we propose are required for this early-life mechanism, with causal roles in several interlinked genetic models of these disorders. This research program tests glial functions and neuron-to-glia signaling in experience-dependent critical period remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In spite of extensive approaches, critical limb ischemia (CLI) is still one of the leading causes of disability and mortality in diabetic patients in USA. In this proposal, we will investigate whether enhanced muscle-specific miR- 499, which has been considered as a marker of ischemic tissue injury in human, and its downstream signaling targets can modulate endothelial/endothelial progenitor cell-mediated ischemic limb repair in diabetes. The results of this proposal will therefore be highly relevant for improving public health and improving the length and quality of life of millions of diabetic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Dietary fatty acid supplementation could be the most potentially effective dietary strategies to reduce critical diet- related health disparities; however, the under-representation of African American adults in studies of omega-3 (n-3) highly unsaturated fatty acid (HUFA) supplementation has obscured the staggering reductions in cardiovascular disease risk and other chronic disease outcome benefits in this historically underserved population. Our prior work shows that differences in genetic makeup leads to differential response to n-3-HUFA supplementation for African Americans and Non-Hispanic Whites. Here we propose to recruit African Americans and non-Hispanic Whites based on their genetic makeup, provide HUFA supplementation, and see if we can improve markers of inflammation and cardiovascular and metabolic disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to provide insight into the cell division process of meiosis, which is essential for the formation of gametes, such as eggs or sperm. Errors in meiosis can cause a gain or loss of genetic material in the gametes, which can lead to miscarriage, infertility, and trisomy conditions. The experiments in this proposal address the fundamental question of how errors in meiosis occur so that we can learn how to prevent them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative CryoEM has unique capabilities to study biological systems at atomic resolution that are not accessible to other structural methods. NCCAT provides a unified facility to lower the barriers to nationwide access to state-of-the- art equipment and technical support, to enable the production and analysis of high-resolution cryoEM structures. NCCAT will lead an educational program to engage and train the scientific community from neighboring fields to maximize the benefit for non-experts and expand the reach of the field while boosting the scientific output.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Melanoma, one of the most aggressive and fatal neoplasms, is the 5th most frequent cancer in men and 7th most frequent cancer in women and is responsible for over 80% of the skin cancer-related deaths. By investigating the role and mechanism of elongation factor-2 kinase (eEF-2K) as a novel immunomodulatory target and by assessing the antitumor efficacy of the eEF-2K-based integrative targeted therapy, we wish to provide innovative and effective immunotherapeutic strategies for patients with immune poor-responsive melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Currently available influenza vaccines provide protection only against circulating influenza strains and are totally ineffective against novel influenza strains that have the potential of causing pandemic outbreaks. Therefore, the development of a universal vaccine that will provide life-long protection against all influenza strains is urgently needed. The proposed studies aim to develop novel vaccines that will confer protection against all influenza strains through activation of specific immune pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood production requires precise regulation by transcription factors and epigenetic regulators, including transcriptional co-factors MLL3 and MLL4. Mechanisms that govern co-factor usage at one gene but not another remain ill-defined, yet they are critical for maintaining blood homeostasis. We propose experiments to define the mechanisms that govern usage of MLL3 and MLL4 to promote appropriate blood production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Our preliminary data suggest that the social structure of care delivery—the pattern of social relationships, practices, and institutions determining the nature and context of care delivery—is a major contributor to SRD in HF care. The objective of this proposal is to address SRD in HF care by examining determinants of disparities and identifying stakeholder-informed areas of intervention within care delivery networks, which will inform a toolkit to enhance equitable HF care and outcomes. We have the following aims: (1) Evaluate the “social structure of care delivery” for populations disproportionately affected by SRD in HF care delivery and outcomes; (2) Develop a comprehensive understanding of structural barriers and facilitators for equitable HF care and outcomes; and (3) Develop a best practices toolkit to address SRD in HF care and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The establishment of highly precise neuronal connectivity is required for the proper functioning of the nervous system. Genetic disruptions affecting the development of the olfactory system in Kallmann or in CHARGE Syndromes profoundly and permanently disrupt olfactory function. Our goal in this project is to identify and understand the molecular mechanisms that are required for establishing normal neuronal connectivity in the developing olfactory system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is evidence that orally ingested cannabidiol, the non-psychoactive component of cannabis, has sedative- like effects, which could negatively impact driving performance, but limited research exists. The objective of this application is further our understanding of whether and how CBD may impact driving performance by dose and biological sex in a sample of young healthy adults using a driving simulator and a battery of well- validated self-report instruments and cognitive tests. Given that cannabidiol products are growing in popularity among all age groups in the United States, and their effects in a healthy population are virtually unknown, the positive impact of this study is the collection of essential data regarding the potential unintended consequences of this drug, which could put drivers and other road users at increased risk of motor vehicle collision.

PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop and evaluate an automatic system for collecting and analyzing language data from individuals who use augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) devices. The research findings can potentially enhance AAC interventions by leveraging a smart finger ring and advanced computational methods, to collect and analyze AAC language data, resulting in more personalized and effective interventions. The findings can also provide a foundation for developing comprehensive databases to inform future AAC research and intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project tests intergenerational impacts of two different interventions (unearned cash transfers and social- cognitive skill building) in which the original child participants have been followed into adulthood and are now parenting their own children. This research will have high impact on public health by estimating the extent to which two forms of childhood interventions can affect family environments and child outcomes across generations. Risk and protective factors that disrupt intergenerational continuity in maladaptive parenting and child adjustment problems will be identified as potential future intervention targets, and lifespan developmental processes to inform future practice and policy decisions regarding promising proximal targets to reduce risk and improve children’s healthy development will be evaluated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Down syndrome (DS) children have a significantly higher risk of developing acute leukemias compared to non- DS children. The goal of this proposal is to determine the role of the DS bone marrow microenvironment in myeloid leukemia associated with DS (ML-DS) therapy response, furthering our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the extremely high cure rates of children with ML-DS. This proposal will also identify a novel treatment strategy of enhancing cytarabine treatment to further improve treatment outcome and reduce relapse of ML-DS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic lack of sleep places people at risk for bone loss and bone fragility that characterize osteoporosis, an age-related, debilitating disease affecting millions of U.S. men and women and which can lead to lost independence and early death. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will define the biology of chronic sleep deficiency—how it changes bone structure and remodeling activities that underlie bone fragility and fracture risk, using a validated animal model. The knowledge gained will be a foundation for translational research aimed at reducing age-related morbidity imposed by chronic sleep deficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE New antibiotics that can act against gram-negative pathogens are limited and new therapeutic approaches are urgently needed. We aim to discover approaches to sensitize antibiotic-tolerant Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa to existing topoisomerase inhibitors along with compounds that are in clinical trials. We will investigate phenotypic changes that underlie bacterial survival in the presence of these drugs and as cells recover after antibiotic treatment terminates, which will enable us to develop strategies that thwart the evolution of antibiotic treatment failure and resistance development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The persistence of minimal or measurable residual disease (MRD) is considered to be a key determinant of relapse and poor patient prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The current clinical strategy at complete remission with MRD positivity is, depending on the level, to either provide additional dose(s) of the initial treatment or switch to a new therapy at the time of relapse. Through the use of a novel single-cell assay developed by an industry/academic partnership, we are proposing to instead target MRD by selecting a more optimal therapy before relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: High-grade serous ovarian carcinoma (HGSOC) is the deadliest form of ovarian cancer due to frequent recurrence and metastasis with minimal treatment options. Recurrent HGSOC often spreads to the peritoneal cavity in the form of ascites, where tumor cells grow as spheroids, and metastasize to other organs causing death. The overall goal of this proposal is to uncover how protein kinases orchestrate this process, so that we can design kinase inhibitor therapies to prevent the growth and spread of recurrent HGSOC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: PT4A (Peers and Technology for Adherence, Access, Accountability, and Analytics) Elevated blood pressure is the leading risk for mortality worldwide; despite numerous evidence-based practices to optimize medication adherence, substantial implementation gaps persist, and medication non- adherence is a major cause of uncontrolled hypertension and cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. This project aims to improve hypertension medication adherence, thereby improving blood pressure control, by evaluating a novel implementation strategy combining peer-based medication delivery and health information technology. The findings from the project will add to the existing knowledge base on innovative and scalable strategies for improving medication adherence for hypertension control, especially for low-resource settings worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our work has the potential to dramatically impact public health because by determining the influence of the lymph node microenvironment on lipidomic changes in melanoma, we will be able to 1.) identify feasible lipidomic targets to prevent death from cancer spread from lymph nodes and 2.) determine lipids in melanoma cells that serve as prognostic biomarkers for metastasis and thus identify patients who could be spared the side effects of undergoing surgical resection of lymph nodes. Furthermore, we will elucidate how lipids modulate the lymphatic microenvironment to influence melanoma metastasis, which will offer important evidence linking lipid usage to risk of melanoma progression. Our work will provide the groundwork for future research efforts to develop novel therapeutic strategies to prevent progression of early-stage melanoma, with applicability to other cancer types as well (e.g., prostate, lung, breast cancer) by modulating the lymphatic microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal explores the evolutionary mechanisms by which proteins have gained novel functions in a medically important class of enzymes, the malate and lactate dehydrogenases (MDHs and LDHs). Due to their significant differences from the human MDH enzymes, many of the bacterial MDH enzymes are important potential drug targets, including human pathogens such as cryptosporidiosis, malaria, anthrax, Bacteroides, and Pseudomonas. The results of this research will aid in answering several long-standing evolutionary questions and will aid our understanding of how enzymatic functions can be engineered.

PHR: Narrative We will utilize high pressure (50-100Atm) to dissolve adequate volumes of oxygen in saline to make a clinically relevant therapy to sustain body oxygen requirements for up to 10-20 min/L of saline infused. We will create a solution consisting of nanobubbles and saline to be mixed with the returning venous blood and test its effect on blood oxygenation in a porcine model of cardiac arrest. Success of this project will open new horizons in the management of multiple human disease emergencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE:  This proposal addresses critical issues of central importance to advance our understanding of the mechanisms of age-related decline in visual system. Those include: investigating how sex could play a critical role in RPE, retina and visual cortex functions during aging and how sex chromosomes, sex hormones, or their interactions could regulate the visual system function. The results and conclusions derived from this study will provide important information for better understanding the age-related changes in the visual system and will further our knowledge of how aging, sex chromosomes, and gonadal sex contribute to the visual system function during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The antibiotic resistant ESKAPE pathogens, the major cause of health care associated pneumonia, activate the production of itaconate and fumarate in the airway. Itaconate activates anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidant responses in the host, which protect against tissue damage due to excessive oxidant stress, but also interfere with effective bacterial killing. We will establish how itaconate and fumarate orchestrate both airway defenses and bacteria adaptation in the pathogenesis of pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) affects 15% of the adult population in the United States and half of these patients die from cardiovascular disease, with the primary cause related to cardiac fibrosis (left ventricular hypertrophy) and arrhythmias. Diets are widely used as an effort to prevent heart disease in patients with and without CKD, but there are only limited studies in CKD. In the current proposal, we will test a simple dietary intervention of fiber to change the gut bacteria and reduce a toxin that accumulates in kidney disease and determine how that affects the hear in order to prevent cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by injury to endothelial cells, leading to vascular leakage and pulmonary edema, often associated with critical illnesses like sepsis, trauma, and severe COVID-19. With the lack of effective treatments for ARDS, innovative strategies targeting endothelial regeneration and vascular repair are urgently needed. This study aims to investigate the role and mechanisms of perivascular macrophages in regulating endothelial regeneration and vascular repair following acute lung injury, aiming to identify novel therapeutic targets for treating ARDS and addressing the critical need for effective interventions in this life-threatening condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Individuals with Down syndrome, the genetic condition caused by trisomy 21, display widespread auditory dysfunction, with current estimates indicating that ~80% of this population may have one or more forms of hearing loss. However, the mechanisms by which trisomy 21 causes hearing loss are unknown. This project will fund a multi-disciplinary team of synergistic expertise that will employ a combination of human research and research in mouse models of Down syndrome to elucidate how trisomy 21 impairs auditory function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Two-thirds of approximately 5 million Americans living with Alzheimer's disease (AD) are women, and a higher incidence of AD has been observed in postmenopausal women with lower serum 17β-estradiol (E2) levels. Additionally, patients with aromatase/estrogen inhibition often experience a greater amount of cognitive decline. Therefore, this proposal meets the critical needs as it will examine the underlying mechanisms and evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of non-invasive pulsed laser therapy for the treatment of cognitive deficits following the down-regulation and/or inhibition of brain aromatase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), or primary liver cancer, results in considerable worldwide illness and fatality, especially when it grows beyond the original location and spreads within the liver. Advances in HCC diagnostics and treatment are highly dependent on the development of new systems to better understand cancer growth. The aim of this research study is to utilize a pig HCC model to investigate the ability of advanced imaging techniques to noninvasively provide insights into HCC tumor biology, with the overall goal of incorporating these techniques into clinical management to improve diagnosis, treatment, and treatment response monitoring for liver cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Platelets circulate in the bloodstream and, when they encounter a damaged blood vessel, become activated and stick together to help to plug up the damaged area and stop bleeding; excessive bleeding occurs when platelet counts are too low, which is a condition referred to as thrombocytopenia. This application represents a unique application of hematology and immunology expertise required to tackle unresolved problems in the immunologic bleeding disorder Fetal/Neonatal Alloimmune Thrombocytopenia (FNAIT), which is a non- malignant hematologic disease that arises when the immune system of a pregnant person makes antibodies that clear a baby's platelets before or immediately after birth. We are especially interested in determining why FNAIT develops in some at-risk pregnancies but not others and why some babies with FNAIT experience excessive bleeding in the brain, referred to as intracranial hemorrhage, which can result in irreversible brain damage and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We generated the first bisteric mTOR inhibitors, demonstrated their activity in GMB preclinically, and generated a strategy to potentiate efficacy in GBM while sparing mTOR inhibition outside the CNS; by dosing mice with both RapaLink-1 and a brain-impermeable FKBP12 ligand that we synthesized, called RapaBlock. A clinical bisteric mTOR inhibitor, RMC-5552, developed by Revolution Medicines, is currently in clinical trials, with a GBM trial to open in 2023. We hypothesize that: 1), RapaBlock will potentiate efficacy while decreasing peripheral toxicity of RMC-5552 in GBM, and 2), We can further develop our strategy to develop FKBP-dependent inhibitors of other prominent targets in GBM, including targets with liabilities outside of the CNS, initially focusing on inhibitors of JAK kinases that block activation of STAT3. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Basal forebrain cholinergic neurons (BFCNs) are important for arousal, attention, learning, and memory, and they are prone to degeneration in Down syndrome (DS) and other neurodegenerative diseases. The F99 proposal will determine if there are fewer BFCNs at birth in DS and utilize iPSC models while the K00 proposal will expand this work to determine the temporal order of pathology accumulation in the DS basal forebrain and identify molecular mechanisms that may contribute to BFCN susceptibility. A better understanding of the role of BFCNs in disease progression may improve DS and other neurodegenerative disease models as well as elucidate novel therapeutic targets.

PHR: In this project, we develop and apply novel, robust, rigorous, and transparent statistical methods to identify for whom a surrogate marker can be used in place of an expensive or invasive outcome when the utility of the surrogate marker varies with multiple patient characteristics, and to formally investigate the impact of such complex heterogeneity on future trial design. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH We have chosen to study leprosy, because it remains a global health burden on developing countries, because it provides an extraordinary model to study human immune responses to a microbial pathogen and because the lesions are readily accessible for study of immune processes at the site of disease. The investigation of how T cells are activated in leprosy and how they contribute to host defense against the bacteria that causes leprosy will provide new insights into the human immune system as well as provide novel targets for therapeutic intervention against a wide range of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of the proposed research is to elucidate the cellular composition, detailed cellular morphology, and patterns of taste cell-to-nerve connectivity of murine fungiform taste buds. Several lines of evidence suggest that the fungiform taste buds of the anterior tongue might differ considerably from the circumvallate taste buds of the posterior tongue in both composition and function. A thorough examination of fungiform taste bud morphology would fill in a glaring gap in our anatomical understanding of the peripheral gustatory system in mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Antiphospholipid antibodies can elevate the risk of blood clot formation. Unfortunately, existing treatment options in individuals with antiphospholipid antibodies have demonstrated limited effectiveness, as evidenced in antiphospholipid syndrome patients. This project introduces a novel approach that involves dual targeting of two essential coagulation factors to mitigate the risk of vascular thrombosis in individuals with prothrombotic autoantibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a need for accessible interventions to promote healthy growth and feeding practices in infancy to prevent later obesity. This proposal will evaluate an innovative virtual feeding intervention program for infants and their caregivers focused on optimizing infant breast-, bottle- and complementary feeding to support healthy growth and prevent obesity in the first two years. If effective, this program can be broadly disseminated to support healthy growth and obesity prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A cell carefully regulates the transcription of each one of its many genes. In humans, abnormalities in this complex process (whether inherited or acquired) can lead to many diseases, including a variety of cancers. Plasticity in transcriptional circuitry is well documented in the progression of normal cells to cancer cells, and a deeper understanding of it will provide insights into recognizing and perhaps treating cases where it leads to aberrant physiologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is one of the most common causes of respiratory failure worldwide, but there are no disease-modifying therapies that have demonstrated efficacy. Alveolar macrophages (AMs) are an attractive therapeutic target for ARDS because they play a central role in almost all aspects of its pathophysiology. This project will determine the ontogeny and functional characteristics of AM subsets, and evaluate which subsets are robustly associated with ARDS clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a deadly malignancy with limited treatment options, and it has defined risk factors, including hepatitis C virus (HCV)/hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, liver cirrhosis and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), making it a type of cancer which can clearly benefit from chemoprevention. TEA domain transcription factors (TEADs) bind to YAP/TAZ and mediate transcriptional output of Hippo pathway, and activation of TEAD-YAP complex has been shown to play an important role in HCC initiation. Hence, inhibition of TEAD palmitoylation could lead to the prevention of HCC initiation, which is highly relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults are more vulnerable to health impacts from climate-related events such as hurricanes, floods, wildfires, and heat waves. This project provides important research infrastructure to improve understanding of these impacts and their implications. Through funding for pilot projects, training for researchers, and the development of useful publicly available data resources and tools, we enhance understanding of the public health consequences of environmental conditions and change across the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Child sexual abuse (CSA) is preventable yet many existing programs focus on raising awareness regarding relevant risk and protective factors, rather than fundamentally shifting the contexts in which CSA takes place. The purpose of this community-partnered study is to evaluate the Public Will Campaign to End Child Sexual Abuse (PWC) for its effectiveness in building community connection, promoting collective efficacy, identifying and correcting misperceived social norms relative to CSA prevention, and ultimately, reducing CSA perpetration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity continues to increase in children and is associated with increased metabolic risk. Oxytocin, a hypothalamic hormone that regulates eating behavior and energy metabolism, is a promising therapy to promote weight loss and improve metabolic risk in adolescents with obesity. This randomized placebo- controlled investigation will study the effects and underlying mechanisms of twelve weeks of intranasal oxytocin on weight and metabolic risk markers in adolescents with obesity 12-18 years old.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We propose to develop survivor-specific risk models to predict adverse outcomes of childhood cancer through collecting daily symptoms and other patient-generated health data (physical activity, sleep behavior, heart rate variability) using mobile health devices. We will apply machine/statistical learning methods to develop and validate risk prediction models, and use qualitative methods to receive input from clinicians and survivors for developing a user-friendly dashboard and decision support tools. Our risk prediction tool will facilitate informing individualized levels of specific adverse outcomes, and providing key information for clinicians and survivors to discuss in view of preventive interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Molecular Biology Across Scales multidisciplinary training program will train students to tackle biological problems across length scales within and beyond a traditional discipline, thereby enabling high-impact discoveries with ultimate relevance to human health. We will offer a rigorous program focused on broad conceptual knowledge, creative and critical thinking, mastery of experimental logic and methods, application of computational and quantitative approaches, appropriate analysis and interpretation of results, clear and fluent communication of findings, and incorporation of responsible, safe, and ethical practices. MBAS will prepare a highly diverse cadre of young scientists (~30% from historically excluded groups) to join the modern biomedical workforce, meet both present and future scientific and societal challenges, and push the boundaries of knowledge forward.

PROJECT_TITLE: Molecular Biology Across Scales Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The advent of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has revolutionized our understanding of human cognition. Unfortunately, it is nearly impossible to ensure identical execution of fMRI experiments across different MRI scanners due to subtle differences in how MRI scanners from different vendors implement fMRI protocols, leading to challenges in interpretation or pooling results from different fMRI centers. This project will establish and distribute a software environment to help fMRI researchers achieve consistent results across sites and scanner models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evaluation and improvement of cancer care quality is of growing interest nationally, with a pressing need for research to support decisions by policy makers, hospital systems, payers, clinicians, and patients – evidenced by the growing scope of the National Cancer Institute’s Division of Cancer Control and Population Science in areas germane to this application, including the programs of Health Care Delivery Research, Health Disparities and Health Equity, Implementation Science, and Survivorship. The UNC Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center’s Cancer Care Quality Training Program (CCQTP) is a pre- and postdoctoral fellowship training program that prepares fellows for careers in cancer care quality research, by providing rigorous methodological training with an applied clinical orientation. The CCQTP has successfully trained researchers with a multidisciplinary and collaborative focus over the past 15 years, and proposes to continue its mission to train the next generation of investigators in this field over the next five years.
PROJECT_TERMS: cancer care;Quality of Care;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Cancer Care Quality Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The purpose of this grant is to provide under-represented minority undergraduate students with an opportunity to work on an mentored research project in genome sciences or medicine, supplemented with training in the core genome sciences and ethical/legal/social issues, and to develop essential research skills including conducting a literature review, critical reading of scientific literature, and oral and written presentations. The students supported by this grant will gain the necessary knowledge and experience to continue their educational training in a research-oriented path in science, technology, or mathematics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Biophysics Training Program supports a multi-pronged approach to recruiting and training a diverse cadre of predoctoral students and preparing them to become future leaders in biophysics. The program includes core coursework in biophysics at the molecular and cellular levels, quantitative and computational skills development, career development activities, rigorous, reproducible and responsible research, record keeping, and laboratory safety. Students trained in this interdisciplinary program will be uniquely positioned for employment in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries and in academic biomedicine, where their discoveries will lead to novel diagnostics and therapeutics for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many classes of natural products have tremendous potential as therapeutics or as biological tools but have structural liabilities that limit their utility. Our lab uses modular chemical synthesis with accompanying methodology development to enable systematic modification of promising chemical scaffolds to overcome such liabilities. This proposal outlines several examples of this approach for molecules with anticancer, antibiotic, and antiviral properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital conditions in which the calvarial suture joints fuse prematurely are common and lead to serious developmental problems, yet the reason why susceptibility to fusion varies among sutures is unclear. This proposal addresses fundamental components that drive regional differences in suture patterning and aims to identify the role for these differences in disease models of premature and delayed suture fusion. These findings will decode cues that impart suture-specific features, which will inform future improvements in patients’ treatments and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trichotillomania and excoriation disorder are disabling psychiatric conditions with limited effective treatments. This research uses a series of complementary neurogenomic investigations to significantly advance our understanding of the genes and neurodevelopmental pathways that contribute to these conditions. This is relevant to public health because it advances our fundamental knowledge of the underlying mechanisms that lead to trichotillomania and excoriation disorder, which has the potential to identify novel treatment targets to ultimately reduce the burden of these conditions.

PHR: Project Narrative Protective factors across the life course can have profound effects on individual health, including mental health symptoms. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Medications to treat addiction exist for many drugs of abuse, but not for amphetamine-type stimulants, which include amphetamine, methamphetamine and the increasingly popular new psychoactive substances such as synthetic cathinones, also knowns as “bath salts” and “legal highs”. Amphetamine-type stimulants are among the most commonly abused, afflicting approximately 56 million people between the ages of 15 and 64 worldwide, creating a major public health burden, and underscoring a vital need to find effective treatments. Proposed studies will explore a previously unknown mechanism of action of amphetamine-type drugs, with the goal to identify and validate organic cation transporter 3 as a novel target for the development of effective treatments for amphetamine-type stimulant abuse.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA WESTERN NEW YORK HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is commonly reported in Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder, which can potentiate symptoms of anxiety and depression, daytime symptoms and worsen nightmares. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is the most effective therapy but adherence to treatment is suboptimal. Insomnia is considered a barrier to long-term adherence. The overarching theme of the proposal is to compare the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT) plus eszopiclone, a nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic, versus CBT alone in Veterans with PTSD who are diagnosed with both OSA and insomnia, using a randomized, clinical trial, on sleep quality of life, PTSD severity, and CPAP adherence.

PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this training grant renewal, From Biological to Social Processes: Interdisciplinary Training in Life Course Research (ITLCR), is to facilitate the integration of social and health science research approaches to improve the scientific community’s understanding of population health and well-being across the life course. Junior scientists trained in the ITLCR better identify, understand, and produce new knowledge on the social and biological pathways that are important to population health and the understanding of health disparities across the life course. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are 57.7 million people living in the world with limb amputation due to traumatic causes with a 5-year post-amputation survival rate of only 48.6%. Thus, it is important to understand the major limitations behind mammalian composite tissue regeneration in order to develop more effective treatments for those with major wounds such as limb amputations. This project utilizes cutting edge single-cell lineage tracing and gene delivery techniques to investigate the driving forces behind fibrosis and regeneration in the mouse digit tip, a model system that has strong translatability to humans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Trauma-related guilt is common and impairing among trauma survivors, particularly among Veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Those who have guilt tend to have more severe PTSD and depression symptoms and greater suicide risk. Although PTSD treatments such as Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) are effective to treat PTSD and trauma-related guilt, many still experience symptoms or maintain their diagnosis after treatment. Thus, additional and less burdensome approaches are needed. Our work shows that a brief treatment targeting trauma-related guilt, Trauma Informed Guilt Reduction Therapy (TrIGR), can reduce guilt and PTSD and depression symptoms. In our first study with 144 Veterans who served in conflicts with Iraq or Afghanistan, TrIGR reduced PTSD and depression more than supportive therapy. More than 50% lost their PTSD diagnosis. Whether TrIGR is no less effective than longer, more resource heavy PTSD treatments disseminated by by VA, like CPT, is the next critical question that this proposed study will seek to answer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Findings will advance understanding beyond the pain–suicidality link by pinpointing (a) proximal factors predicting when suicidal ideation (SI) occurs (i.e., in moments of social threat or physical pain), (b) neural vulnerability markers identifying who develops SI, and (c) how SI may develop through interactions between negative social environments and altered function in the pain system. Findings will inform novel targets for just- in-time interventions that deliver skills through electronic devices in critical moments of risk. Additionally, findings may help refine or augment other existing interventions for SI among vulnerable youth by integrating treatment components that target physical pain in the context of social threat, such as cognitive-behavioral therapies established for pain, or non-invasive fMRI real-time neurofeedback in which youth learn to regulate brain activation in key pain-related brain regions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Sickle Pan African Research Consortium NigEria Network (SPARC-NEt) hub at the Centre of Excellence for Sickle Cell Disease Research and Training, University of Abuja (CESRTA) has 18 satellite sites across the six geo-political zones of Nigeria. This spread is important to achieve SPARC-NEt’s goal of expanding its SCD patient cohort from 6000 to 9,000 (including 1,000 newborns), training health care workers and stakeholders to offer improved care to patients with SCD and carrying out studies aimed at assessing how patients with SCD in Nigeria will respond to standard treatment known to be effective in SCD populations in developed countries. We also plan to use genomic technologies to investigate the association between changes in gut microbiome, protective fetal hemoglobin levels and frequency of sickle cell crisis in new born babies followed up for five years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The current cycle of AG011378 was designed to test aspects of a hypothetical model of the temporal evolution of Alzheimer’s biomarkers that we proposed; however, a major missing element when the current cycle of AG011378 began was a method to measure fibrillar tau deposits with imaging. Tau PET has recently become available and consequently for the first time imaging biomarkers exist to ascertain three of the most important pathologic features of AD: amyloid, tau and neurodegeneration. Our aims in this renewal application are to empirically evaluate our hypothetical model of AD biomarkers and to create new imaging biomarker models for individuals who are not in the Alzheimer’s continuum using imaging measures of amyloid, tau, and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Prostate cancer is the most diagnosed cancer in the VA Healthcare System. Unfortunately, in 20% of Veterans who have curative treatment for prostate cancer, the cancer later spreads to other parts of the body, and half of these men will die of cancer. New treatments are needed to help improve the survival of these Veterans. Promising evidence suggests that men with limited areas of spread may benefit from further radiation or surgery to these new areas. However, the benefit is unknown when Veterans are receiving hormonal or chemohormonal therapy. Our study will determine whether adding radiation or surgery to the areas of spread in Veterans re- ceiving hormonal or chemohormonal therapy reduces the chance of further growth of the can- cer. We will also study how the treatments impact the Veteran’s quality of life and how genetic changes in the tumor can determine who benefits most from the combined treatment approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hypertension is a major cause of global mortality and a primary modifiable risk factor for renal, cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease. The present studies will address a significant knowledge gap by directly assessing the mechanisms whereby immune cells lead to salt-sensitive hypertension and kidney damage. Results of this work will transform the understanding of immune mechanisms in salt-sensitive hypertension by utilizing novel animal models and approaches, revealing new paradigms, and providing insight with the potential to transform clinical/therapeutic approaches for the treatment of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly half a million people each year lose their ability to breath on their own and are treated by placing a breathing tube in their throat. After regaining their ability to breath, as many as 44% of patients may have trouble swallowing. This proposal will identify modifiable factors, determine the optimal screening tool, and classify specific groups of patients who may have different rates of recovery of their swallowing difficulties. Overall, this research will improve the care of patients recovering from critical illnesses and pave the way for the discovery of novel treatments for their swallowing dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Native Hawaiians’ traditional lifestyles and diets that ensured mutual health and wellbeing of the land and its inhabitants stand in stark contrast to the disproportionately high prevalence of diet-related, cardiometabolic diseases they experience today. In this project, we will adapt and test an evidence-based multilevel intervention entitled PILI ‘Āina to improve the self-management of prevalent cardiometabolic diseases and reduce risk factors for developing new diet-related illness and implement and evaluate the impact and sustainability of community- wide cooking demonstrations. The objectives of this project are to optimize the effectiveness and sustainability of PILI ‘Āina, improve diet quality and cardiometabolic markers and promote traditional Native Hawaiian diets and improve social cohesion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Team-based interdisciplinary molecular medicine has become increasingly complex, teams more interdisciplinary, and communication and leadership skills more critical. This training program in Comparative Molecular Medicine addresses two critical national needs in biomedical research. First, is the growing need for developing new training approaches that better address the increasingly complex, interdisciplinary and collaborative research environment of today. Second, the need to educate PhD students that understand the ethical principles of rigor and reproducibility and responsible conduct of research and can successfully function, and become leaders, in the highly collaborative scientific environment of today that combines basic scientists, translational scientists and clinicians from many diverse backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The rapid development and clinical translation of neurotechnology, such as brain stimulators and devices to map and monitor the brain, has revolutionized the care of neuropsychiatric diseases. As the burden of neurological diseases on society increases at an exponential rate, society must be prepared and train future leaders who have multidisciplinary training and are prepared to develop, innovate, and translate basic neuroscientific findings into real-world neurotechnology solutions. The UCLA program, Training in Neurotechnology Translation, will serve as a training hub that will demand that trainees bridge the gap between technology and experimental science, taking advantage and building upon local expertise in relevant fields, close collaboration and interaction with industry partners, and the culture of innovation and translation that permeates UCLA.
PROJECT_TERMS: neurotechnology;Training;Translations
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Neurotechnology Translation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) are a devastating form of chronic disease in adults and children marked by progressive respiratory failure for which there are limited therapeutics due to poorly understood disease development and progression. Activation of cell stress pathways in alveolar epithelial type 2 cells (AEC2s), an epithelial cell that line the air sacs (alveoli) of the lung, and dysfunction in their ability to repair injured lung have emerged as leading paradigms for why ILD develops and progresses. Coupling two novel mouse models that express Surfactant Protein C (SP-C) gene mutations that are associated with human ILD with state-of-the-art modeling using cells derived from an ILD patient with an SP-C mutation, we now aim to better understand ILD development and to identifying therapeutically targetable pathways by characterizing the molecular and cellular mechanisms that link AEC2 cell stress and dysfunctional lung repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Human craniofacial development is a complex process and requires suites of genes to be switched on and off at appropriate times and spaces during formation of the embryo. There is now a wealth of data available in public databases concerning which genes are expressed when and where during mammalian facial development, including for the transcription factors which are the proteins that regulate these critical expression programs, but we have not yet begun to connect this information together to derive logical predictions about the critical networks responsible for craniofacial development. This proposal will address that gap using both computational and laboratory-based methods to derive and verify transcriptional regulatory networks relevant to the genetic and molecular underpinnings of normal facial development as well as how these are disrupted to cause defects such as human orofacial clefting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Craniofacial skeletal muscle is essential for basic life functions including chewing, swallowing, and speaking; therefore, understanding how this tissue regenerates in response to injury and disease will provide the basis for therapeutic advances in the treatment of craniofacial muscle diseases and disorders. Our group has demonstrated that craniofacial skeletal muscle has the ability to regenerate following damage, but to what extent remains unknown. The goal of this proposal is to comprehensively investigate the regenerative capacity of craniofacial muscle and its stem cell population to inform developments in treatment modalities for individuals suffering from craniofacial muscle injury or disease.

PHR: Pain is ubiquitous, expensive and disabling; while our knowledge of pain mechanisms has increased, advances in pain treatment remain disappointing.
