IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE Calcification is a hallmark of major diseases of aging, including Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD) and Alzheimer's Disease (AD), disorders that are currently incurable. There is an urgent need for new therapeutic and diagnostic strategies. This program Project will investigate the biological mechanisms of calcification and their roles in the onset and etiology of AMD and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the knowledge that CD4+ T-cells mediate wound healing during myocardial infarction (MI) but exacerbate left-ventricular remodeling and cardiac dysfunction during heart failure (HF), the specific mechanisms that mediate this phenotypic shift in T-cell biology are not known. Our published results suggest an important role of estrogen receptor (ER) α signaling in mediating this phenotypic shift, and autoimmune activation of T-cells during chronic HF. In this proposal, PI intends to develop a novel ERβ agonist (OSU-ERb- 012), to functional oppose ERα signaling, by studying i) therapeutic efficacy of OSU-ERb-012 at clinically translatable low doses and ii) dissect, in detail, its effects on the cardiomyocytes and CD4+ T-cells using relevant cell-specific ERβ-/- HF mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: We recently discovered a novel form of Enhanced hammerhead ribozyme (EhhRz), an RNA therapeutic with idealized properties for cellular target mRNA knockdown (speed, concentration, specificity). Here we optimize this agent for gene or injectable nucleic acid therapeutics capacity and cellular knockdown performance, and conduct a highly focused preclinical therapeutic test to rescue retinal degeneration in a mouse model of autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa (adRP) that expresses human rhodopsin genes. Success would be a first step to translate EhhRz therapeutic agents into clinical trials for adRP, and validate a new nucleic acid pharmacological modality, which is highly relevant to the National Eye Institute mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cognition is the focus of human achievement and is essential for human success, but it is also the focal point of the most malicious attacks on health, giving rise to immense suffering and a high emotional and monetary cost in our society. Treating and preventing neurological and psychiatric disease, as well as the cognitive decline of aging, depends on understanding the cognitive problems presented in the clinic, which in turn depends on understanding the brain bases of these problems. The Training Program in the Neuroscience of Human Cognition is primed to contribute to these endeavors by delivering a steady infusion of young scientists with the high-quality training and the necessary experiences and guidance to prepare them to become scientific leaders and valuable contributors to this agenda.
PROJECT_TERMS: Cognition;Human;Neurosciences;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in the Neuroscience of Human Cognition

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Pain is the principal reason for seeking medical attention, respects no boundaries, is not restricted to any one disease or medical discipline, is distributed across the life span, and experienced by all irrespective of status (economic, educational, etc.) age or gender, and remains difficult to manage if it can be managed at all. Novel and more effective treatments for pain that are so desperately needed will only be discovered by the hard work of the next generation of pain scientists. Thus, this training program fills a compelling need by enhancing and broadening the training of the next generation of pain researchers.
PROJECT_TERMS: Clinical;Pain;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Mechanisms and Clinical Presentation of Pain

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Temporal lobe epilepsy is the most common form of epilepsy in adults, causes widespread brain network dysfunction, and has widespread effects that are not understood, such as loss of consciousness and cognitive deficits. This study will use functional magnetic resonance imaging and electrophysiological brain recordings in persons with temporal lobe epilepsy to better characterize brain networks contributing to loss of consciousness and cognitive deficits. Through this work we hope to improve understanding of disrupted brain networks in temporal lobe epilepsy and identify potential targets for new therapies that may benefit the lives of those with this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is a leading cause for vision loss and remains a major public health problem due to its continued rise in prevalence despite available medical treatments. Barriers in social determinants of health (SDoH) can lead to inadvertent lapses in DR care, which are major preventable risk factors for poor visual outcomes. This project will use novel data science approaches to investigate the SDoH that impact DR care and lay the groundwork for developing interventions to prevent vision loss from DR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To date, there are no adjunctive therapies to reduce pediatric cerebral malaria mortality or morbidity, resulting in enormous economic and public health impacts. This research aims to evaluate the safety and preliminary efficacy of a candidate adjunctive therapy for pediatric cerebral malaria, 6-diazo-5-oxo-L-norleucine (DON). If found safe now, and if future clinical trials confirm clinical efficacy, this paradigm-shifting intervention could be easily implemented by trained medical staff and readily scaled up to impact public health across malaria- endemic countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders are a major public health issue and are characterized by maladaptive learning processes resulting in overvaluation of drugs and drug-associated stimuli, as well as disruptions in non-drug reward reinforcement learning. Though upregulated kappa opioid receptor activity is thought to be implicated in maladaptive negative reinforcement processes underlying addiction, the role of both endogenous and augmented activity of the kappa opioid receptor system in learning has not been thoroughly investigated. The focus of this proposal is to directly assess predictions of this model by determining the endogenous role of kappa opioid receptor signaling in adaptive reinforcement learning and whether upregulation of the system is sufficient to drive maladaptive learning behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial disparities in alcohol use behaviors and outcomes are a significant public health concern in the United States, particularly among historically marginalized populations. This research will use an innovative mixed- methods approach to examine the relationship between neighborhood characteristics (e.g., neighborhood disorganization and deprivation), and the role of drinking motives, on alcohol consumption and alcohol-related consequences among Black adults. Findings may encourage health researchers and professionals to address community-related barriers maintaining alcohol use-related inequities and enable the development of pertinent, culturally sensitive, community-driven interventions and policies to eliminate such disparities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conductive airway epithelium in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease often show pathologic changes and this will have profound effect on the outcome of respiratory infections. We will determine the mechanisms underlying the defective airway repair in stem cells present in the COPD airways. We will also examine whether quercetin, a natural polyphenol can reverse the pathologic changes of airway epithelium in mice and COPD subjects.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common heart rhythm disorder and a major cause of stroke. Unfortunately, current therapies for AF are suboptimal, in part because the precise electrical ‘sources’ of AF within the heart are difficult to find. This project uses a unique new method, called Electrogram Morphology Recurrence, to: a) find these electrical sources of AF and b) target these electrical sources, using either ablation or a gene therapy approach.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is an underdiagnosed and undertreated disorder affecting 1 in 4 US individuals in a given year. Early detection and treatment are crucial for positive outcomes, yet despite its high heritability, genetic risk estimation for PTSD remains largely imprecise. This proposal aims to improve detection of PTSD-relevant signatures by integrating interrogation of genetic risk with nuanced measures of environmental trauma and stress to elucidate context-dependent genetic and traumatic regulation of disorder susceptibility, carrying the translational potential to better predict and mitigate complex PTSD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advances in magnetic resonance imaging and facial recognition technologies have together made it possible to create realistic images of participant faces from medical research images and automatically match these with photographs on a large scale, creating an imminent and growing threat to the privacy of research participants, including those in many large imaging studies of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and related dementias. We propose a novel technique that de-identifies MRI by replacing facial imagery with an average face, producing a de-identified MRI that resembles an unmodified image and has reduced negative effects upon popular brain biomarker measurement software. We propose to develop/refine, extend, validate, and publicly share our technique to protect the privacy of research participants and promote wider, safer sharing of research imaging data.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative This 5-year program's goal is to support FDA's efforts to improve the training of state, local, territorial and tribal (SLTT) food safety officials, set standards, and administer training and education programs to ensure a competent work force in program areas under its purview by addressing the four key components: 1) National Curriculum Standard (NCS) development; 2) Course Delivery and Planning for Course Offerings and Program Area; 3) Course Design, Development and Evaluation; and 4) Facilitation for Updating and Developing. The project aims will be achieved thorough the following specific deliverables per Project Year, which can be adjusted to meet OTED priorities: 1) Participate in Annual Meeting with OTED; 2) Support 2 instructor led course development/redesign projects with 2 development meetings, 2 walkthroughs, and 2 pilots; 3) Develop or redesign up to 5 web courses; 4) Support up to 14 instructor led course deliveries in Years 1-3, 13 deliveries in Year 4, and 12 deliveries in Year 5 for federal and SLTT regulators; 5) Provide unlimited access to hosted web courses by federal and SLTT regulators; 6) Support NCS development work such as conducting gap analyses of existing course content and resource materials, and development or refinement of curriculum frameworks; 7) Support facilitation of online focus groups or development, administration and analysis of surveys to either evaluate the need for new OTED courses, revise existing courses, change course delivery modalities, or solicit input on OTED business processes; 8) Provide technical support to OTED on 508 compliance and instructional design practices, following the ADDIE framework; 9) Report all course performance and evaluation data to OTED; and 10) Submit required financial and progress reports. Our goal is to serve as a resource for OTED and provide flexibility in our approaches and plan.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Supporting FDA’s National Curriculum Standard Development and Training Development and Delivery

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative: Sleep apnea is associated with cardiovascular dysfunction and increased performance fatigability. Thus, the development of novel treatments to eliminate apnea and mitigate associated co-morbidities is imperative. We will address this mandate by determining if repeated exposure to mild intermittent hypoxia (MIH) mitigates cardiovascular dysfunction and performance fatigability. We propose that exposure to MIH has a multipronged effect. MIH directly targets cardiovascular co-morbidities, while simultaneously enhancing upper airway stability and increasing the arousal threshold. These modifications may serve to directly mitigate apnea. Alternatively, these modifications may serve to improve treatment adherence with continuous positive airway pressure. Independent of its effect, MIH may serve as an adjunctive therapy which provides another path to mitigating cardiovascular co-morbidities that might ultimately result in improvements in performance fatigability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription factors directly bind DNA to regulate the expression of targeted genes within brain cells, a process that is initiated by drug use. While the expression and function of transcription factors is correlated with addiction, the exact causal contribution of these factors in worsening drug use behaviors often remains unclear. Here, we demonstrate the potential of utilizing re-engineered synthetic transcription factors to query the causal contribution of ZFP189 to the drug-specific phenotype to resolve their exact role in drug-specific transcription and behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The PKA catalytic subunit serves as a structural prototype for the protein kinase superfamily, while the diverse functionally non-redundant holoenzymes serve as a model for dynamic allosteric regulation by a second messenger. In parallel with characterizing macromolecular polyvalent PKA signaling complexes, we will use our interdisciplinary tools to characterize previously unstudied Cβ isoforms that are highly expressed in neurons, including pathogenic Cβ mutants, as well as mutants of RIβ, that are also highly expressed in neurons, that form novel biomolecular condensates in cells, and that are associated with dementia.

PHR: Project Narrative  The fundamental premise of this training program is that early engagement of computationally strong students, principally engineers, in understanding fundamental mechanisms of neuroscience will accelerate development of technology and solutions for the diagnosis and treatment of stroke, Parkinson’s disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, traumatic brain injury, pain, epilepsy, paralysis, and other neurodegenerative disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In accordance with NINDS scientific goals to “understand the basic mechanisms of neurological disorders”, and “to discover and validate biomarkers and outcome measures”, the proposed work will advance the understanding of the neurobiological basis for poststroke spasticity and provide quantitative neuroimaging biomarkers to be used as outcome measures in clinical trials. This research will solve an urgent public health need to provide a more complete understanding of the neural mechanisms of poststroke spasticity by characterizing the functions of major descending and ascending circuits in relation to spastic hypertonia and hyperreflexia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This study seeks to establish a registry with a cohort of 6,000 individuals living with Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) across the lifespan with a dual purpose of understanding the determinants of the manifold acute and chronic complications of this common genetic disease. We will develop guidelines to improve the clinical care of patients living with SCD receiving healthcare at various levels of care delivery in Ghana. We will work collaboratively with the Clinical Coordinating Center of SPARCO to conduct three cohort studies, three implementation research studies and store patient-consented bio- specimens for future studies in a bid to establish the necessary infrastructure to develop a SCD in sub-Saharan Africa Research Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic diseases, including diabetes mellitus and obesity, are major public health concerns in the US and worldwide. The objective of this Training Program is to recruit, mentor, and train a talented and diverse cadre of scientists to carry out cutting-edge basic science and translational research focused on improving the health of individuals with or at risk of type 1 and type 2 diabetes, obesity, and their associated complications. This program will leverage the infrastructure, resources, and rich training environment of the Indiana University School of Medicine and the Indiana Diabetes Research Center to nurture the careers of the next generation of diabetes, obesity, and metabolism investigators.

ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: NARRATIVE There are a variety of motor deficits following stroke which present growing challenges to healthcare. Therapeutic practice with physical devices remains an exciting frontier for the recovery of function, but a critical question is precisely how such devices should be programmed. Here we investigate differences in outcomes using models that describe how a person responds to error during practice, and we evaluate how well these models can prescribe the best therapeutic training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Coordination of the cellular transcriptional program is central to all processes of life, including growth and differentiation as well as response to environmental cues. Emerging evidence suggests a primary role for coding and non-coding RNAs in mediating this response through direct interaction with transcription factors. Uncovering the mechanisms of action of this layer of regulation promises to reveal fundamental processes driving the transcriptional response as well as uncover new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic exposures to environmental dusts lead to lung inflammation, injury, and disease. The overarching goal of our studies is to determine how dietary omega-3 fatty acids promote resolution and repair in the lung following dust exposure through regulating macrophage-derived IL-22 signaling. These studies support NIH goals by increasing our understanding of how particulate matter inhalation impacts lung inflammation, and exploring strategies for promoting recovery from these inflammatory exposures to protect against disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative People living with HIV have comparable life-expectancy as their HIV-negative peers but their life-quality is deeply compromised due to the high prevalence of neuropsychiatric disorders. Cocaine abuse could exacerbate the existing neurological disorders in PLWHIV. Understanding the detailed mechanisms for the combined effects of HIV/HIV-TAT, antiretroviral and cocaine on microglial activation and neuronal injuries could give us clues to develop effective therapeutics and interventions for those people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Transgender and other gender minority youth (TGMY) experience high rates of psychosocial (e.g., depression, teen dating violence) and behavioral health (e.g., substance use) problems, which are rooted in experiences of gender-related minority stress (e.g., peer and family rejection, internalized transphobia). This project aims to complete feasibility and pilot testing of a synchronous, group-delivered eHealth mentoring and skill-building program (i.e., Teen Connection Project) for TGMY ages 14 to 17 that focuses on evidence-based skill-building components (e.g., social-emotional skills) designed to reduce psychosocial and behavioral health problems in this population. The proposed project aligns with NIMHD’s research priorities to advance the scientific understanding of health disparities and improve minority health as well as the NIH Strategic Plan to Advance Research on the Health and Well-Being of Sexual and Gender Minorities (2021-2025).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In humans, mutations of SAGA subunits have been implicated in developmental disorders, neurological, endocrinological, and immunological diseases, and several cancers. Any novel and specific function assigned to the conserved yeast SAGA subunits will yield new mechanistic insight and will likely be generalizable to higher eukaryotes. By revealing a new and predictive mechanistic understanding for the precise effects of SAGA mutations, our work has the potential to radically transform how human diseases are studied and how drugs are developed.

South Carolina will enhance and support a national level integrated system by expanding routine surveillance of human and animal food products and enhancing preparedness for food defense response while also contributing to a growing understanding of microbial ecology and diversity through whole genome sequencing of foodborne pathogens. These projects will serve as a foundation to strengthen and improve the FDA’s efforts to prevent foodborne illness and minimize exposures in order to build upon a nationally integrated laboratory science system and equips partner laboratories with additional resources to increase sample throughput capacity within the state.

PHR: Project Narrative Nonmuscle myosin motors play important roles in almost every physiological process, including cell migration, cell adhesion, and cell division. A variety of human diseases are the direct result of defects in nonmuscle myosin motors, yet the underlying molecular mechanisms are unknown. We will apply structural, biochemical and cell biological approaches to define how nonmuscle myosins work to contribute to our understanding of their fundamental roles in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This research application is relevant to the public health because it will characterize an important group of proteins called androgen receptor-interacting proteins, which bind androgen receptor to modulate androgen-mediated functions in reproductive organs including the testes and prostate gland, as well non-reproductive systems such as the pancreas, musculoskeletal system, and motor neurons. Moreover, androgen receptor-interacting proteins represent a special class of genetic and biochemical modifiers of pathological functions underlying androgen receptor-related diseases that afflict multiple organ-tissue systems in humans. The findings of this research proposal will be directly responsive to part of NIH’s mission to provide fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems and the long-term goal to uncover new knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Untreated opioid withdrawal and craving leads to poor treatment retention and high rates of relapse among those seeking treatment for opioid use disorder. Opioid withdrawal and craving are influenced by transmitter systems (dopamine, serotonin) that may not be fully treated with existing medications. We will evaluate whether buspirone (Buspar), an FDA-approved medication that acts on these systems, mitigates withdrawal and craving during residential and outpatient treatment.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: MASSACHUSETTS STATE DEPT OF PUB HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Massachusetts Department of Public Health State Public Health Laboratory (MASPHL) is applying for funding under PAR-20-105, the Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (U19). By participating in projects related to routine surveillance of human and animal food products, Massachusetts will be contributing to a National Integrated Food Safety System. Routine sampling testing allows Massachusetts officials to assess the overall burden of pathogens and chemical contaminants in the food supply, and to respond quickly before there is human illness. MASPHL will also use the funding opportunity to enhance programs such as food defense which will allow Massachusetts to be able to respond to intentional or unintentional threats to the food supply. Lastly, Massachusetts residents will benefit from the funding opportunity as MASPHL is able to develop new capacity for the detection of Cyclospora in food products following outbreaks in 2019, and to assess the level of allergens in the food supply.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Lab Food Safety Testing Program

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: New Jersey Food Testing Program - Food Safety and Defense (2020-2025): Overall Narrative The New Jersey Department of Health will test foods for microbiological, chemical, and radiological contaminants, further integrate its food testing into a unified food defense system, and expand its testing capabilities and capacity to support FDA activities. The data will be used to remove potentially harmful products from the market and proposed activities will further safeguard public health and support FDA priorities by providing federal and State partners with critical microbial, chemical, and radiological contaminant data and capacity they can use to enhance their own food defense practices.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: New Jersey Food Testing Program - Food Safety and Defense

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Food and feed safety laboratories serve to create public goods through the creation of knowledge using analytical science that informs the creation of sound policy, provides consumer confidence against adverse economic impacts in a global marketplace, and protects the health of the general public from food and feed adulteration or pathogenic outbreaks. The accreditation of food and feed safety laboratories, through ISO/IEC 17025, is considered a gold standard in demonstrating the competence to perform defensible laboratory science in support of these public goods. The Laboratory Accreditation Rule of the 2011 Food Safety Modernization Act, implemented by the Food and Drug Administration, makes the activity of achieving and maintaining accreditation pivotal for food and feed safety laboratories to actively participate in a fully integrated food safety system.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Expansion of Pennsylvania's State Food and Feed Laboratory Services in Response to the 2011 Food Safety Modernization Act, Laboratory Accreditation Rule, and the FDA Integrated Food Safety System

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PAR-20-105 Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (LFFM) (U19) Overall Component  Division of Consolidated Laboratory Services  Principal Investigators: Christopher Waggener, Ph.D. SF424: Other Project Information Project Summary: The Division of Consolidated Laboratory Services (DCLS) is the public health laboratory for the Commonwealth of Virginia and offers a wide variety of laboratory testing services for state and federal agencies, local governments and other states in support of public health, environmental protection and emergency response. DCLS provides surveillance and emergency response testing of food samples for the Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services (VDACS) Food Safety Program by offering nearly comprehensive testing of food samples by microbiology, chemistry and radiochemical methods. DCLS obtained ISO/IEC 17025 accreditation in January 2017 and has expanded this scope of accreditation to include nine test methods, and proposes to maintain and further expand this accreditation scope to include up to three new test methods during the budget period. DCLS’ experience with testing MFRPS food samples for our state partners along with participation in proficiency testing events, dedicated BSL-2 trained staff, dedicated laboratory space and equipment along with our long-standing history with the FERN Network, sets DCLS apart from other state testing facilities. If granted these funds for human and animal food safety/defense testing for all three disciplines, DCLS is committed to providing emergency testing, surveillance and regulatory human and animal food testing for any situation when called upon by the FDA. DCLS is also committed to providing testing support for national security events as well as participate in all proficiency tests and training when applicable. DCLS will participate in FDA-requested exercises, and/or surveillance activities to support and maintain a state of readiness. In an effort to maintain a state of readiness, DCLS will ensure analysts are trained and have passed competency exercises, all equipment will remain in working order, and reagents and supplies are available or could easily or quickly be procured.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Proposal Narrative Bone marrow transplantation is a preferred treatment for high-risk acute leukemia and other bone marrow diseases. Inflammation of the GI tract and lung, caused by donor white cells, is a significant cause of complications after transplant. We have found that a population of immune cells that block inflammation is lost after bone marrow transplantation. The goals of the current work are to better understand why these cells don’t develop after transplant. This should allow us to develop new methods to generate/maintain these cells to prevent transplant-associated inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Findings from the past few years have changed traditional views about the role of lymphatics in health and disease. Lymphatics are now considered to be active, tissue-specific players in major physiological and pathophysiological processes, including cardiovascular, neurological, and metabolic diseases. Improving our understanding of the metabolic landscape of LECs in normal and pathological vascular beds should help us better characterize the complex, step-by-step process leading to the formation of fully mature vascular networks, and offer novel approaches for treating vascular diseases. Accordingly, the stimulation or blockage of LEC metabolism could potentially be used to promote or inhibit vessel growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Despite increasing popularity, human health hazards associated with exposure to e-cigarette (e-cig) aerosols are poorly defined. New data suggests significant health risks may be associated with inhalation of hazardous metals, including known neurotoxicants, released from various components of the e-cig device, and also varying depending on e-liquid flavoring and operation parameters. Human cell culture and animal models will be used to identify which e-cig aerosol mixtures pose significant neurotoxic risk(s), with particular emphasis on individuals genetically-susceptible for neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although routine use of patient-reported outcomes capturing the lived experience of chronic inflammatory skin disease in clinical practice has the potential to improve quality of care, patient-reported outcomes are rarely used in the clinical setting. This research will prioritize the outcome domains most meaningful to patients with chronic inflammatory skin disease and develop and field test a novel patient-reported outcome profile that uses item response theory-based Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) scales to enable efficient administration in a busy clinical setting. The results of this work will facilitate the routine use of patient-reported outcomes in the clinical setting, which has the potential to improve patient satisfaction, symptom management, treatment selection, and patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Health disparities research is a high priority for public health, but there is a vital element of healthcare quality with a paucity of data on disparities: compassion from treating clinicians. In an academic primary care network, we will use a mixed methods research design to test for differences in patient experience of clinician compassion between health disparity and non-disparity populations, and test if these differences are associated with greater patient distrust of the healthcare system among health disparity populations. We will also identify salient clinician behaviors that communicate compassion (or lack of) for health disparity populations, to inform a future R01 application that will develop and test patient-informed training curricula to raise clinician compassion for health disparity populations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Compassion Disparities in Primary Care: A Mixed Methods Pilot Study

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High levels of postpartum uninsurance among individuals with Medicaid-paid births contribute to rising rates of maternal morbidity and mortality in the United States. Passed in response to the COVID-19 Public Health Emergency, the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA) and the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) allow for federal (FFCRA) and state (ARPA) extensions of pregnancy-related Medicaid eligibility through the first year postpartum. Our study will produce data of high scientific value to inform whether these large-scale interventions are an effective tool for improving maternal and child health and racial health equity in the year after birth.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Maternal and Child Health in the Year After Birth: An Early Evaluation of Postpartum Medicaid Eligibility Extensions

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: RHODE ISLAND STATE DEPT OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative for State of Rhode Island PAR-20-105 Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (LFFM) (U19) Application: Overall Project Narrative The Rhode Island State Health Laboratories (RISHL) is applying for five years of LFFM funding to maintain and expand the food microbiology and chemistry testing capabilities of its state’s food testing laboratories. RISHL will continue to interactively support the integrated food safety system with the goal of providing an increased variety of testing services to respond to threats to the integrated food safety system and national food supply. The RISHL will administer, manage and coordinate the Analytical Projects under three disciplines of the Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (LFFM), Microbiology, Chemistry and Special Projects by leveraging its food laboratories’ organizational and quality management systems. RISHL’s Chief Environmental Laboratory Scientist and Chief Biological Laboratory Scientist will serve as principal and co-principal investigators. Together along with RISHL’s microbiology and chemistry Quality Assurance Officers, database administrator (to be hired) and its strong team of food laboratory scientists, RISHL will exercise its systems to fulfill the requirements of these multi-faceted disciplines. RISHL will work closely with the FDA NFSDX and ORAPP teams to further develop its data exchange capabilities and improve the submission and availability of its food sample collection and testing data to the FDA and network of state food safety surveillance and defense programs. 1
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Enhancing State Food Microbiology and Chemistry Testing Laboratories Capacity and Capabilities In Support of the Integrated Food Safety System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Health Relevance Narrative: Instability of neuronal function can be debilitating, as evident from its association with numerous neurological disorders – including forms of epilepsy and migraine that present with acute attacks, or forms of neurodegeneration which can manifest in decades-long problems. In order to develop more effective treatments for disorders caused by unstable function, we need a better understanding of how neurons maintain stability. This proposal addresses that problem, using a genetic model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  People with schizophrenia are characterized by marked impairments in cognitive function, for which there are no current pharmacological treatments. The development of an effective intervention for cognitive impairments remains a major therapeutic challenge. Prebiotics are dietary fibers that promote the growth or activity of gut microorganisms, which leads to the enhanced well-being of the host. The proposed R61 and R33 projects are designed to evaluate the hypothesis that prebiotic administration will lead to increased production of butyrate, through increased activity of butyrate-producing bacteria in the gut microbiota; the increase in serum butyrate levels will be associated with changes in cognitive function, symptoms, and metabolic measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Heart failure remains a leading cause of mortality and morbidity for both men and women in the United States. Despite recent advances in the treatment of heart failure, new cases are still increasing by 10% per year which imposes a significant economic burden especially with the increased aging population. The current treatments for heart failure focus primarily on symptom management in the end-stage after irreversible remodeling has occurred by delaying the progression of the syndrome. Herein we aim to identify early changes following cardiac injury that drive this process to aid the diagnosis and development of therapies to prevent the irreversible remodeling and heart failure altogether.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses the critical limitation in currently-available outcome measures of clinical disability progression in people with multiple sclerosis (MS), a limitation that has greatly impeded therapeutic development for people with the progressive form of the disease. Wearable tri-axial actigraphs are non- invasive, inexpensive devices that measure patterns of activity in a home-based, real-world setting; using our sophisticated analytic approach incorporating multiple dimensions of activity patterns, we are able to distinguish even small numbers of people with MS based on the gold-standard clinical disability score. We hypothesize that actigraphy-derived measures, alone or in combination with other currently-employed phase 2 trial outcome measures, will improve the prediction of clinical disability progression, setting the stage for meaningful breakthroughs in treatments by transforming the conduct of clinical trials among people with the devastating, progressive form of MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH) is the most common form of hereditary rickets, yet current treatments lack efficacy and no treatments are available to specifically improve associated dentoalveolar defects that substantially affect oral health and quality of life. Limited efficacy of treatments to date is in part related to complex etiology of mineralization defects in XLH, including local perturbations unaddressed by current treatment approaches. This project is designed to provide new insights into local mineralization defects in dentoalveolar tissues using a mouse model of XLH, and to test novel treatment approaches to prevent and ameliorate those defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: Parkinson's disease (PD) and Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) are a chronic neurodegenerative illnesses which affect 1-2% of people over age 65 and are associated with disability, reductions in quality of life, caregiver distress, pain, fatigue, dementia and increased mortality. While PD and LBD are typically managed using a chronic disease model focused on motor symptoms such as tremor, palliative care offers an opportunity to improve quality of life for patients with PD/LBD and their family caregivers by addressing potential causes of suffering not well met in current models of care including advance care planning, non-motor symptoms such as pain, psychosocial issues, caregiver distress and spiritual needs. This proposal will build upon work by members of this research team to conduct a pragmatic clinical trial of a novel palliative care model for PD delivered through online communities for patients, caregivers and clinicians with the specific objectives of determining whether: a) this community-based intervention is effective to improve patient quality of life or caregiver distress; and b) this approach is feasible to disseminate palliative services more widely to PD patients and their families in the communities in which they live.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PAR-20-105: Overall Component Project Narrative The Washington State Department of Agriculture (WSDA) Food Safety & Consumer Services (FS&CS) Laboratory has a history of demonstrated success as an awarded CAP member for FERN, MFRPS ISO, AFRPS, BSE, RRT, Produce Safety, USDA-MDP, beginning in 2000 to the present. As a CAP member, the laboratory actively participates in all activities associated with the Cooperative Agreements: sample collection, testing, proficiency testing, training seminars, conferences, face-to- face annual meetings, IT integration and method validation assignments. As an ISO17025:2005-2017 accredited laboratory, we’ve had a quality management system in place since 2011 with a dedicated quality assurance staff and procedures in place to assure good laboratory practices. We have laboratory facilities to assure the proper environment for advanced instrumentation in addition to secure sample custody and laboratory space. As a current FDA FERN, ISO and AFRPS cooperative agreement-funded laboratory, the laboratory is applying for five years of funding through the FDA Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (LFFM) Cooperative Agreement Program’s Discipline A Microbiology Track 2, 3, 4 and 5 and Discipline D Special Project Track 1, 2, 3 in order to enhance the capacity and capabilities of the laboratory in support of an integrated food safety system. The laboratory will participate in:  1. The use of various standardized cultural, biochemical and molecular analytical methods for the  detection and identification of foodborne pathogens in human and animal food (Discipline A  Microbiology Track 2 and 3). The laboratory will participate in human and animal food  sample analysis for surveillance assignments, food emergency outbreak testing, and ensure  large-scale food emergency event surge capacity by using various standardized cultural and  biochemical analytical methods for the detection and identification of pathogens. The WSDA  FS&CS Laboratory has trained staff and equipment to perform testing of pathogens as well as  serological analysis for Listeria monocytogenes (Poly O, Type 1 and Type 4), Escherichia coli  O157:H7 (O157 and H7), and E. coli STEC Big Six (all six O types).  2. Sequence using Whole Genome Sequencing for at least 100 isolates of pathogens.  The laboratory has the training and equipment to sequence and will upload sequences into  GenomeTrakr (Discipline A Track 4).  3. Gaining capacity for Cyclospora testing (Discipline A Track 5). The laboratory needs to gain  capacity by request of our food safety partners and to be a supportive member of the  integrated national laboratory system. The laboratory has worked hard to find funding to  support Cyclospora testing and was able to secure very small funding support to send its  microbiologists for a week long training at FDA Bothell in FDA BAM 19b Molecular Detection  of Cyclospora cayetanensis in Fresh Produce using Real-Time PCR method. We have some  equipment to support the test but we must purchase several more pieces, therefore we  require support.  4. The collection of samples (>1,000) (Discipline D Track 1). For decades, we have utilized  annual sampling agreements with our regulatory inspection partners. Our laboratory’s self-  sample collection history dates back to 2001 as a member of the USDA AMS Microbiological  Data Program (MDP) and for regulatory purposes. Training provided by USDA included  aseptic sampling technique, preserving sample integrity during transit, and maintaining  complete chain of custody documentation. Our sampling experience has only grown stronger  as a FDA FERN MCAP participant. For instance we collected over 3,600 samples in the last 2  years for testing by our FERN lab.  5. The integration of NFSDX-ORAPP systems with our data collection systems. We worked  closely with FDA for integrating our system to eLEXNET, so we desire to work on this new  integration. (Discipline D Track 2)  6. The Validation of a qPCR screening method for Salmonella in Foods (Discipline D Track 3).  We have decades of history validating methods under the USDA MDP, FERN MCAP, private  test manufacturers, as well as our own “Fit for Purpose” methods.  Washington State Department of Agriculture, Food Safety and Consumer Services Laboratory
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Enhancing the Capacity and Capability of Washington State Human and Animal Food Testing Laboratory in Support of an Integrated Food Safety System

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this proposal is to leverage the Wadsworth Center’s considerable laboratory capabilities and capacity as a world-class public health laboratory and research institute, coupled with its scientific expertise to create a first-class integrated Radiochemical, Microbiological and Chemical Testing Program for Food Defense and Capability Development that will serve the future needs of the FDA’s Food Emergency Response Network (FERN). Building on its current success as an FDA-FERN Cooperative Agreement laboratory for the Surveillance of Foods for Alpha, Beta, and Gamma Radioactivity; as an FDA Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition (CFSAN) Cooperative Agreement GenomeTrakr laboratory; and as a USDA Food Safety Inspection Service (FSIS) Cooperative Agreement laboratory for Microbiology and Chemistry Food Defense, the Wadsworth Center will provide key leadership, scientific expertise and analytical support to FERN under the proposed Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (LFFM).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Wadsworth Center's Radiochemical, Microbiological and Chemical Testing for Food Defense and Capability Development

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: NY STATE DEPT OF AGRICULTURE/ MARKETS
PHR: NY AGM Division of Food Laboratory Project Narrative: The New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets (NY AGM) has a comprehensive food safety inspection program and regulatory food safety testing laboratory. The Division of Food Laboratory is willing and able to engage with the national food safety system initiative by (1) participating in, and passing, annual chemistry and microbiology food related proficiency tests offered through a suitable proficiency testing program; (2) participating in small-scale chemistry and microbiology food testing related method development, method validation research, and matrix extension research, as requested by the FDA; (3) providing chemistry and microbiology food testing related training and mentorship to other state laboratories, as requested; (4) continuing to be a FERN member; (5) participating in annual LFFM face-to-face meeting; (6) maintaining ISO/IEC 17025 accreditation to ensure quality assurance and quality control testing; (7) maintaining laboratory facilities and personnel necessary to complete regulatory activities; (8) providing notifications, summaries and reports to FDA, as requested and required; (9) engaging NY AGM inspectors to collect regulatory food samples and ensure they maintain best practices when sampling FDA food regulatory products; (10) notifying the FDA project manager and the technical lead within one (1) business day of any presumptive positive or “cannot rule out” (CRO) food samples, (11) submitting a full laboratory package for any confirmed positive or violative food sample, as required; (12) maintaining a confidentiality agreement with FDA as a valid 20.88; (13) participating annually in at least one FDA requested assignment related to food testing; (14) providing an outline plan on how the laboratory will sequence genomes and upload data in real-time to NCBI-NIH curated national database for enteric pathogens; and (15) providing outline plans for Chemistry and Microbiology Capability/Capacity Development and for Special Projects (Sample Collection, NFSDX and ORAPP Integration, and Method Development/Validation).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: NYS AGM Food Laboratory - Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (LFFM) (U19)

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: VERMONT STATE AGENCY OF HUMAN SERVICES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Vermont Farm to Plate Network’s Rooted in Vermont grassroots initiative has increased locally sourced food purchases from 6.9% in 2010 to 12.9% in 2018 (representing more than $289 million in local food sales) and aims to mainstream local food consumption in Vermont during the next decade. At the same time, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates that 1 in 6 Americans (or 48 million people) get sick, over 128,000 are hospitalized, and 3,000 die from contaminated foods or beverages each year and the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) estimates that these foodborne related illnesses cost over $15.6 billion dollars each year. The Vermont Department of Health Laboratory (VDHL) attained ISO/IEC 17025 accreditation in September 2016 and is the primary serving laboratory for the VDH Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS) and is seeking funding to maintain and enhance its ISO/IEC 17025 accreditation, increase its microbiological and radiochemical food sample testing capacity and capabilities, increase its data sharing and surveillance capabilities, and overall capacity to protect Vermonters from unsafe food supplies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: VDH Laboratory Food Testing Capability and Capacity Enhancement Project

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The rise of high-throughput genomic profiling of individual cells and efficient, targeted manipulation of cellular phenotypes (including CRISPR-based genetic perturbations) promise to revolutionize our understanding of cellular biology and disease. However, realizing this revolution will require new computing paradigms that can integrate and analyze these massive datasets and suggest new biological hypotheses and experimental designs. Here we develop novel computational algorithms and software for tackling these challenges to characterize cellular diversity and improve our ability to manipulate cells to understand and treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative It has been estimated that neurodevelopmental disabilities (NDDs) affect at least 10% of all families in the USA. A new generation of multidisciplinary investigators are urgently needed who will be able to apply cutting-edge research approaches and new technology to elucidate mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of these disorders, so that new and more effective therapeutic interventions can be developed. The major objective of our NDD training program – the DC NDD T32 Training Program - is to fill this need by leveraging on all resources available at our institutions in the District of Columbia and at our DC-IDDRC. We have been successful in training several generations of investigators in research that will advance our understanding of NDDs, and the proposed program will support training and career development of new investigators by providing 3 years of coaching and experience under the direction of a highly qualified investigator/mentorship team.

PHR: Narrative Enduring cognitive and emotional difficulties are frequently reported as factors reducing quality of life by individuals living with a traumatic brain injury (TBI). The proposed study will investigate the impact of altered endocytosis on synaptic vesicular recycling and neurotransmission that contribute to impaired synaptic function after a TBI. PHR: Project Narrative Enhancing the Capacity and Capability of Human Food and Environmental Testing Laboratory  in the Texas Department of State Health Services  With this new funding opportunity, the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) Laboratory Services Section (LSS) intends to use funds to maintain and build our capabilities and capacity for microbiological, radiochemistry and chemistry-based food testing and emergency response to be utilized in Texas as well as nationally to improve the overall safety of our food supply and subsequently the public’s health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Much of the focus in biomedical science today concerns failures of regulatory circuits that control proliferation, growth, and maintain homeostasis. Two of the most important are the Wnt pathway, prominent in cell differentiation and cancer, and cell size control, important in bridging physiology with growth. We use several new methods including new forms of microscopy and biochemistry to understand these pathways in mechanistic chemical terms with the hope of appreciating their normal function and addressing underlying pathologies.

PHR: Narrative Brain Injury Training Grant The continuing aim of the Brain Injury Training Grant (BITG) is to provide an excellent mentoring environment for highly motivated clinician and basic scientists to prepare them for careers in nervous system injury research. We request continued funding for 4 post-doctoral training slots (simultaneous) for individuals with a strong interest in studying injury to the nervous system who will train within a broader program. These positions are anticipated to be filled by a combination of neurosurgical residents (during their strictly protected research training) and highly qualified Ph.D. graduates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1 PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic resistance is the rule rather than the exception and strongly limits the clinical benefits of recently introduced “breakthrough” treatments for advanced melanoma. Translating cancer research into patient survival depends on a deep understanding of resistance mechanisms to clinically active therapies. As RAF/MEK and PD-1/CTLA-4 therapies were first developed in patients with advanced melanoma, overcoming resistance to these therapies has wide-reaching implications for cancer treatments in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 2 PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy and targeted therapeutics are having major impact on melanoma treatment. Nonetheless, in many patients resistance arises as these treatments drive melanomas towards aggressive, resistant subtypes, such as dedifferentiated variants. We have discovered a new Achilles heel for dedifferentiated melanomas related to their sensitivity to oxidative stress, and are pursuing co-treatment therapies that would prevent dedifferentiation-based resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Denervation of skeletal muscle from traumatic or iatrogenic injuries causes devastating and often permanent disability. Full function is rarely recovered, but given the uncertain nature of peripheral nerve recovery, the independent effects of increasing degrees of nerve injury on muscular atrophy are not well understood. This project seeks to characterize the effects of increasing degree of nerve injury on muscular atrophy and better visualize this process in real time utilizing calpain sensitive custom designed optical probes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3 PROJECT NARRATIVE In the new era of cancer immunotherapy becoming standard of care and often the preferred frontline therapy for several cancers, it is of key importance to understand why some patients never respond to this mode of therapy, and how some patients respond and then progress. If we understand these processes at the mechanistic level we can then rationally design approaches to prevent or treat resistance to cancer immunotherapy in patients with advanced melanoma, with applicability to many other cancers. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE B PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed projects of this PPG seek to understand the molecular and cellular basis for mechanisms and resistance to targeted therapy or checkpoint inhibitors to allow the rational design of combinatorial therapies that treat and eventually prevent resistance. These studies rely heavily on patient-derived samples collected both at UCLA and provided by outside collaborators through the Biospecimen Repository and Processing Core (BRPC). Core B will serve for obtention, generation, and authentication of biomaterial (tissue and biofluid) from patient samples; as well as provide advanced expertise in melanoma biology, cell line development, pathologic interpretation and biorepository management for all proposed studies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disease Modifying Agents (DMAs) are not effective in older adults for preventing disability and disease progression associated with aging. Therefore, the goal of this research is to evaluate deprescribing and the associated effectiveness and safety outcomes in older adults with MS. This will be the first national study to provide valuable real-world evidence regarding DMA deprescribing and the associated outcomes with significant clinical and policy implications for improving prescribing practices and quality of care in older adults with MS.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Deprescribing of Disease Modifying Agents in Older Adults with Multiple Sclerosis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE C PROJECT NARRATIVE Patient-derived Xenograft (PDX) and Syngeneic Mouse Melanoma Core The study of therapeutic resistance in melanoma requires experimental models which faithfully recapitulate the complexity and heterogeneity of the disease. This proposed PDX and murine melanoma core will provide the three Projects in this application and the melanoma scientific community with a large-scale library of Patient- derived Xenograft (PDX) and murine melanoma models encompassing the genomic diversity of human melanomas. Through next generation omic profiling of these models, investigators will be able to discover or validate novel strategies to overcome resistance in the best possible melanoma model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Standard and non-standard analogs of insulin and glucagon will be designed, synthesized and characterized (in cells, rats and dogs) in an effort to enhance the efficacy and safety of novel delivery devices and closed- loop systems for the treatment of T1D. Non-standard insulin modifications will be sought that, for the first time, enhance in vivo potency without increased mitogenicity, which may decrease per-unit price and illuminate molecular determinants of bio-potency (as distinct from receptor binding). Basic scientific principles underlying protein design will be explored, including structural studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative My laboratory is pursuing fundamental questions about salivary gland development, maintenance and repair: (1) How do salivary stem cells enable organ renewal? (2) How do nerves control organ homeostasis and regeneration? (3) How does aging impact salivary stem cells? And finally, (4) How is salivary gland architecture created? We explore these questions with the ultimate goal of generating restorative therapies for restoring salivary function and improving quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF SCIENCES, TECH & TECH OF BAMAKO
PHR: Our goal is to improve quality and duration of life for people living with sickle cell disease (SCD) in Sub-Saharan Africa by joining the Sickle Pan-African Research Consortium Collaborative (SPARCO). We will enroll 4,000 people living with SCD from our center, the Sickle Cell Disease Research and Treatment Center (CRLD) in Bamako, Mali in a longitudinal cohort study. We plan to strengthen existing standards of care at CRLD for both preventive and acute SCD. In conjunction with SPARCO, we will perform observational and implementation research studies and seek to coordinate regionally feasible standards of care across Sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary aim of the proposed randomized parallel-group design clinical trial in 94 patients over 65 years old with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is to determine if exercise rehabilitation initiated with 4 weeks of a new intervention PRIME (focused on peripheral tissue beds without a significant cardiovascular workload) prior to 8 weeks of guideline recommended exercise (COMBO-aerobic and resistance training) is more beneficial that currently recommended 12 weeks of COMBO training. Our primary outcome measures are group changes in VO2peak (a critical predictor of death and hospitalization) during maximal cycle ergometry graded exercise test, with secondary clinical aims of strength (maximal voluntary contractions) and function (senior fitness test) will also be examined. We will examine the relative contributions of central (cardiac) and peripheral (skeletal muscle) markers to fitness and function and preliminarily explore if they endure at a 6-month follow-up timepoint.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: In response to excess calories, white adipose tissue expands by both generating more adipocytes via de novo adipogenesis and by enlarging existing adipocytes. The relative balance between these two modes of expansion has significant consequences to metabolic health. We propose that the primary cilium, a small antenna-like signaling organelle, of pre-adipocytes regulates how white adipose tissue expands, and that ciliary dysfunction in this context contributes to adipose tissue dysfunction and pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Center for Quantitative Biology of Complex Systems develops novel technologies that accelerate the pace and depth of protein, lipid, and metabolite analysis. These molecules, and their interactions, regulate the complex cellular processes underlying many devastating diseases. Specifically, the technologies developed in this Resource are being used to advance our understanding of many human conditions including diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, and heart disease, among others.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For patients with advanced cancer, pain is a common and disabling symptom for which opioids remain a mainstay of treatment. The current epidemic of opioid misuse and addiction has led to widespread changes in opioid-related policies, and the impacts of these policies on patients with advanced cancer near end of life are not well understood. This project will inform how state-level opioid policies can be structured to ensure safe and equitable opioid access for the roughly 600,000 adults who die from cancer annually in the United States.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Policies to Inform Safe and Equitable Opioid Access for Patients with Advanced Cancer Near End of Life

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this research program is to understand metabolic stress responses of adipose tissue. The focus of our analysis is on the stress responsive cJun NH2-terminal kinase (JNK) signaling pathway. We propose to combine physiological analysis together with an investigation of JNK isoforms to define molecular mechanisms that mediate adipose tissue stress responses. The knowledge obtained may represent a basis for the design of novel therapeutic strategies for the treatment of metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is a genetic low bone density disorder characterized by increased bone fracture, often from little or no apparent trauma. Current treatments are based on anti-resorptives that prevent fractures, yet may interfere with normal jaw bone healing. This study will develop an innovative OI treatment strategy by increasing bone formation to benefit implant osseointegration (bone healing) with anabolic Sclerostin antibody and to diagnose this SclAb-induced bone density with minimally invasive and sensitive bone-remodeling related miRNA biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Appropriately coordinated gene expression is involved in almost every process underlying human health and disease. Our studies will uncover new mechanistic insights into how human genes are controlled and will enable biomedical researchers to reshape gene expression easily and precisely within living cells. Since gene expression is fundamentally important, this new knowledge and technical ability can spur improved treatments for several human diseases and can result in new ways to sculpt clinically useful cellular behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Many smokers have taken up e-cigarettes hoping to quit smoking and reduce their health risks, but more than half of e-cigarette users continue to use cigarettes. Current research suggests these dual users of cigarettes and e-cigarettes are at high risk of negative health outcomes. This project designs and tests campaign messages and ads to educate dual users of cigarettes and e-cigarettes about their health risks and encourage them to quit cigarettes and e-cigarettes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Genome wide association studies (GWAS) are the dominant study design for identifying genetic variants associated with complex human disease. However, identifying the molecular and cellular effects responsible for a GWAS association is challenging and slow, which has thus far blunted the impact of GWAS on the understanding and treatment of human disease. This project will develop a new genomic community resource – the “Association to Function Knowledge Portal” – in order to make data and methods for interpreting GWAS associations more easily accessible, thus accelerating the pace at which findings from GWAS can be used to improve human health.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Inequities in access and outcomes of health services are a pervasive problem that has remained essentially unchanged over the past several decades in the United States, particularly in the Southeastern United States. This T32 post-doctoral fellow application proposes to train the next generation of health services researchers to receive multidisciplinary training in methods to both describe and address inequities in access to care, outcomes of care, and healthcare delivery in order to reduce health inequities in health services.

PROJECT_TITLE: Emory Health Services Research Center Training Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food insecurity is highly prevalent among college students and is associated with poor general and mental health, higher weight status, inadequate physical activity and sleep, and poor diet quality in this emerging adult population. Food insecurity likely influences cardiovascular and metabolic health (CVMH) among college students via several mechanisms, however, this relationship has received little attention. This project will elucidate mechanisms by which chronic food insecurity impacts CVMH among college students—a modifiable target for prevention of poor CVMH that is biologically plausible and common, and therefore potentially high impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immune based treatment strategies are increasingly employed to treat patients with Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL), but many patients still experience relapse. In this study I seek to identify biomarkers that are predictive of relapse following immunotherapy, and also to gain an understanding of the mechanisms underlying these relapses. This project will build a foundation for future clinical trials by informing the development of improved immunotherapies for this illness, thus directly contributing to the NIH mission to seek basic knowledge about the nature of living systems that will help to improve health, reduce illness and disability, and lengthen life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infectious Leptospira cause leptospirosis following contact with mucosa through wounds or ingestion, leading to headaches, fever, jaundice, kidney or liver failure, or death in about 1.03 million people each year. These bacteria are found worldwide and are shed in urine into the environment by mammalian hosts, however almost nothing is known about temporal and spatial pathogen population dynamics and the importance of different mammalian host species in cycling and transmission to humans. This information is essential for controlling and avoiding disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Nausea and vomiting (emesis) act as primitive aspects of our physiology and behavior that ensure survival and, contrarily, are also ubiquitously present side effects of drug treatments for chronic disease (e.g., obesity, diabetes, cancer) that reduce medical pharmacotherapy tolerance. Here, we address the antiemetic mechanism and potential of gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP) and GIP receptor activation as a novel system contributing to clinical drivers of emesis (e.g., glucagon-like-peptide-1 (GLP-1)-based drugs for obesity and diabetes, chemotherapy in cancer). Via this investigation, the work proposed may positively impact treatment of chronic metabolic diseases by improving the management of nausea and vomiting driven by common drug therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Prior successful interventions to address racial and socioeconomic inequities in access to kidney transplantation have been focused on provider- and patient-level interventions, and yet substantial health system barriers have prevented equity in access to kidney transplantation. The proposed study seeks to adapt and enhance sustainability of proven educational and quality improvement interventions to target multiple health systems– dialysis facilities and transplant centers – as well as clinical staff and patients in the Southeastern United States to target the policies, practices, and structures of these health systems that pose barriers to underrepresented minorities with end-stage kidney failure seeking a kidney transplant. If successful, interventions could be adapted and scaled nationally, where our health system partners are committed to transplant equity.

PHR: PI: Nguyen, Lien PROJECT NARRATIVE (3 sentences): Alzheimer's disease (AD) currently affects approximately 5.8 million people in the United States, however no effective treatments are available and causes for most sporadic AD cases remain unclear. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Multiple sclerosis (MS) results from an immune-response which triggers inflammation and demyelination in the central nervous system (CNS). There are an estimated 450,000 MS patients in United States alone. Unlike many other neurodegenerative diseases, MS affects mainly young adults; the lifetime direct and indirect costs estimated at $1.2 million per patient. Several sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor 1 (S1PR1) modulators had been approved by FDA for treating relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS) and show good efficacy. The PET with a imaging agent to measuring of S1PR1 expression my provide an innovative biomarker to predict, diagnose, and monitor the progression of MS, as well as valuate the efficacy of treating RRMS and other inflammatory diseases using S1PR1 inhibition strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): The lipid composition of cell membranes must be tightly regulated. Enzymes called Ubiquitin E3 ligases are embedded within the membrane and respond to changes in lipid levels by selectively labeling other proteins involved in lipid production for degradation. This proposal will study the biophysical and biochemical basis for how the lipid membrane composition regulates the activity of these enzymes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Raptor is the defining subunit of the mTORC1 complex, which functions as a master regulator of cellular metabolism. We have recently discovered a novel conditional loss-of-function mutation in the nematode C. elegans Raptor that confers improved survival from hypoxic injury. We will use the unique advantages of this mutant for genetic, cell biological, metabolomic, and proteomic approaches in C. elegans to define the mechanisms whereby Raptor controls hypoxic injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As part of the NCI Experimental Therapeutics Clinical Trials Network (ETCTN), the California Cancer  Consortium, consisting of four NCI-Designated Comprehensive Cancer Centers, will conduct early phase clinical  trials of investigational new anticancer agents. Through the use of multi-institutional, multi-disciplinary project  teams, the CCC will identify improved approaches to the development of novel anticancer agents that capitalize  on molecular characterization of cancers, while also providing the recommended dose and early evidence for  the therapeutic activity of these agents. Collectively, these efforts will expedite development of urgently needed  new drugs to treat patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the gene POU4F1 cause a childhood-onset ataxia, which is a condition with lack of coordination of voluntary body movements. We propose to study this disorder using cellular models of the developing human brain via the generation of 2D neuronal cultures and 3D brain organoids derived from human pluripotent stem cells with and without a POU4F1 mutation. The gene expression profiles of the wild-type and mutant cells will be compared.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is a serious and often fatal infectious disease, posing an enormous global health challenge with over 250 million cases per year and more than 600,000 deaths in year 2020. Our goal is to develop small chemical molecules that trick malaria parasites into producing multiple versions of an inhibitor of one of their own essential enzyme complexes, consequently overcoming resistance. Successful completion of the proposed studies will provide novel anti- malarial therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This study will perform novel released tumor DNA (rtDNA) and protein-based APT-weighted MRI assays on newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients. We will determine the accuracy of combined rtDNA/APT indices in identifying disease recurrence following the therapy. If our rtDNA/APT investigation is successful, it will allow clinicians to monitor response more accurately (as a result, potentially obviating the need for invasive neurosurgical procedures) and alter therapies more timely.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Giardia is a widespread intestinal parasite, and both parasite colonization of the host gut and transmission of cysts between hosts are key aspects of Giardia’s life cycle. Proteins called transcription factors (TFs) are essential for parasite growth, development, and survival in the host. This research seeks to identify and evaluate key TFs regulating parasite responses in the host, and this research could lead therapies that prevent or decrease the severity of Giardia infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggregation of α-synuclein at synapses, the functional contacts between neurons, has been linked to cognitive deficits and dementia in Parkinson’s disease and Dementia with Lewy Bodies. The proposed studies will provide insights into the early events and mechanisms leading to synaptic dysfunction in α-synuclein-related diseases. Understanding these mechanisms will help advance the development of therapies aimed at improving synapse function in neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Randomized controlled trials demonstrated a reduction in lung cancer mortality with annual lung cancer screening with low dose computed tomography, yet real-world populations eligible for and undergoing lung cancer screening differ substantially from trial populations. By leveraging data from a randomized controlled trial and multiple real-world data sources, the proposed study will evaluate the benefits and harms of lung cancer screening in clinical practice settings with a focus on optimizing internal and external validity by applying novel causal inference methodologies. The proposed research is consistent with the Cancer Moonshot Initiative of the National Cancer Institute, which issued a call to action on cancer screening and early detection in February 2022.
