IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Upper respiratory virus infection (URVI) is responsible for 80% of asthma attacks; however, the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood. This project is proposed to dissect the cellular and molecular mechanisms undelying the nose -lung cross talk, particularly how URVI causes asthma attacks. Findings from this research are expected to lead to not only novel preventive and therapeutic strategies for asthmatics, but also to define nasal mucosal immune system and subsequently facilitate nasal vaccine development against airborne pathogens. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Despite the functional importance, studies of long-distance human brain circuitry development and connectivity have been significantly hindered due to lack of suitable microphysiological platforms. To fill the critical gap, we will reconstruct human cortico-striatal circuits in both two and three dimensions by developing a novel microfluidic chip together with lineage-specific neuronal differentiation approaches and utilize such new paradigm to study axon projections, global network dynamics, and high-order brain function e.g., brain waves during human brain circuitry development. Completion of the proposed studies will present an innovative approach to reconstitute well-defined long-distance human brain circuits and gain novel insights into how cortical inputs drive human striatal function, laying the foundation for future pathological studies of patients- derived brain circuitry models such as schizophrenia and eventually for developing novel therapies for disease via targeting dysfunctional brain circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious diseases are particularly dangerous for individuals with compromised immune systems due to cancer, transplantation or other conditions, or medications that weaken the immune system. Immunocompromised persons are more susceptible to initial infection, less capable of successfully battling infections, and therefore more likely to have severe complications from infections that are rarely seen in the general population. We seek continued support to train two new physician-scientists and/or post-doctoral PhD scientists each year for three years in three research areas that will advance knowledge of the biology, pathogenesis, diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of infectious diseases in immunocompromised persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE We have identified a population of neurons in the brain that can be activated to induce torpor, a form of hibernation characterized by low body temperature and metabolic rate. Our preliminary data suggests that this synthetic torpor may reduce or prevent the progression of brain injury after stroke. We propose to confirm these preliminary findings and identify the metabolic pathways involved in cerebroprotection to develop novel treatment strategies for patients recovering from stroke and other forms of brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  Sexual minorities (e.g., gay, lesbian, and bisexual adults) have significantly greater risk for obesity, asthma, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and some cancers compared to heterosexuals. However, biomarkers of risk, modifiable behavioral and psychological factors, and intersectional identities contributing to these health disparities are unknown. With a robust sample size and strong representation across different sexual identities, NCHAT-BIO offers a uniquely comprehensive and methodologically rigorous investigation of stress biology among sexual minorities in the US, permitting novel tests of mechanisms linking stress, health, and intersectionality within a minority stress framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For patients with thoracic aortic aneurysms (TAA), prosthetic graft replacement of the ascending aorta eliminates dissection risk in graft-replaced regions, but risk increases in the distal aorta - especially in patients with genetically triggered aortopathies, who undergo graft replacement at lower thresholds, higher frequency, and younger age. Prosthetic grafts differ from native aortic shape and stiffness, and thus alter flow to distal aortic regions. This study will use cardiac MRI and computational modeling to test if prosthetic grafts drive adverse distal aortic remodeling and dissection, so as to inform risk stratification and therapy with current grafts, and guide development of new graft materials to accommodate for differential aortic compliance in patients with genetically triggered TAA – towards the goal of improved outcomes after proximal graft replacement surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work is aimed at deciphering the processes governing labral tear-mediated tissue damage while developing a new and complementary technology for treating glenoid labral tears with improved healing outcome. The results will lead to creation of a novel, injectable, in situ-forming, and biomolecule-releasing adhesive scaffold which can reduce inflammatory response-associated tissue damage and enhancing labral tissue regeneration by eliciting the regenerative activities of endogenous labral and progenitor cells at the site of the labral tear.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project has major public health relevance because diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) remain one of the most common secondary diabetes-related complications and are the leading cause of lower extremity amputation in the United States. Current treatments are ineffective and evidence now demonstrates a surge in major lower extremity amputations and necessitates development of novel treatment avenues and technologies to advance care for this vulnerable population. The main objective of this proposal is to utilize metagenomics next generation sequencing to understand the role of the microbiome in the pathogenesis of DFU and identify new treatments and reduce sequela of DFU.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Pathogens require iron for growth within host human cells, but the host can prevent pathogens from acquiring this metal. It is not known how pathogens in membrane compartments acquire this resource, or how the human prevents the pathogen from acquiring it. The proposed work will identify the source of this iron, how the iron moves across this membrane, and uncover strategies that prevent pathogens from having unlimited access to this source.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic or pharmacological disruption of brain mTOR activities are frequently associated with disrupted daily rhythms in patients and the mechanisms are unknown. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Brown adipocytes are associated with metabolic benefits to alleviate diabetes and obesity, but are much less abundant than white adipocytes in humans and hard to obtain in large numbers. We combine our novel technologies for extensive expansion of human adipocytes in culture and for engineering genes in these cells with CRISPR to convert them into brown-like adipocytes. Our project is designed to test the hypothesis that CRISPR-based disruption of two genes in particular--Nrip1 and Pkrar2—will optimally generate human brown adipocytes from abundant human white adipose tissue as a basic step towards therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The development of therapeutics for diseases, which includes vaccines to fight viruses such as COVID-19, is substantially aided by directly visualizing the viruses or cellular components responsible for causing disease. The NIH has recently established three National Centers that contain the most powerful microscopes on the planet, enabling biologists across the country to look at these tiny disease-causing components. We will design and build a series of cutting- edge computer programs to help biologists take better pictures, so that we are able to more quickly make biomedically important discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Cannabis use during pregnancy has increased substantially, in conjunction with legalization and decreases in the percentage of the population who believe cannabis use is harmful. Cannabis passes through the placenta and binds to cannabinoid receptors and can potentially alter prenatal brain development. In this prospective study, we will monitor cannabis use in pregnant women throughout their second and third trimester and investigate infant outcomes using brain imaging and behavioral measures that our prior work has shown to be sensitive for detecting early manifestations of neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: About 84,000 patients are expected to be diagnosed with bladder cancer this year and about 70-80% of the patients will have non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC), which is considered the golden time for cure of bladder cancer. Although intravesical treatments have been used following transurethral surgery, recurrence and progression to the advanced stage still remain critical problems. This proposed integrative project will provide new effective treatment strategy and prodrugs for treating NMIBC with a great potential for rapid clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The global malaria burden is demanding new therapeutics and a change in drug discovery paradigm to more time- and cost-efficient approaches. We propose herein the use of machine learning methodologies to discover novel dual-stage antimalarials lacking cross-resistance with existing therapies. The deliverables will be new computational models for hit discovery and validated hits which will be evolved to early lead molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Quantifying and preventing privacy leakages in data will enable increased use of omics and clinical data, thus permitting better statistical power for genotype–phenotype relationship inferences. The ability to accomplish this goal requires the development of efficient statistical, information theoretical, and privacy-preserving tools. The proposed research combines novel algorithmic advances with traditional bioinformatics methods for processing and combining genomics, transcriptomics, and clinical data in a privacy-enhancing manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The Opioid Epidemic constitutes a major public health crisis as rates of opioid use and overdose continue to rise in the United States. Many individuals with opioid user disorder struggle to remain abstinent, even those who have undergone treatment, necessitating development of new therapeutics. We will deepen our understanding of how opioid use changes the brain to promote relapse by identifying and manipulating activity- dependent transcriptional and epigenetic changes in an opioid self-administration mouse model, thereby informing new treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A major approach for treating brain disorders non-invasively is application of a transient magnetic field to the head, a procedure called transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS). The effects of TMS are relatively weak, however, and help only a minority of patients, likely due to unoptimized protocols for applying the stimulation. This project will use recordings of nerve cells in the brain, paired with models of brain activity, to reveal the fine- scale mechanisms of TMS and promote biologically-founded improvements to its use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Ending the HIV epidemic requires implementing proven tools in areas with the highest need such as the Deep South. We propose to adapt and deploy three tools to promote (1) HIV testing in under-tested communities, (2) effective linkage to care, and (3) rapid start of antiretroviral therapy in order to push three counties in rural Alabama closer to meeting targets to end the HIV epidemic. We will learn from administrators, providers, and clients how to adapt and scale the combination intervention to improve HIV outcomes in other rural HIV-endemic settings like Alabama.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the genetic basis of blood cell development is key to gain insight into immune deficiency disorders and leukemias. The fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, is a very powerful model organism for genetic dissection of blood development and studies in this model organism have led to several important advances in humans and provided the means to fill the gap between descriptive observations and in vivo function. This work explores the mechanisms that determine the balance between maintenance of blood progenitors and blood cell differentiation, which is critical for ensuring normal immune system development and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed project is to better understand the molecular underpinnings and cell diversity of opioid use disorder in the human brain. This study will conduct a joint profiling of methylomics, hydroxymethylomics, 3D chromatin structure, and transcriptomics of OUD in single nuclei from human postmortem brain to identify molecular targets that may inform prevention and treatment efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social isolation is an increasing public health problem and is associated with many negative physiological and psychological health outcomes. A handful of studies, including my own, have shown that social isolation also leads to bone loss in mice. This proposal will investigate the mechanisms by which social isolation affects bone metabolism, which may inform future clinical studies and treatment strategies in individuals suffering from social isolation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Finding effective treatments for neurological disorders and strokes requires not only a fundamental knowledge of the nervous system but also the participation of a diverse workforce to enhance our overall creativity. The inclusion of underrepresented groups in the biomedical scientific workforce is critical to addressing the need for improving the health of the U.S. population and eliminating health disparities nationwide. This project will increase the number of undergraduates from underrepresented minority groups being trained as the next generation of neuroscientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Critical treatment gaps exist for the sustained, local delivery of therapeutics, with a particularly urgent need for local anesthetics that are used to treat post-operative pain and minimize exposure to opioid medications. This work generates new biomaterial films and particles that are designed to be implanted within the body and that feature brush-like polymers extending from a surface, like blades of grass on a lawn. The approach represents a new platform to enable discoveries about how the brush-like polymer architectures impact therapeutic loading and release, as well as provide the opportunity to tune how cells interact with the materials, affording the potential to control tissue localization and immune responses toward implanted materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE for P30 The purpose of The Ohio State University Vision Sciences Research Core Program (OSU-VSRCP) is to enhance the environment for NEI-funded PIs and other vision science faculty who represent five Colleges: Medicine, Optometry, Veterinary Medicine, Engineering and Arts & Sciences. Three cores are proposed based on a survey of 61 scientists: Core A-Structural and Functional Assessments, Core B-Biostatistics, Bioinformatics and Genetic Analysis, and Core C-Image Analysis and Data Science. The institutional commitment (i.e., support the Program Director includes successful recruitment of vision scientists, space for a new confocal microscope purchase for Core A, and space in the 2023 Interdisciplinary Research Facility) supports our common goal to prevent blindness, restore vision and develop cures for eye diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative For Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD, the 4th cause of death in the USA) defined by irreversible airflow, there is emerging evidence that suggests that variation in airway tree structure is common in the general population and is a major contributor to unexplained COPD risk. The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding airway tree structure subtypes from lung CT scans would advance our knowledge of disease susceptibility and improve personalized therapies, prognosis, and identify an underlying genetic basis to COPD risk. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for ultimately protecting health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More efficient hematopoietic progenitor cell (HPC) generation from cultured induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) would support translational research and cell therapies. I used penalized regression modeling of human genetic data, and iPSC cell models, to determine that the Tropomyosin 1 gene normally constrains in vitro HPC production. In this grant, I will determine mechanisms by which Tropomyosin 1 constrains HPC development, and define other genetic mechanisms that could be manipulated to augment in vitro HPC yield.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Our two Multiple Sclerosis (MS) Centers have been at the forefront of deploying telehealth to improve access to outpatient MS care, and, while we have demonstrated both feasibility and high satisfaction at the time of service, there are broader knowledge gaps regarding its impact on clinical outcomes and on the high costs (>$48 billion) of and access barriers to MS care. We propose a 2-year 2-Center randomized pilot trial to determine whether telehealth for MS care in newly diagnosed patients can maintain clinical outcomes, improve satisfaction, and reduce costs of care relative to in-clinic visits. We will also perform detailed qualitative analyses to understand patient and care team experiences, preferences, concerns, and satisfaction regarding telehealth care to identify facilitators and barriers to widespread implementation of telehealth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  We propose to develop a novel theoretical framework using mathematical modelling, all-atom simulation and experimental data (in-vitro and in-vivo) to understand sequence-conformation-function relation in disordered proteins. Our work is of biomedical relevance due to its importance in understanding fundamental principles that biology relies on to alter conformation of Intrinsically Disordered Proteins that constitute a large fraction of human proteome and perform great many vital biological functions. Strategies learnt from the work will help design new sequences to control function of these proteins with potential for therapeutic application.

These skills will equip Dr Adedeji to establish a research career in HIV clinical pharmacology and pharmacogenomics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Overall Component This P30 Core Grant provides essential infrastructure and expertise for the investigators of the Visual Sciences Research Center at Case Western Reserve University who study major inherited and acquired blinding diseases such age-related macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, Leber’s congenital amaurosis, Stargardt’s disease, Fuchs dystrophy, and glaucoma. Through its critical functions, this grant will continue to enhance the ability of vision researchers to decipher the mechanisms of many common blinding diseases and develop new therapies for their treatments. The grant will also facilitate collaborations among vision researchers and will help bring new investigators to vision field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood cancer patients have an increased risk of developing heart failure because of chemotherapy and radiation treatments. As a result, many survivors of childhood cancer receive lifetime screening with echocardiograms (ultrasound of the heart) to monitor their long-term heart function. The proposed project would apply new computer artificial intelligence-based methods to improve the ability of echocardiograms to detect earlier heart disease in these high-risk survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A promise of precision medicine is that individual genome sequence data will enable the determination of disease risk and effective treatments, however unravelling contributions of genetic variation to disease remains one of the greatest challenges in genomics. By combining DNA editing with single-cell transcriptomics, we will experimentally decipher regulatory networks for a whole human chromosome and engineer hundreds of genetic variants to uncover their gene regulatory effects. This data will be used to train machine learning models to predict regulatory interactions throughout the genome and across cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The UK CTSA program hub is uniquely positioned in the National CTSA Consortium to foster novel technologies, team science, clinical trial start-up and cutting-edge translational research across the lifespan. Our UK CTSA hub has a significant presence on the national stage, and our focus on the Central Appalachian community, a rural region with many of the highest priorities (i.e., cardiovascular, neuroscience, cancer, obesity/diabetes) of health disparities in the nation and an epicenter for the opioid and substance abuse epidemic, distinguishes our mission and activities. The programs in this proposal will ultimately elevate the health and quality of life for people of this region and provide a national model for rural, underserved populations. Project Narrative Page 277

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Enspectra Health, Inc. is continuing its mission to increasingly move skin cancer detection earlier where the healthcare cost and burden to patients is minimal. In this project, we aim to pair the analytic power of the data generated by our novel, noninvasive cellular imaging technology (VIO) with deep learning algorithms to identify problematic precancers in patients before they progress to malignancy. By far, the greatest innovation of this project will be accomplishing our aims without the need of even a single biopsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood cancer survivors are at risk for adverse late health effects from their treatment, but many disengage from follow-up care during the transition from pediatric to adult-oriented health care. The proposed randomized trial will evaluate a novel digital self-management and peer mentoring intervention designed to improve self- management behaviors, enhance health-related quality of life, and increase adherence to guideline-concordant care among adolescent and young adult survivors. Results will advance clinical practice to reduce the long-term burden among this vulnerable group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to identify cognitive strategies and brain mechanisms that humans use to learn about their environment and update the decision-making strategies. Since many neurological disorders impact decision-making, understanding the (diversity of) strategies humans apply to relate their decision-making process to their environment and how these strategies are enacted by the brain is the first step to identifying mechanisms of dysfunction and producing translational treatments and diagnostics. By applying an interdisciplinary approach of computational modeling, behavioral experiments, and human brain recordings, this work can improve our understanding of flexible decision-making, linking behavior to neural activity in a systematic way that sets the groundwork for future endeavors into human cognition and deficits in it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The premise of the present proposal is that intrauterine inflammatory processes disrupt kidney development and that environmental chemicals also impair renal this growth during gestation and postnatal development via oxidant stress. We further interrogate this hypothesis by examining phthalates, bisphenols, glyphosate and organophosphate pesticides as modifiable risks. We will test these hypotheses in the New York University Children's Health and Environment Study, one of the participating cohorts in the NIH Environmental Influences and Child Health Outcomes Program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Annually, about 50,000,000 doses of synthetic gadolinium imaging contrast agents are injected into patients worldwide when getting an MRI scan. While these agents are extremely safe, they have the potential for adverse effects in some patient populations, which may accumulate when a procedure is repeated. We propose to develop the use of sugar (D-glucose) as a biodegradable contrast agent for imaging tumor physiology with MRI; we will first develop and translate this approach for brain cancer, after which the technology can be adjusted for use in other cancers and other disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinal cord injury (SCI) causes major neurological impairments including long-term sensorimotor deficits and posttraumatic neuropathic pain, with no effective treatment. The aim of our research is to understand the cellular and molecular mechanisms responsible for post-injury neuroinflammation in order to allow future development of novel therapies. In particularly we will target the signaling pathway of the voltage-gated proton channel Hv1, one of major ion channels expressed in resting microglia of the central nervous system, in order to decrease damage and increase functional recovery after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the fundamental circuit interactions between excitatory and inhibitory neurons underlying neural coding within the mouse olfactory bulb, the first region of the mammalian brain where peripheral olfactory sensory input is processed. Neural coding within the relatively compact architecture of the olfactory bulb supports perception of extremely complex and varied environmental stimuli, making the olfactory bulb a preeminent model for studying general principles of brain function. Knowledge gained through this project about how specific inhibitory interneuron classes influence excitatory neuron output from the olfactory bulb may further provide key insight into the widespread disruption of olfactory perception observed in several neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Misfolding and aggregation of specific proteins into fibrillar aggregates is the pathological hallmark of many diseases, but the precise relationship between molecular structure of aggregates and their heterogeneities and disease pathology is yet to be fully understood. This project aims to develop a set of experimental approaches using nanoscale infrared spectroscopy and confocal infrared imaging to investigate the heterogeneities of secondary structure in amyloid aggregates and explore their correlation with disease progression. The primary focus of this approach will be to study amyloid aggregates in Alzheimer’s disease, and the methods developed herein will be extended to study other amyloid diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Alterations in the growth and differentiation of epidermal stem and progenitor cells can lead to a variety of skin disorders including non-melanoma skin cancers as well as ichthyosis. Thus a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms that regulate epidermal growth and differentiation is necessary to understand the progression to disease. This proposal seeks to characterize the mechanisms of epidermal self-renewal and differentiation through the regulation of transcription elongation.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Dementia remains a leading cause of mortality and morbidity worldwide and high levels of salt in the diet have emerged as a factor that increases the risk of developing cognitive impairment. The present application seeks to find out how a diet rich in salt acts on brain vessels and leads to accumulation in the brain of the protein tau, a major culprit in Alzheimer’s disease. The proposed studies open the way to new approaches to protect the brain from the harmful effects of excessive dietary salt.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance    This research advances understanding of optic cup, stalk and disc outgrowth and  morphogenesis, which can be abnormal in congenital anophthalmia, microphthalmia, coloboma,  pediatric glaucoma, optic neuritis, or optic nerve hypoplasia. This study creates new transgenic  and mutant mouse models and will provide novel insights into formation and maintenance of the  optic disc and nerve, overt goals of the NEI.  This research will also provide fundamental  information relevant for adult onset glaucoma.  This project addresses several objectives  recommended by the Retinal Diseases Panel which are to “Identify and characterize genes  responsible for optic nerve disease” and “Develop transgenic and other animal models of optic  nerve disease”.  In a broader context, our experiments also contribute new information about  the Pax2 transcription factor whose mutations also impact brain, kidney and inner ear  development and homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spondyloarthritis is a complex disease with a multitude of manifestations, spanning the joint, skin, gut, and eye. Given the inherent immune restrictions of the eye, we theorize that sampling the human eye during periods of ocular inflammation will enrich for pathogenic immune cells in spondyloarthritis, specifically T cells. We propose to use single-cell RNA sequencing to identify putative pathogenic T cells in the human eye and to assess whether dysregulation of these T cells track with disease activity in other anatomic sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcoholic hepatitis is a life-threatening complication of alcoholic liver disease, and it is increasing in frequency. It is widely believed that alcoholic hepatitis results largely from damage to hepatocytes, but recent work suggests that alterations in bile duct cells (cholangiocytes) also contribute to the development of this disease. This project will determine whether and how white blood cells affect cholangiocytes in alcoholic hepatitis, which may lead to identification of new targets for therapy.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: CLC channels are compelling targets for drug development, yet CLC pharmacology is undeveloped. The CLC-Ka inhibitors developed in this project will advance biomedicine by providing novel tools to investigate the function of CLC-Ka in the kidney and to advance new kidney therapies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims elucidate the role neutrophilsnplay in the homeostatic regulation of the CNS. Specifically, determining how neutrophils modulate neuronal function and ultimately an organism behavioral output, will greatly inform our understanding of their role in injury and neurodegeneration. The results of this project will not only define a new role for neutrophils, it will also define the meninges as a non-medullary source of these cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Fungal diseases in the U.S. have been increasing in incidence and geographic distribution, with disproportionate effects in communities with high socioeconomic vulnerability. While many fungal pathogens are thought to be climate sensitive, a poor understanding of fungal disease epidemiology coupled with limited surveillance data on fungal infections has prevented a mechanistic and quantitative understanding of the role of climate variability and extreme events on fungal disease incidence. This project will use a massive electronic health record and infectious disease surveillance database to characterize relationships between climate conditions and incidence of major fungal diseases across the U.S., quantify the historical and projected effects of anthropogenic climate change on incidence rates, and examine the role of social disadvantage in exacerbating future impacts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Warning signs signal immediate risk for suicidal behavior and their assessment is of critical importance in acute care settings including emergency departments and crisis lines. This innovative 4-year study analyzes adult hospital patients’ stories of their suicide attempts in their own words and through systematic review of the hours leading up to the attempt. The project is designed to discover warning signs that have been overlooked, to clarify which warning signs confer especially high risk, and to explore the language patients use to describe warning signs, results that are critical to improve risk assessment in acute care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The recent emergence of type 2 diabetes (T2D) among youth has significant public health implications as young people with T2D are likely to manifest debilitating complications of diabetes during what should be the most active and productive years of their lives. There is an urgent need to need to identify children at risk for T2D and intervene appropriately earlier in the pre-clinical disease course. Our study seek to extend the longitudinal follow- up of the Healthy Start (HS) Cohort, a maternal-offspring dyad study that enrolled 1410 pregnant women and conducted detailed characterization of mothers during pregnancy, of offspring through age ~7 years (R01DK076648), and ongoing at ages 8-10 years (through the Environmental Influences on Child Health Outcomes –ECHO- Consortium, UH3OD023248). This in depth characterization coupled with the proposed follow-up (ages ~10-15) will improve our understanding of early life course pathways influencing pubertal metabolic homeostasis. This foundational knowledge on youth-onset T2D pathophysiology is needed to inform potential prevention approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Throughout their lives, children are exposed to many different chemicals but our understanding of the effects of these mixtures on child health is limited. Our research is relevant to public health: it will inform prevention efforts and communication of risks by creating a deeper understanding of how exposure to chemical mixtures affects oxidative stress and cognition in children and how well the body's antioxidant defenses are able to counteract these effects. Our work is also relevant to the mission of the NIEHS: it will contribute fundamental knowledge on environmental influences on disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project description  Sterols are critical for the structure of eukaryotic cells and serve as important signaling molecules. Some bacteria also engage with these lipids, but the molecular mechanisms of these engagements are not known. Inspired by our recent discovery of bacterial proteins that transport sterols, we seek to uncover the molecular determinants of sterol recognition and transport in other bacteria, including pathogens and the gut microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed research is relevant to human health because preemptive clinical pharmacogenetic testing may improve the personalization of drug therapy which should improve patient outcomes. Better understanding of the effectiveness and feasibility of preemptive clinical pharmacogenetic testing will inform when and how this innovative healthcare technology is implemented into clinical care. To ensure equitable dissemination in all patient populations, such data is also needed in racial minorities and other traditionally underserved populations. The combined proposed research are relevant to the parts of the NIH's mission pertaining to protecting and improving health and developing scientific human resources that will ensure the Nation's capability to prevent and treat disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mouse models are a cornerstone of basic research and the development of therapeutic interventions. The NIH Mutant Mouse Resource & Research Centers (MMRRC) are a group of four repositories (University of California, University of Missouri, University of North Carolina, and The Jackson Laboratories) that collectively curate and distribute mouse strains. The Informatics, Coordination and Service Center (ICSC) funded under this opportunity provides organizational leadership, quality management, and informatics services for the MMRRC to enable cryopreservation, cataloging, and distribution of almost 60,000 mouse strains, embryonic stem cell lines, plasmid vectors, and antibody-producing hybridoma to the research community for the advancement of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human genome contains roughly 25 thousand genes and over 1 million regions that are implicated in determining the level, timing, and place of expression of these genes. In spite of substantial effort, our understanding of the architecture of these regulatory regions and how they communicate and regulate gene expression is far from complete. In this project, we will comprehensively characterize these regulatory regions from two human chromosomes and study their function at multiple levels to better understand the control of gene expression in normal and disease conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed study is highly relevant to public health because it examines the extent to which health disparity populations have access to the standard of care for early psychosis, coordinated specialty care programs, and whether access to services vary based on neighborhood-level characteristics. Due to the widespread dissemination of coordinated specialty care programs throughout the US, the examination of whether youth and families have equitable access to such services is the first step. Given the documented disparities in service utilization and difficulties experienced along the pathways to coordinated specialty care, the present study is critical to understanding these inequities, and aligns with NIMH strategic goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the past 5 years, opioid overdose mortality rates increased 114% among Black, 97% among Latinx, and 32% among White populations in the United States. Naloxone is an evidence-based intervention to prevent opioid overdose deaths, yet access to this lifesaving intervention is insufficient and inequitable. We will contribute directly to the improvement of minority health and the reduction of health inequities by conducting a randomized controlled trial to test the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the systems analysis and improvement approach to increase and improve equitable naloxone distribution in syringe service programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The centriole-cilium complex is a conserved structure that organizes hundreds of proteins for cell signaling and motility, and misregulation of this complex is linked to a wide range of human diseases and syndromes. The defining features of this complex are compound microtubules, which are a unique arrangement of microtubules linked together. This proposal will determine how compound microtubules are formed, with the goal of improving our understanding of how these important cellular structures are organized to create a unique hub of signaling and function within the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Music therapy has become a standard palliative care service in many pediatric and adult hospitals; however, a majority of music therapy research has focused on the use of music to improve psychosocial dimensions of health, without considering biological dimensions. This study builds on prior work examining the psychosocial mechanisms of action underlying an Active Music Engagement (AME) intervention, designed to help manage emotional distress and improve positive health outcomes in young children with cancer and parents, by examining its effects on biomarkers of stress and immune function. Findings will povide a more holistic understanding about how active music interventions work to mitigate cancer-related stress and its potential to improve immune function, with direct implications for the evidence-based use of music to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid-induced respiratory depression is a life-threatening concern that is preventable in patients undergoing surgery yet continues to be a major contributor to costly morbidity, mortality, length of hospital stay, and malpractice claims. NeurOptics is developing a pupillometry-based easy to use, bedside tool to predict postoperative respiratory depression in children in real-time. The perioperative use of this innovative and impactful technology will help clinicians to prevent respiratory depression, improve safety surgical pain management with opioids while reducing perioperative cost of care with optimal hospital resource utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a devastating disease carrying high morbidity and mortality due to fatal dissection and rupture, yet there have been no proven pharmaceutical treatments for AAA prevention and treatment. The proposed studies will address a new mechanism underlying AAA pathogenesis, involving the insufficient ubiquitin proteasome system (UPS) performance-mediated proteotoxicity governed by a novel signal cascade comprising a druggable upstream modulator (PDE10A) and a downstream effector (MYOCD) of gene transcription. Successful completion of the aims will inform therapeutic targeting strategies to combat AAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Our studies have significant translational impact because lineage plasticity is of central importance for understanding the molecular basis for resistance of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) to anti-androgen therapy. Such plasticity is likely to be responsible for the diverse phenotypic spectrum of CRPC, and in particular for the emergence of neuroendocrine differentiation, which is highly aggressive and lacks effective treatments. Our proposed analyses should identify novel targets for therapy as well as candidate drugs that inhibit lineage plasticity, which may ultimately lead to new therapeutic options for lethal metastatic prostate cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Genomic Risk Assessment Coordinating center for eMERGE (GRACE) will create infrastructure to implement and evaluate genomic risk assessments for common, complex diseases such as heart disease, and return these assessments to participants. GRACE will organize collaboration among eMERGE investigators, streamline data collection, and utilize cloud computing to enable large scale analyses of genomic data. GRACE will support the recruitment and genotyping of a 20,000 person cohort to determine the clinical impact of delivering genomic risk assessments, measure the uptake of risk reduction recommendations, and assess changes to clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thousands of ~1-2 µm-long membrane extensions protrude from the top of each intestinal epithelial enterocyte to form the microvillus brush border, which increases the capacity of the epithelium to house digestive enzymes, transporters, and host defense molecules. Despite the importance of this host-environment interface to normal intestinal physiology, very few studies have addressed the biological pathways that regulate this structure and whether it contributes to intestinal pathologies where microvillus structure is disrupted, such as Crohn’s disease. The proposed studies will use mouse models, primary intestinal epithelial cell cultures, and human biopsy samples to address this knowledge gap, with the long-term goal of providing guidance on the design of therapeutics to restore epithelial function and promote mucosal healing in Crohn’s disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH (PROJECT NARRATIVE) OVERALL The Center for Systems Neurogenetics of Addiction (CSNA) seeks to identify the biological relationships among the stages and patterns of cocaine addiction and behaviors that predict drug abuse. To uncover these relationships, we will make use of advanced mouse genetic tools that allow us to precisely and efficiently identify the genes related to addiction, and computational methods that enable holistic study of genes, biological molecules and behaviors. We will discover addiction-related genes, but we will also generate enabling resources and services for the addiction research community to unravel the complexity of addiction risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enterovirus D68 (EV-D68) has been implicated in severe respiratory illness and acute flaccid myelitis (AFM), a polio-like illness causing paralysis in previously healthy children. There are no specific treatments for AFM, most children are left with residual deficits, and it is currently unknown how EV-D68 targets the central nervous system. The goal of this proposal is to identify how EV-D68 mediates cellular damage in the human spinal cord by using an innovative human spinal cord organoid model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Measures of subclinical atherosclerosis assessed by CT provide predictive information for risk of coronary events independent of traditional cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors. This study will address critical gaps in current scientific knowledge on the presence/absence and extent of coronary artery calcium (CAC), and plaque volume, density, and distribution in diverse US Hispanic/Latino heritage groups, and will examine relationships with sociocultural characteristics, lifestyle factors, traditional CVD risk factors, and epigenomic patterns. Findings from this study will help identify novel preventive targets and inform development of precision prevention/ treatment strategies that may benefit all racial/ethnic groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our research concerns fundamental questions about the basic mechanisms responsible for cell polarity (the development of asymmetric cell behaviors along one or more axes) in eukaryotic cells, and how such polarity is regulated. Cell polarity enables cell migration and directed cell growth, both of which are critical to organismal development. Dysregulated cell migration and cell shape contribute to various aspects of disease including metastatic malignancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals living in rural settings, particularly medically underserved areas, are at increased risk for cancer and other chronic diseases; factors such as socioeconomic disadvantage, geographical distances/barriers, social and cultural issues, and limited access to healthcare, healthy foods, and/or physical activity opportunities contribute to this health inequity. Civic engagement for built environment change (CEBEC) interventions hold promise in catalyzing local built environment and policy changes to support healthy eating and active living in rural areas. The Change Club is a resident-led CEBEC strategy that will be implemented by extension educators and co-led by residents in eight medically underserved rural communities; it will provide an innovative model for addressing rural health equity in the intervention communities as well as the potential for broad public health impact in other underserved rural areas through national dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) caused 10 million new cases of active tuberculosis (TB) disease and 1.5 million deaths, in 2019, making TB the leading cause of death in the world by a single infectious agent. The long treatment duration, spectrum of clinical outcomes, high disease relapse, and emergence of drug resistance are all complications of TB treatment attributable to the intrinsic heterogeneity of the disease. Strategies developed in this project will accelerate development of multidrug regimen that will be efficacious against heterogeneous drug tolerant subpopulations of Mtb, achieving faster clearance and lowering the likelihood for evolution of resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The CoBRE Center for Redox Biology and Cardiovascular Disease will provide a unique training and research environment for junior investigators to receive mentorship and guidance, while increasing their competitiveness for major research funding through national grant program opportunities. The Center will advance new insights and understanding of redox biology control of heart and vascular disease processes that may lead to new and better ways to detect or treat cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE From a sample of 272 male-female couples (544 individuals, 272 men and 272 women) recruited from rural KaZulu-Natal, South Africa, couples will be randomized to receive either individual a package of dyadic counseling and testing (intervention arm) or an attention matched control. The research examines the impact of a package of dyadic counseling and testing on viral suppression and engagement in HIV care among sero- discordant and concordant positive male-female couples in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease, it remains the leading cause of death in the US. In many cases the underlying cause is atherosclerosis of cardiac and cerebral arteries. We will test the ability of insulin-like growth factor-1 and a novel senolytic drug, ABT263, to prevent progression and worsening of atherosclerosis in a large animal model, and also use mouse models to understand underlying mechanisms and develop new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a life-threatening condition in adults with high mortality rate (80%) if rupture occurs but lacking pharmacological treatment. Vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) loss is a characteristic feature of AAA. The proposed research will determine the mechanisms by which VSMC ferroptosis contributes to AAA pathogenesis and lead to new therapeutic strategies for treating AAA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The plasma membrane calcium ATPase 2 (PMCA2) is a calcium pump found on the apical membrane of mammary epithelial cells that transports 60%-70% of milk calcium from within these cells into the alveolar lumen. We have found that PMCA2 expression is rapidly downregulated by milk stasis after weaning and that it is re-expressed in ErbB2/HER2-positive breast cancers. This renewal application seeks to continue our studies of PMCA2 during mammary gland involution and in breast cancer by: 1) examining how the decline of PMCA2 and resulting increase of intracellular calcium triggers new lysosome formation, STAT3 activation and cell death during early involution; and 2) examining how interactions between PMCA2, Erbin and NHERF1 form as a result of disturbed cell polarity to promote ErbB2 signaling, malignant transformation and resistance to trastuzumab.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative For dentin repair or regeneration, it is important to have the timely appearance of blood vessels. Therefore, tissue-engineering strategies to regenerate the dentin-pulp complex require establishment of vasculature to deliver oxygen, nutrients, hormones, immune cells, minerals and also help in clearing cellular debris and metabolic waste products during the inflammatory and regenerative phases of healing. The goal of this project is demonstrate that dentin matrix protein 1 is involved in vasculogenesis. Understanding the function of DMP1 in the phenotypic transformation of dental pulp stem cells to endothelial cells will help in regenerating vascularized tissues such as the dental pulp.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement Alzheimer's disease (AD) is one of the leading causes of death in the U.S. and affects approximately 20% of adults in their sixties and 50% over 85 years, creating a heavy burden on the society as well as patients and their families. Given the long prodromal stage of the disease, development of non-invasive and cost-effective methods to detect AD pathologies during the early stage of AD will be crucial for prevention and intervention of AD as well as recruitment of study participants for drug development trials. Completion of the project will markedly improve the understanding of the mechanisms linking AD pathologies to cognitive impairment in the earliest stage of the disease, which will help early detection and development of effective prevention and intervention for individuals at high-risk for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The mitochondrial fatty acid synthesis (mtFAS) pathway is a major rheostat of mitochondrial function, but the pathway is poorly defined in mammals and almost nothing is known about its regulation. Our preliminary data in yeast and cultured cells support a model in which mtFAS activity responds to changes in nutrient availability in the mitochondria, but many questions remain, including which fuels drive mtFAS, and how the pathway acts to direct metabolism in tissues with disparate mitochondrial functions. The experiments outlined in this proposal will mechanistically characterize the basic biology of mtFAS pathway function and regulation in mammalian systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The neurology community has seen extraordinary successes and tremendous breakthroughs in the treatment of neurological disorders. Translating these advances into improved clinical care for patients requires a cadre of specialty-trained clinician neuroscientists who are to be responsive to the increasing pace of scientific discoveries, as well as to the emerging suite of approaches and techniques. This program will train the next generation of leaders in the experimental therapeutics of neurological disease, in order to accelerate therapeutic development and improve access to emerging breakthroughs for all patients and families who may benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Research Narrative We are trying to learn the fundamental principles which govern how different bacteria in a population respond to changes in their environment, such as treatment with an antibiotic. Rather than a population in which all bacteria are prepared for any environmental change, we hypothesize that each individual in the population is prepared for certain environments - and that their preparation changes randomly over time depending on the expression of their genes. Combining cutting-edge experimental and computer modeling techniques, our goal is to demonstrate that this phenomenon exists within individual bacteria, and show how it impacts the population as a whole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Over 400,000 individuals in the United States have Down syndrome (DS) and are living with the significant challenges of cognitive and visual deficits, both of which pose serious threats to the maximum potential of these individuals. Improving visual health remains the primary mission of the National Eye Institute, and becomes particularly critical when the affected individuals cannot advocate for themselves, such as is the case for persons with DS. This proposal aims to test new objective spectacle prescribing strategies to provide improvements in visual quality for individuals with DS which is ultimately anticipated to improve their performance of visually demanding activities of daily living and foster greater independence.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extracorporeal circulation through a membrane oxygenator (ECMO) is used for severe heart and lung failure support worldwide, despite a high incidence of bleeding caused by systemic anticoagulation. Without adequate systemic anticoagulation components of the ECMO circuit are prone to clotting putting at risk patients. This research will refine our nitric oxide (NO) based nonthrombogenic surface which can eliminate systemic anticoagulation and set the stage for commercial development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  Disruption of genomic regulation is accompanied by striking functional changes across cell types and species. However, how mobile genetic elements are regulated throughout life, across biological sexes, and how they influence physiology in response to external or internal cues, remains largely unknown. By leveraging big data and state-of-the-art experimental approaches on vertebrate models including mouse and the emerging African turquoise killifish, the proposed research program will advance our understanding of mobile genetic element control in healthy somatic cells, and shed light on how these elements can influence vertebrate health and disease. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Cells employ multiple strategies, including transcriptional and posttranscriptional regulation events, to ensure that the correct protein is made at the right time and place. Failure to do so could result in drastic consequences such as cancer and cell death. This proposal addresses the mechanisms by which protein synthesis is regulated to maintain control over gene expression, which in turn could be used to develop therapeutics aimed at dealing with defects in the translation apparatus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Mob4 is a gene recently linked to Alzheimer’s Disease, whose function is yet to be determined. Using Drosophila genetics, biochemistry and imaging, we will determine the molecular function of Mob4 and its interacting proteins in neurons and in long-term memory formation. A mechanistic understanding of Mob4 function will provide possible therapeutic treatment strategies for Alzheimer’s disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stem cell-based treatments offer unprecedented hope to treat human neurological disorders. Training of junior scientists having expertise in stem cell biology and neuroscience, together with a comprehensive understanding of industry, regulatory clinical and statistical knowledge, is essential to realization of this vision. We have implemented these goals within our NIH Training Program in Stem Cell Translational Medicine for Neurological Disorders, now in its 9th year, to train predoctoral students in integrated and translational approaches to stem cell biology, neuroscience and human neurological disease and propose to renew and further strengthen this successful training program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Intersectional stigma remains a persistent barrier to ending the HIV epidemic in the US and more broadly, the HIV pandemic and is a stated research priority of the NIH including through publications and notice of special interest. While we know that intersectional stigmas drive disparities in health, but there remains limited understanding of optimal measurement to assess effects on health outcomes and the impact of interventions. This proposed study aims to address these gaps by optimizing measurement of intersectional stigma among sexual and gender minorities, mechanisms driving health inequities, and informing interventions to mitigate disparities.

PHR: Narrative The use of the common marmoset (Callithrix jacchus) in biomedical research has increased by an unprecedented extent over the past five years, emerging as a critical biomedical model system in a variety of study disciplines. Increased demand for marmosets in scientific research studies has perhaps been most acute in neuroscience, where the need to study cognition, behavior, and mental illness in primate models has grown in part in part due to recognition of inherent limitations of rodent models in translational studies of human physiology and disease. The Southwest National Primate Research Center (SNPRC) and the Wisconsin National Primate Research Center (WNPRC) propose a major collaborative effort to dramatically increase the availability of healthy common marmosets for national neuroscience research projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Elucidating the biochemical and conformational changes that initiate cervical ripening will provide a critical step for early detection and treatment of preterm birth, which is the leading cause of infant morbidity and mortality. Raman spectroscopy is a non-invasive, label-free, and highly specific approach for probing tissue biochemistry, which can be implemented in vivo using a fiber optic probe. This proposal will develop multimodal in vivo Raman spectroscopy along with complementary ex vivo imaging techniques to gain in-depth, quantitative information regarding changes in extracellular matrix organization, lipid and water content, and vascularity in order to understand how these components are altered in mouse models of premature cervical remodeling and preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases (ARSs) are a family of enzymes that are essential for the production of cellular proteins. To date, genes encoding ARSs have been implicated in many human diseases; however, the process by which these genes cause specific diseases is still unknown. Here, we aim to define how ARS genes cause human disease toward developing effective therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deaths attributed to concomitant opioid and stimulant polysubstance use are increasing at an alarming rate. There is a critical need to advance both the preclinical behavioral procedures and the brain molecular interrogations to identify and characterize how polysubstance use synergizes to drive this public health crisis. This application proposes preclinical research focused on fentanyl and methamphetamine drug-vs.-food choice procedures in rats combined with single nuclei RNA sequencing of distinct brain regions to uncover the root brain molecular mechanisms that emerge over the course of polysubstance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the United States and worldwide, underscoring the critical need to identify new therapeutic targets for this disease. This project seeks to define the fundamental mechanisms by which the XRN1 exoribonuclease, an enzyme that functions to degrade cellular RNA, regulates the survival of NSCLC cells and the anti-tumor immune response to NSCLC tumors. The proposed research will determine whether targeting XRN1 may represent a unique and broadly applicable treatment strategy for patients with NSCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative To end the HIV epidemic in the US and globally, behavioral interventions are needed for those at highest risk for HIV nonadherence and subsequent HIV transmission, including low-income, racial/ethnic minority individuals with active substance use (SU). Efforts to integrate HIV, SU, and primary care services in resource- limited settings globally must allocate resources efficiently. Implementing a peer-delivered, stepped care intervention for HIV medication adherence and SU may be a sustainable and effective way to improve HIV treatment outcomes and reduce SU in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Out of the 131,000,000 live births every year in the world, 25% of infants of single pregnancies and 50% of infants of multiple pregnancies have some degree of skull deformity at birth that, if not diagnosed early and treated effectively, can impact brain development, cognition, and motor function. This project will be the f irst systematic in-vivo study of joint healthy cranial and brain development—before and after birth—that will address our current limited knowledge of how the cranium and brain grow and co -develop; the normative models generated here will serve as clinical resources for matched comparisons in individual children with suspected disorders that involve abnormal cranial shapes. Additionally, precise in-vivo quantitative imaging methods for assessing joint cranial and brain shape in infants will be developed in this project and will serve as invaluable tools for physicians to better assess, diagnose, and plan treatment for infant cranial deformities in the future.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  COVID-19 is an ongoing global pandemic affecting many millions of people around the world. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. This partnership between Appa Health and the University of Washington will conduct a randomized controlled trial on the effectiveness and costs of a near-peer mentoring program coupled with videos on cognitive-behavioral therapy skills (Full Appa) as compared to videos alone (Appa Light) and a wait list control group. The study will include a pilot trial to optimize study procedures followed by a fully-powered effectiveness trial, and will collect experience and outcome data on adolescents over 12 weeks of the program. The results of this study will inform marketing and commercialization of Full Appa and possible development of Appa Light as a new product version.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with sleep apnea are at increased risk of developing cardiovascular disease – with women at potentially greater risk than men. Contributing mechanisms are not well understood, but may be related to how women respond to low oxygen and, given over 70% of patients with sleep apnea are obese, the impact of obesity. The proposed project seeks to increase our understanding of mechanisms that may contribute to sex differences in the cardiovascular response to low oxygen with the hope that this knowledge will improve the efficacy of current therapies and support the discovery of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because more than 1.5 million older adults undergo emergency intra-abdominal surgery and more than 25% develop delirium post-operatively. Interventions that can enhance the recovery of these patients can lead to a decrease in long-term disability and dependence of these patients. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission to develop new knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens associated with human disability.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to provide highly focused and advanced training in the development, function and dysfunction of the mammalian cerebral cortex at Yale University. Twenty-seven (27) faculty from eleven (11) basic and clinical departments at both Yale School of Medicine and Yale College are mentors in this multidisciplinary program for predoctoral trainees. Training includes focused coursework, aggressive mentorship through advisory committees, intensive research apprenticeship, structured seminar programs, career skills development, extensive critical evaluation of trainees and the training program, and opportunities for laboratory and departmental presentations of research progress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Type III-A CRISPR-Cas systems are RNA-protein complexes used by prokaryotes for adaptive immunity to foreign nucleic acids. A robust understanding of the structures and nucleic acid interference mechanisms of Type III-A CRISPR-Cas will aid in understanding their role in mobile genetic element transfer among bacteria, a common mode of spreading antibiotic resistance genes and facilitate new biotechnologies. We propose integrated biochemistry and biophysics experiments to elucidate the structure and mechanism of Type III-A CRISPR-Cas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of cancer in the United States and across the globe is substantial with an estimated number of cancer cases and deaths in the US in 2019 of 1,762,450 and 606,880 individuals respectively. At the same time cancer is at the vanguard in the development of “precision” approaches using a myriad of advances from the laboratory to advance prevention, screening, diagnosis, treatment, and survivorship strategies and disseminate them broadly and equitably, and this requires trained scientists, especially physician-scientists, to drive the advances in biologically-driven, evidence-based care. The aim of this research training program is to recruit and prepare highly qualified physicians from diverse backgrounds for a research-intensive career in medical or gynecological oncology by developing research skills in cancer biology, diagnosis, prevention, therapy, and outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: TRAINING IN CANCER BIOLOGY AND TRANSPLANTATION

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Medical devices are common in healthcare, but often lead to morbidity in the form of device-associated thrombosis. Current strategies to prevent and treat device associated thrombosis are often ineffective and universally cause bleeding. There is an unmet need to develop safer and more effective therapies for device- associated thrombosis. Herein we will characterize novel druggable molecular interactions between the blood microenvironment and the surface of medical devices that contribute to inflammation and increased blood coagulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative:  Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH) survivors have long term cognitive deficits and memory impairment in their productive years with major responsibilities with respect to work and family. Preliminary data suggests that Deferiprone could improve cognitive outcome in these subjects. The tools include generic estimation and inference methods that can address many practical problems raised in the integrative analysis, as well as a powerful computational tools to handle the block missing data. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE When ovarian cancer is diagnosed at an early stage, combination surgery and chemotherapy can cure 90% of women with disease contained in the ovary (stage I) and 70% with disease limited to the pelvis (stage II), but when disease has spread further, cure slips to 20% or less. Our group has shown that annual measurement of CA125 followed by ultrasound, and surgery, if indicated, can detect early stage (I, II) disease in 71% of patients with no more than two-three operations for each case detected, but a multi-marker algorithm is likely to be required to impact mortality. Our Clinical Validation Center will continue to collaborate and to provide specimens to EDRN BCCs and test whether annual measurement of four blood tests detects early stage cases in >70% of cases with an acceptable number of benign ovarian lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Methods and Logic in Molecular Biology (MLMB) Training Program at Princeton University is a diverse and inclusive program that trains graduate students to become leaders in biomedical research, teaching, and related life science fields. We use a customized mentoring program that provides MLMB trainees with advanced skills in multi-disciplinary research, including critical thinking, generation of hypotheses, experimental design, data analysis and interpretation, and science communication, in conjunction with skills in leadership and mentoring. Research projects directed by MLMB program faculty train Ph.D. candidates in diverse areas related to human health, including reproduction and development, infectious disease, cancer, and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson's disease (PD) symptoms of postural instability and gait disorder (PIGD) cause profound disability and are inadequately treated by current therapies. This project uses new brain-imaging and computer-modeling techniques to comprehensively investigate how targeting deep brain stimulation (DBS) at specific path- ways on a patient-specific basis can effectively treat the disabling symptoms of PIGD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioma/glioblastoma is a family of malignant brain tumors that affects about 3 out of 100,000 people around the world every year and is barely treatable. The underlying cause of gliomas is still under investigation, but epigenetic changes are considered very important. This proposal will study how dysregulation of post- transcriptional modifications on small non-coding RNAs contributes to aberrant gene expression in gliomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human spinal cord injury (SCI) currently has no effective treatment, and thus any new treatments would have a significant impact on public health. In the United States, there are more than 12,000 new cases of SCI each year. While many groups have focused on therapies for subacute SCI, chronic SCI remains an unmet need, with an estimated 250,000 people currently living with chronic SCI in the US. Our long-term goal is to bring a successful cell transplantation therapy from bench to bedside for chronic SCI via a next-generation 3D printing approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Preeclampsia is a major medical disorder occurring during pregnancy and brings about more than 50,000 maternal deaths worldwide, with an estimated 45,000 death is in US alone, however, biological mechanisms underlying preeclampsia pathology are unknown. Our investigations will utilize a novel complement activation- based mouse model to investigate molecular mechanisms of complement induced signaling in preeclampsia pathology. These studies will provide an insight into fundamental processes involved in preeclampsia pathology and is crucial in the future exploration of new therapeutic targets and thus reduce morbidity and mortality in women.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of this proposal is to evaluate the feasibility of a social marketing public health strategy for reducing HIV-related stigma, and associated intersectional stigma, among young people (18-29 years) living with HIV, or at high-risk of HIV acquisition, in an urban Latin American setting. Using theory-based approaches for stigma reduction and health communications, and input from key stakeholders, we will create a series of multimedia content (short videos, music videos, comics, memes) and study whether influencers are willing to share the content via their social media platforms. We will generate evidence of potential efficacy of the content and the intervention as a whole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The objectives of the proposed research are to build a causal pathway framework that helps us understand how multi-level social determinants and intermediary factors related to health and quality of health care together lead to severe maternal morbidity and its disparities. We will use this framework to analyze population-level data from multiple states. Our findings will enable us to identify actionable strategies to prevent this life-threatening outcome and promote equity in maternal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, first, middle): Wu, Jianqiang Public Health Relevance Statement (Narrative attachment) Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is an inherited disease predisposing affected individuals to plexiform neurofibromas (PNFs) on which no effective therapy available. This proposal will study the mechanism(s) of Runx and VCP regulated proteostasis and adaptive endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress in neurofibromagenesis and test if overwhelming of irresolvable ER stress signaling by targeting VCP will provide novel therapy for PNFs. This will provide proof-of-concept for testing MEK-independent cytotoxic and/or durable therapy for PNFs.
