IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inherited retinal degeneration diseases like retinitis pigmentosa (RP) are caused by genetic defects leading to photoreceptor cell loss, irreversible loss of vision and eventual blindness. However, it is unclear how photoreceptors die or how to slow/stop/reverse this process. To better understand the disease mechanism and develop new therapies, we propose to: investigate whether the PARP dependent cell death pathway acts as a common RP mechanism; identify compounds which promote photoreceptor survival in new RP zebrafish model via perform in vivo phenotypic drug screening; and validate identified compounds in established mouse RP models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance: The brain possesses the remarkable plastic ability to change its connectivity, which is often disrupted following injury or neurological disorder, making these plastic mechanisms a target of brain stimulation-based therapies. The goal of this study is to integrate principles from multiple plasticity mechanisms to enhance our ability to induce functional connectivity changes through neural stimulation and promote functional recovery following injury. The results of this study will then be used to inform the development of stimulation-based therapies for neurological disorders, for example to restore lost functions or behaviors following injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Cleft palate is the most common pediatric craniofacial anomaly, and up to 40% of children with cleft palate will develop severe limitations in speech intelligibility and acceptability due to velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI). This research will compare the effectiveness of existing surgical procedures for VPI, establishing which procedures are most effective at improving speech and determining the risks of each procedure. The results will directly contribute to NIDCR’s mission to improve the health of children with craniofacial anomalies by enabling surgeons to select the most effective, least harmful surgical procedure for each child with VPI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a highly prevalent and progressive lung disease that leads to significant morbidity and mortality, yet there are no current therapies to stop lung function decline. A better understanding of the mechanisms underlying COPD pathogenesis, particularly related to the role of the immune cells which infiltrate the lungs in COPD, are necessary to develop therapies. This study will test the hypothesis that dendritic cells and regulatory T cells are dysregulated in COPD and that restoring appropriate regulatory T cell functions could be a potential immunotherapy to treat patients with COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Early-life adversity (ELA), including interpersonal trauma and/or loss, family dysfunction and poverty, is highly prevalent and has profound psychological, biological and social impacts, as well as lasting negative effects on health and well-being. Persons with ELA misuse alcohol, nicotine and illicit drugs at an earlier age, have a quicker transition to substance use disorders (SUD), and a more pernicious clinical course compared with those who did not experience ELA. Using a longitudinal design, this project aims to examine the development of SUD during adolescence, a period of high risk for SUD, among youth with none, low and high levels of ELA and identify the clinical, biobehavioral and family-environmental factors that influence the association between ELA and SUD.

PHR: Project Narrative Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation.

PHR: Project Narrative Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The division of our genome into 22 autosomes and an X and Y chromosome with only a small region of homology is one of the most fundamental descriptions of our genome. However, we lack a clear understanding of the forces that have led to genome organization on this scale. This application will identify the forces that lead to changes in chromosome number, sex chromosome systems, and sex chromosome morphology across the tree of life and identify those forces likely to be acting on the human genome today and in the past.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In recent years, there has been an exponential growth of youths’ e-cigarette use nationally and in the State of Hawai‘i [1, 2], which has been associated with adverse health consequences, such as e- cigarette/vaping-associated lung injury (EVALI), susceptibility to COVID-19 [2, 7], and asthma [8]. In Hawai‘i, 30% of current e-cigarette users in middle/intermediate school are of Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander ancestry, representing the highest percentage of users in this age group among the major ethnic groups in Hawai‘i [1]. This study actively engages rural communities in the development and evaluation of a culturally grounded e-cigarette/vaping prevention intervention for Hawaiian youth, complementing existing population- based efforts to address the e-cigarette epidemic affecting the State of Hawai‘i and Continental U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Overall Project Narrative Alcohol misuse has broad effects on the HIV epidemic, both domestically and globally, contributing to HIV transmission and poor outcomes for those in HIV care. The proposed renewal of the Brown University Alcohol Research Center on HIV (ARCH) will support collaborative research to evaluate the most effective ways to address alcohol misuse in HIV prevention and care through the use of novel HIV staff training models and technology-assisted interventions. Results of ARCH research will directly inform approaches to reduce the substantial social and health costs associated with the co-occurrence of alcohol misuse and HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unfortunately, we are losing the fight against both infectious and chronic diseases due to ongoing pandemics, the alarming increase in the number of multi-drug resistant microbes, and our inability to find drug leads with novel mechanisms of action. To assist in the ongoing search for new drugs and drug leads, this proposed research further develops Fungal Artificial Chromosomes (FACs) into an advanced FAC-NGS-AI technology and tool for drug discovery that allows access to the majority of fungal biosynthetic gene clusters for high yields of natural products from environment filamentous fungi. For this Phase II proposal, our functional metagenomic approach will be used to synthesize, identify and characterize novel antibiotics, and produce them in high yield from dedicated fungal FAC-transformants to aid in the fight against drug-resistant microorganisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Hippo-signaling pathway (HSP), a kinase cascade, inhibits nuclear localization and transcriptional activity of YAP, a transcription co-factor via post-translational modifications. Disruption of the HSP 1) reverses established ischemic cardiomyopathy and heart failure and 2) improves heart function in mouse and pig cardiomyocytes due to increased nuclear YAP and activation of YAP target genes. We will explore the mechanism(s) through which YAP Lysine acetylation and phosphorylation regulates heart regeneration, and how these mechanisms can be leveraged in HF therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Our goal is to parse apart opioid-induced side effects from opioid-induced pain relief by developing new drugs that act differently at the opioid binding site on cells, the mu opioid receptor. The compounds that we have developed bind to the mu opioid receptor in a different way than morphine and fentanyl; moreover, they produce pain relief in rodents and primates at doses that do not produce respiratory suppression, the primary cause of opioid overdose. Herein we propose to understand how these new compounds interact with the receptor from a mechanistic perspective and how they will act in combination with known opioids such as fentanyl and morphine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Babies born prematurely who are exposed to oxygen in the neonatal intensive care unit are at increased risk of airway diseases such as asthma, which makes it important to understand how oxygen detrimentally impacts the developing airways. The goal of this proposal is to use human cell and mouse models to investigate a novel, targetable mechanism (senescence) that we believe plays important roles in making developing airways more reactive and fibrotic (thus contributing to asthma). The importance of our work lies in the potential application of novel drugs that can target senescent cells (senolytics) for improving airway function in preterm infants and reduce the risk of developing asthma later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a progressive neurological disorder that alters the brain circuitry involved in movement control and affects more than ten million people worldwide. This project will help to establish a new closed-loop deep brain stimulation (DBS) tool that we can use in humans to characterize the role of frequency- specific neural activity in PD as well as other brain conditions, and to determine if controlled suppression or amplification of synchronized oscillations in the subthalamic nucleus of PD patients influences the severity of bradykinesia and rigidity. If the studied influence is causal, our DBS approach could become an alternative treatment of PD that can be programmed based on patient-specific neurophysiological data, relevant to reducing health care costs associated with tuning traditional (open-loop) DBS therapies using a trial-and-error process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative    Chromatin  is  a  dynamic  structure  that  requires  constant  assembly  and  disassembly.  Histone  proteins  are  the  subunits of chromatin and require dedicated chaperone to orchestrate their function. This application will define  a  novel  histone  chaperone  pathway  for  new  and  evicted  histone  ad  define  a  new  mode  of  crosstalk  between  chromatin assembly and nucleotide synthesis.

PHR: NARRATIVE Large genetic studies are important for understanding disease risk, including for obesity, but further work is needed to understand the processes affected by genetic factors. This study will combine multiple types of biological measures to identify genetic variations contributing to obesity, evaluate their medical utility, and confirm their functional role through experimentation. In the end, this project will lead to a more complete knowledge of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The olfactory epithelium is one of only three prominent regions within the mammalian nervous systems where new neurons are incorporated throughout life, but a major challenge remains to understand how olfactory sensory neuro- genesis is regulated and maintained. In humans, the failure of persistent olfactory sensory neurogenesis is strongly linked to olfactory dysfunction, which can adversely affect health and quality of life, and for which treatment options are currently limited and often ineffective. The proposed studies are expected to provide insights into fundamental aspects of persistent olfactory sensory neurogenesis, including how it is regulated, how it functions, and how it may be manipulated to enhance human health.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impacts from air pollution exposures on adverse pregnancy outcomes can have serious consequences for populations in low and middle income countries (LMICs) struggling to improve maternal and child health in the face of multiple risk factors. The proposed research will use novel exposure assessment tools to generate extensive (environmental and biomarker based) pregnancy period exposure information for PM2.5 and PAHs in relation birth outcomes in India. Evidence from the study will inform monitoring and evaluation efforts directed at maternal and child health in India and other LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to train obstetrics and gynecology (Ob/Gyn) health professionals on structural and social determinants of health, and the role of health care bias in perpetuating and exacerbating sexual, reproductive, and maternal health disparities. We will design, implement, and evaluate a curriculum for medical student learners about the intersection of race, ethnicity, sex, and gender in Ob/Gyn health care equity, including didactic modules and a reflective learning community app to provide space for active learning and peer exchange. We will implement the course with 140 medical school learners completing mandatory Ob/Gyn clerkship and elective didactics and conduct longitudinal surveys following the Kirkpatrick model to evaluate learner experience, understanding, ability, and growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The immune system deploys a coordinated set of mechanisms that collectively enable peaceful co-existence with the bacteria that occupy various niches of the gastrointestinal tract. The absence of several of these pathways is associated with an increased risk of intestinal inflammation. This project will explore potential mechanisms whereby spontaneous inflammatory responses to bacteria that inhabit the mucus lining of the large intestine may be averted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alveolar bone is essential for supporting teeth and dental implants, but its loss commonly occurs in chronic inflammatory oral diseases, causing severe reductions in quality of life due to the impairment of many basic daily functions such as eating and speaking. Despite its high prevalence, there is no effective treatment in the clinic to reverse alveolar bone loss associated with excessive inflammation. To address this significant unmet public health need, we aim to bioengineer an innovative 3D printed biomimetic and immunomodulatory alveolar bone implant that can effectively resolve periodontal inflammation and promote alveolar bone tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: NARRATIVE  Our research program in Environmental Epitranscriptomics has demonstrated that the levels of over 23 RNA modifications are altered in response to toxicants to regulate the translation of stress response transcripts. Here we will define mechanistic details of codon-biased translation in response to different xenobiotics, and identify toxicant-, cell- and organ-specific epitranscriptomic response programs in rat tissue and human cell models. Our studies will define the biomarker potential for RNA modifications to asses exposures to arsenite and other toxicants, and then test the idea that whole blood and white blood cells (WBCs) serve as an accessible sampling compartment for human epitranscriptome biomarker studies.

PHR: Project Narrative Vision research spans a vast range of basic science areas (cell biology, molecular biology, neurobiology, chemistry, biochemistry, computer science, human and mouse genetics, optics, physiology) with strong traditional links to neuroscience and newly evolving dimensions in translational research on ocular diseases. The principle underlying the Vision Research Core (VRC) at the University of Utah is that research excellence is best served by ready access to resources outside the scope of individual R01 awards, ready access to technical expertise outside the scope a single laboratory, and staff training to remove barriers to efficient translational research and collaboration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinal cord injury resulting in paralysis affects more than 250,000 people nationwide. Implant technology is now available to infer one's desired movement from signals recorded from microelectrode arrays implanted in the brain areas that control movement. Implanted stimulation technology can now reanimate paralyzed muscles, and combining these technologies has the potential to restore reaching movements by thought after paralysis. The goal of this study is to improve stimulation control algorithms to optimize limb motion and stability while also minimizing fatigue and conserving battery power.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Coordination of the actin and microtubule cytoskeleton through molecular motors and associated proteins is essential for performing vital large-scale cellular tasks such as cell division and motility, and, as such, deficits in these proteins lead to devastating diseases and cancer. This project aims to provide fundamental molecular- level understanding of this critical cytoskeletal crosstalk using an interdisciplinary approach -- engineering novel, physiologically relevant assays to study the cytoskeleton’s mechanistic underpinnings using powerful biophysical tools. These findings will not only facilitate deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms that sustain life, but also be the foundation for developing screening and diagnostic tools to better predict and treat cytoskeletal- based diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While fluorinated functional groups have become a hallmark of the modern medicinal chemist’s toolkit, there remain a number of groups – e.g., SF5, N(CF3)2, and N(CF3)(CF2H) – with demonstrated potential that are counterintuitively underemployed. The source of the problem is that all known methods to make these groups require extremely harsh reagents and reaction conditions; that is, the apparent bottleneck in realizing their utility in biological applications is overcoming the vertiginous challenge of chemical accessibility. Accordingly, the proposed research focuses on developing user-friendly synthetic methods to make the SF5, N(CF3)2, and N(CF3)(CF2H) groups more readily available to a broader community of scientists, ultimately to enable downstream applications in drug design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Interactions between human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) and their environment are a main factor in the function of these cells. During cell-material interactions, there is a feedback loop between environmental cues and hMSC-mediated remodeling of the pericellular region which is poorly understood. The proposed work will use synthetic hydrogel scaffolds to mimic aspects of the native tissue environment to quantitatively characterize the change in 3D encapsulated hMSC processes and dynamic hMSC-mediated pericellular degradation and remodeling to build a fundamental understanding of the role of cell-material interactions and the inﬂuence on basic cellular processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite powerful chemotherapy, Mycobacterium tuberculosis survives in many patients' lungs and causes treatment failure or reemergence of tuberculosis, forcing clinicians into surgical intervention. It is unclear why sputum-based diagnostics fail to predict this outcome. This project aims to determine the underlying causes of diagnostic failure and create a knowledgebase enabling development of more sensitive diagnostics, powerful new antibiotics, and vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative To achieve early detection of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), which is critical for effective intervention, mechanistic models of preclinical AD pathological changes must be more comprehensive, incorporating all regions affected early in AD. The current proposal will use multiple approaches to demonstrate that two key AD-vulnerable regions historically studied separately, the basal forebrain and the entorhinal cortex, are affected similarly by early AD pathology with distinct cognitive consequences. This work will help to uncover drivers of AD-vulnerability in cortical and subcortical regions and to develop a more holistic understanding of preclinical AD, including variability in early cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The locus coeruleus, a minuscule region in the dorsal pons, is important for cognition and one of the first regions to accumulate pathologic tau proteins. The proposed study aims to apply novel methods in two large-scale longitudinal cohorts to examine whether the patterns of locus coeruleus activity contribute to the propagation of tau from the brainstem to the entorhinal cortex, the first cortical region accumulating tau, and ultimately leading to cognitive decline. This project has important public health implications and is relevant to part of the NIH’s mission as it will provide insight into the mechanisms of propagation of tau pathology during the primitive stages of Alzheimer's disease and can provide new targets for treatment before irreversible damage has occurred.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE b-cell dysfunction is a key factor in the progression of type 2 diabetes, as well as an unmet treatment need. Studies supported by this grant have led to a reassessment of mechanisms of b-cell failure, and suggested novel alternative approaches to its treatment. Key advances in the last cycle, including the conceptual underpinning that led to the identification of diabetes-enriched islet cell types and master regulatory activities, as well as the discovery of tractable targets for drug development against b-cell failure, offer hope that the disease can be reversed and prompt a strategic reassessment of drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Behavioral HIV research depends on a nuanced understanding of culture and beliefs and calls for a diverse, informed body of researchers, which is currently lacking. This R25 grant application proposes the Fostering Diversity in HIV Research Program that will provide structured career guidance and research mentorship to underrepresented in medicine/public health trainees (residents, post-doctoral fellows, and graduate students); research will address multiple aspects of the HIV continuum of care. The program will also train a dedicated team of mentors with the specific skills needed for effectively supporting these trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: ––– PROJECT NARRATIVE –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Substance use disorders are a chronic human condition where initial consumption leads to long-lasting behavioral changes that are fueled by impulsive choices and changes in motivation, chiefly an increased desire for the abused substance. Substance use is also driven by genetic factors, but what genes underlie impulsivity and changes in motivation are largely unknown. The results from this proposal will isolate genetic factors affecting impulsivity and motivation, thereby illuminating critical mechanisms driving addiction and substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in genes encoding mitochondrial proteins frequently result in congenital heart disease, highlighting the need to elucidate key molecular pathway(s) in mitochondrial homeostasis during heart development. Protein Tyrosine Phosphatase localized to the Mitochondrion 1 (PTPMT1) is a mitochondrial phosphatase, exclusively localized to mitochondria. Proposed studies will help us to understand the biological function of PTPMT1 in cardiomyocytes at the molecular, cellular, and physiological levels, and determine consequences of partial or complete loss of Activating Transcription Factor 4 (ATF4), a master transcriptional regulator of the mitochondrial stress response, on phenotypes of Ptpmt1 cardiomyocyte-specific knockout mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative DNA double-strand break (DSB) repair is critical to maintain genomic stability mending DNA lesions that are induced by ionizing radiation and other common modalities of DNA damage-based anti-cancer therapies including topoisomerase I and II-targeted drugs as well as inhibitors of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP). Homologous recombination involving BRCA2, single-strand annealing catalyzed by RAD52, and POLq-mediated end-joining are key cellular pathways for DSB repair. Our mechanistic findings are important for the understanding of the synthetic lethality network of BRCA2-defective cells, and the insights gained will help to stratify tumors that best respond to the inhibition of RAD52, POLq, and/or PARP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative People living with HIV (PLWH) who use drugs experience significant health disparities including lower rates of retention in HIV care and higher rates of unsuppressed viral load, resulting in secondary infections and increased mortality. The proposed study will used mixed methods to explore (a) providers’ attitudes towards working with PLWH who use drugs as well as their preparedness for delivering harm reduction care; (b) patients’ experiences of stigma in healthcare settings, viewed from an intersectionality framework; and (c) the extent to which structural and relational harm reduction care buffer the effects of stigma in HIV primary care settings, contributing to improved clinical outcomes. The study will also use these findings to inform the development of an intervention to operationalize harm reduction in healthcare settings, using stakeholder- engaged and human-centered design approaches, presenting a novel path to reducing HIV health inequities for PLWH who use drugs.

PHR: Project Narrative: Mental illness (anxiety and depression) and Non-communicable diseases (Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus) are major global problems. We propose to test a Behavioral Community-based COmbined Intervention for MEntal Health and Noncommunicable Diseases (BECOME) delivered by Community Health Workers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: One of the biggest challenges in reducing the mortality of esophageal adenocarcinoma is screening for people at high risk for developing this deadly cancer. In this grant, we will create and validate a swallowable tethered capsule screening tool that obtains targeted biopsies of regions of the esophagus that harbor molecular abnormalities that confer risk for developing cancer. Analysis of these biopsies will determine who needs intervention, intercepting esophageal cancer before it has a chance to form.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The COVID-19 pandemic that took lives of more than 500,000 U.S. citizens is the evidence that emerging infectious diseases are a serious threat to human health. Many patients who died from COVID-19 and other infectious diseases developed severe thrombotic complications shortly after disease symptoms were manifested, and their lives could be saved by predictive diagnosis of disease severity and timely treatment. The goal of the proposed research is develop technology for infectious disease severe assessment that requires only a single drop of venous or capillary blood and can be performed inside a hospital, in a clinic or outpatient center, or at home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The group A strep bacterium is responsible for serious, life-threatening diseases. We are investigating how a major virulence factor of group A strep, the M protein, gives the bacterium the ability to avoid killing by the immune system. Our studies on the M protein will provide knowledge that will be applicable to the design of novel therapeutics or preventive strategies aimed at combating group A strep infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance This proposal aims to dissect the underlying mechanisms of how the host (Tc1-cells) and the liver microbiota (L. reuteri) affects AIH-like pathology and will assess the efficacy of therapeutic interventions (Trp diet, blocking AhR) to alleviate AIH pathology. The proposal will have a significant positive impact on human health because it will advance our understanding of the pathophysiology of AIH and assess rational therapeutic interventions for patients with AIH. Thus, this work will directly support the NIDDK mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden of human disease, and improve the health of patients with autoimmune hepatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to identify gut microbial features and metabolites of gut microbial origin that explain inter- individual differences in post-intervention changes in cardiometabolic risk and adiposity in two randomized Mediterranean diet (MedDiet) intervention studies. We will also investigate long-lasting, post-intervention effects of combined MedDiet and autologous fecal microbiota transplantation (derived from the time of maximal weight reduction) and characterize gut microbial changes during and after the combined interventions in a randomized controlled trial. Based on these unique resources and our experienced transdisciplinary team, the proposed research will provide unprecedented insight into the functional role of the gut microbiome in explaining inter-individual variability in response to dietary interventions and lead to translational and reproducible evidence for novel gut microbiome-guided dietary strategies for cardiometabolic disease prevention.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Thailand remains one of the countries with the largest population of people living with HIV (PLWH) in the Asian-Pacific region. In Thailand, as in other middle-income Asian countries, HIV stigma has been impacted in PLWH and their family members is a pressing health concern. The purpose of this study is to culturally adapt and evaluate the feasibility of a 4 weekly 2-hour group-based stigma reduction intervention to promote health engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The cerebellum contains more neurons and uses more energy than the rest of the brain combined, and in addition to its well-known role in motor control, this remarkable structure has been implicated in language, working memory, cognitive control, and social cognition. Prominent theories of cerebellar computation typically focus on its role in error-based motor learning. The focus of this project is to explore the idea that cerebellar contributions to learning in nonmotor domains may involve the same prediction and error-based learning principles observed in cerebellar motor learning, thus refining current models of cerebellar function in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Women with a history of preeclampsia are at increased risk for heart disease, and new treatments are needed to help prevent heart attacks and death in this population. This work proposes new insights, using novel noninvasive imaging techniques and biomarkers of inflammation and stress to help identify factors linked to heart disease, and help understand factors that affect disease of the blood vessels in this high risk population of young women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorders (SUDs) are pervasive threats to global public health, for which there are few pharmacotherapeutic agents. The aim of the symposium is an interdisciplinary exposition of the recent, most important, research-related advances in medicinal chemistry, pharmacology and (pre)clinical research, related to drug abuse. The emphasis is on laboratory findings that inform the search for SUD pharmacotherapies and to respond to paradigm shifts in the field and emergent threats to at risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital Heart Disease (CHD) is the most common major birth defect, affecting an estimated 1 in 130 live births, yet the cause remains elusive. CHD is tightly associated with heterotaxy syndrome, a condition in which numerous major organs including the heart, lungs and liver are positioned abnormally in the chest and abdomen. This study has the potential to increase our understanding of heterotaxy and CHD by elucidating the fundamental processes that regulate the distribution of the heart and other organs during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Most diseases of the nervous system arise from aberrant function of neuronal circuits, but how individual neurons contribute to the function of larger networks is not well understood. This proposal will establish new methods to test the role of individual neurons and how they contribute to the function of a defined neuronal circuit. Success in these proposed experiments will reveal novel strategies used by neuronal circuits to support brain function, behavior, and perception as well as a better understanding of how circuits can become dysfunctional in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the proposed study, we will examine the effectiveness of oral cefixime 400 mg twice-daily for 10 days (compared to injectable single dose benzathine penicillin G) in treating syphilis among people with and without HIV infection. The results of this clinical trial might identify cefixime as a novel alternative treatment for syphilis that is useful for people living with HIV infection, in patients with penicillin allergy or in settings of penicillin shortage. We will also describe predictors of syphilis treatment failure among people with and without HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Pioneer transcription factors can bind and open silent chromatin, leading to transcriptional activation. The pioneer factors Sox2 and Oct4 orchestrate cell-fate changes during development, yet how they selectively target and destabilize closed chromatin remains largely unknown. This project will investigate the molecular details of how Sox2 and Oct4 alter the structure and epigenetic state of chromatin, which will advance our mechanistic understanding of pioneering action and ability to manipulate stem cells for research and disease therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy affects millions of individuals globally. Among those affected, 30% suffer from untreatable recurrent seizures throughout life, putting them at high risk for post-ictal cardiorespiratory failure and unexpected death (SUDEP). The goal of this fellowship is to determine the role neuroinflammation plays in epilepsy pathophysiology to help identify novel therapeutic targets to prevent the consequences of uncontrolled seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nanoparticle therapeutics are a promising therapeutic modality that are used clinically to treat a variety of diseases in different tissues, but their successful application requires precise delivery to target sites. Integrating our expertise in nanoparticle design and cell engineering, we will develop living cell inspired systems to improve the delivery of nanoparticle therapeutics by mechanistically understanding how the interface between living cells and nanoparticles impacts the migration of carrier cells and transport of nanoparticle, identifying ideal delivery parameters for engineering living cell as drug delivery carriers, and creating multiscale strategies to enable delivery to specific cells. As such, this project has the potential to positively impact public health by developing new ways to deliver and improve the biological outcomes of nanoparticle therapeutics and other therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  (Relevance to Public Health)  This proposal follows a unique sample from age 13 to 37 to examine adolescent peer and family experiences as long-term predictors of key physical health and aging outcomes in early midlife. The project has strong relevance to public health in that it will allow us to identify adolescent-era roots of key outcomes in adulthood ranging from specific health outcomes (e.g., cardiovascular disease risk and metabolic illness) to more fundamental patterns of physiological and epigenetic aging. Results are expected: a. identify several entirely new arenas within adolescence for potential interventions to promote lifelong health and healthy aging; b. suggest specific relational characteristics to target across this period in screening and preventive interventions; c. distinguish social processes in adolescence that directly predict accelerated aging (and are thus critical to address within adolescence) from those that lead to mediated chains of risk (which would suggest multiple promising points of intervention); and d. dramatically advance our overall theoretical understanding of the ways in which early relationship difficulties are linked to and potentially affect physical health and aging outcomes well into midlife.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because our approach will establish the mechanism of disease progression in fatal cerebral phenotype of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, a genetic disorder that in 2016 was added to the federal Recommended Uniform Screening Panel of all genetic diseases recommended for state newborn screening programs. The identified metabolic pathways upon completion of the proposed research can be potentially translated to the clinical laboratory setting for drug development. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NINDS mission that pertains to acquiring and using fundamental new knowledge of the nervous system to decrease the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research proposed here will contribute to an understanding of major depressive disorder, the commonest psychiatric disorder and a leading cause of disability throughout the world. The proposal will combine information from voice recordings and genetics to identify subtypes of depression and develop robust predictors of mood, severity of illness and other clinical indicators. Our research will thereby provide new insights into disease, and well enable the more effective targeting of therapy to those who will most benefit at the appropriate time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Co-transcriptional and post-transcriptional control of RNA metabolism and fate requires the coordinated action of hundreds of RNA binding proteins. This proposal seeks to explore the biological function of a large set of predicted non-canonical RBPs that are enriched for neurological disease-associated nuclear- cytoplasmic transport factors. Characterization of this RNA-binding activity will expand the repertoire of human RBPs and define RNA regulatory networks disrupted in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2)-mediated coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is an evolutionarily unprecedented natural experiment that causes major changes to the host immune system. We propose to develop a test that accurately predicts short- and long-term (within one-year) outcomes in hospitalized COVID-19 patients broadly reflecting US demographics who are at increased risk of adverse outcomes from COVID-19 using both clinical and molecular data. We will enroll patients from a hospitalized civilian population in one of the country’s largest metropolitan areas and a representative National Veteran’s population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Simultaneous alcohol and marijuana (SAM) use is common among young adults and can lead to more negative consequences than use of either substance alone. No current intervention addresses SAM use and few leverage new technological methods or strategies to engage young adults. Using the Multiphase Optimization Strategy (MOST) framework, the goal of this project is to test the feasibility and efficacy of a new, fully mobile adaptive ecological momentary intervention on two outcomes (negative consequences and use of protective behavioral strategies) for young adults recruited from primary care clinics who are engaging in SAM use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overdose (OD) crisis continues to devastate communities throughout North America. Although most overdoses are non-fatal, there is little knowledge concerning the health outcomes of people who experience a non-fatal overdose (NFOD). The proposed project will utilize administrative health data to provide insight into the role of sex, gender, and HIV status on the health outcomes of people experiencing an NFOD. This project will establish a Community Advisory Board, composed of people with diverse lived and living expert experiences, to provide guidance and ensure research soundness and relevance to the community. The results from this project will inform the direction and nature of subsequent community co-led research to answer relevant research questions and collaboratively explore barriers to care following an NFOD, which will ultimately support the development and implementation of relevant, and culturally appropriate services for cisgender women and gender minorities living with and without HIV who are affected by the OD crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We will investigate four newly identified eye and brain malformations – caused by large unique autosomal DNA insertions at the same chromosome Xq27 site – a palindromic `hotspot' near SOX3, which encodes a potent DNA-binding factor. The insertions harbor enhancer(s) that activate SOX3 in ectopic cells or compartments, homeotically trans- forming one embryonic tissue type into another (SOX3 gain-of-function). We will use patient-derived stem cells, in vitro differentiation, 3D chromatin interaction assays, and informative mouse models to test this hypothesis. Our study will throw light on blindness, brain disorders, human genetics, transcriptional regulation, mutation and evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The research will study how supporting cells called astrocytes and microglia are important to the loss of vision caused by the eye disease, glaucoma. The pressure in the eye affects these cells, leading to both good and toxic effects on the important nerve cells whose death is the cause of glaucoma blindness. Treatments that come from this work are envisioned that would preserve vision in a process called neuroprotection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) is a major cause of death in the first year of life for which there is no known cause. While our research strongly implicates defects in and reduced function of the life-sustaining brainstem serotonin system in a major subset of SIDS cases, the mechanisms underlying these defects remain unknown. We will test the hypothesis, directly in SIDS tissue as well as mechanistic validation in model systems, that neuroinflammation in the brain, originating from environmental factors (low oxygen or infections), causes or exacerbates the consequences of abnormalities within the serotonergic system and reduces the likelihood of successful recovery from reflex apneas (periods of breathing cessation). Confirmation of our hypothesis would guide new therapeutic strategies targeting neuroinflammation and aimed at prevention in a substantial group of SIDS infants.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed Center for Collaborative Research in Health Disparities (CCRHD) at the University of Puerto Rico Medical Sciences Campus builds upon research resources developed under a previous RCMI-U54 grant and an extensive academic/community partnership to address health disparities affecting the Puerto Rican population. Translational research projects in the areas of basic biomedical, behavioral and clinical research, if successful, will provide different and innovative approaches to increase the capacity to conduct word-class research on diseases that disproportionally affect the Puerto Rican population by enhancing participation of Hispanic patients in clinical studies, partnering with community organizations and enabling all level of investigators to conduct health disparities research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human papilloma virus (HPV) has been established as a causative agent of cervical cancer (CC), and Hispanic woman in Puerto Rico have the highest age-adjusted incidence compared to women in the US. Persistent infection with high-risk human papilloma virus (hr-HPV) types is a necessary, but not sufficient to cause cervical cancer. We hypothesize that the key factors that promote cancer progression likely reside in the cervical environment, notably its local multi-kingdom microbiome. Here we propose to comprehensively study crossectionally and longitudinally, the relationship between HPV, lower genital tract commensal bacteria and fungi, the metabolome and the immune response and cervical cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research focuses on acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which affects more than 10,000 Americans annually, the majority of who die of their disease within a short time. This research addresses the role of SHP2 in receptor tyrosine kinase signaling in relapsed/refractory AML and the use of SHP2 inhibitors in combination with BCL2 inhibitors in AML treatment. The overall goal of this work is to establish new and effective strategies to treat relapsed/refractory AML.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Ending the HIV Epidemic Initiatives has the goal of reducing new HIV infections among at risk groups in priority jurisdictions. We propose the creation of ConPrEP; a behavioral intervention to increase PrEP uptake among latino men who have sex with men in Puerto Rico. The proposed study will allow for a comprehensive understanding of what are the best practices for interventions focused on PrEP uptake among Latino MSM in Puerto Rico. It will also provide for the development of a culturally congruent HIV prevention intervention to reduce new HIV infections among Latinos in Puerto Rico.

PHR: Project Narrative - Relevance of Proposed Project to Public Health Milder forms of HIV-CI are prevalent in PWH and are at a higher risk to progress to worse stages, reiterating the importance of early diagnosis and possible treatment. We will explore the relationship between biological, behavioral responses and structural racism and discrimination (SRD) factors that position the Puerto Rican and Hispanics HIV population at a higher risk of developing HIV-CI. We expect that our findings will translate into interventions to improve Hispanic health and decrease the severity and prevalence of HIV-CI. Reducing SRD will improve health and reduce disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anhedonia, a core symptom of depression and other forms of psychopathology associated with severe negative health outcomes, including suicidality and poor treatment response, is a major public health concern. We will test an innovative positive emotion-focused preventive intervention for children and mothers with a history of major depression with anhedonia to enhance child reward responsiveness and prevent the emergence of anhedonia in youth. This study will advance understanding of how affective neuroscience can be translated into an experimental therapeutics approach to prevention, leading to more personalized interventions to reduce the burden of anhedonia and associated psychopathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative A group of collagen-degrading enzymes present in dentin is suggested to be responsible for tissue breakdown that advances caries lesions, but the real contribution of these enzymes to disease progression and how their expression and activity is modulated are unclear. This study will fill major gaps in the understanding of endogenous processes in caries progression and provide insights into interactions between the microbiome present at different stages of the disease with host responses that express and/or activate dentinal enzymes. The information gained will provide the foundation for the development of novel therapies for caries management to promote a shift from invasive surgical restorative to conservative reparative treatments, while at the same time contributing to a much deeper understanding of the microbiome-host interactions in caries disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the common complications of pulmonary hypertension is right-sided heart failure that is associated with poor prognosis in patients. We have developed preliminary data showing that right-sided heart failure, in part, is mediated by excessive activation of cardiac fibroblasts induced by the specific enzyme named protein kinase D. This research will allow us to design a novel strategy for the management of right-sided heart failure during pulmonary hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Human Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is the etiological agent for Kaposi's sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) and multicentric Castleman's disease. We discovered that KSHV exploits an innate immune kinase to promote the proliferation of KSHV- infected PEL cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Above-normal systolic blood pressure is a highly prevalent chronic condition that increases risk for cardiovascular diseases, stroke, cognitive decline/dementia, and other chronic disorders, due in part to blood pressure-associated vascular dysfunction mediated by increased oxidative stress and consequent reductions in nitric oxide (NO)-bioavailability. Healthy lifestyle practices are first-line therapies to lower systolic blood pressure; however, adherence to time-intensive lifestyle interventions is poor, due in large part to time- availability related barriers. This clinical trial seeks to establish the efficacy of high-resistance inspiratory muscle strength training, a novel time-efficient lifestyle intervention, for lowering systolic blood pressure; improving endothelial, cerebrovascular, and cognitive function; decreasing oxidative stress; and increasing NO bioavailability in adults age 50 years and older with above-normal systolic blood pressure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Narrative Autophagy, a cellular process of self-eating, plays a critical role in degrading and recycling cellular components by delivering them to the lysosome. Although dysregulated autophagy is recognized as a significant feature of cancer, effectively harnessing autophagy for optimal therapeutic benefits poses a challenge. This project aims to investigate a novel approach to induce alternative cell death signaling from autophagosomal membranes. The successful completion of this research holds the potential to reveal innovative strategies for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Transfer RNAs (tRNAs) are critical for decoding messenger RNA during translation by the ribosome, where they insert their charged amino acid into the end of the growing peptide chain. The numerous tRNA modifications found in all organisms are critical for function and stability, are highly conserved in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and in humans, and are required to prevent poor growth in yeast and human neurological disorders and mitochondrial diseases. This project is directed toward study of critical tRNA decay pathways in S. cerevisiae and the evolutionarily distant yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe, and study of tRNA turnover dynamics in wild type cells and cells lacking critical modifications, to understand factors that influence the population of tRNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the use of intensive multimodal therapy for high-risk neuroblastoma approximately 50% of children still die from this disease, survivors suffer life-long treatment related co-morbidities, and relapsed neuroblastoma is almost universally lethal. This research project is relevant to public health as it focuses on defining resistance mechanisms to chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells targeting the robustly differentially expressed neuroblastoma cell surface oncoprotein glypican-2 and on developing next-generation CAR T cells that circumvent this resistance, studies that will be important for the field of cancer immunotherapy in general and the pediatric cancer neuroblastoma in particular. The proposed research is highly relevant to the NIH mission and urgent unmet medical need of developing rational evidence-based strategies to reduce the health burden of neuroblastoma and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder is among the most common and severe major psychiatric disorders. This proposal seeks to combine AUD GWAS with gene expression and DNA methylation findings from a large cohort of postmortem brains and regions. This novel, integrated analysis will detail so far unknown AUD-associated genes and epigenetic marks and will allow identification of neurobiological mechanisms and novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Initial work in this project conclusively demonstrated the ability of contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) to detect residual viable hepatocellular carcinoma following transarterial chemoembolization significantly earlier and with improved sensitivity relative to the current clinical standard. We now seek to expand these findings to other solid tumors being treated with chemoembolization and to use advanced ultrasound imaging approaches to improve on the technique’s suboptimal specificity. Additionally, we plan to expand the role of CEUS by investigating intraoperative treatment assessment as well as pre-treatment assessment for guiding the selection of locoregional therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mounting evidence suggests poor patient experiences with peripartum contraceptive care. Validated quality metrics grounded in patient-centeredness and health equity could help drive efforts to improve these crucial domains of healthcare quality, but no such measures currently exist. We will use modified Delphi methods with patient and expert stakeholders, cognitive interviews with patients, and psychometric testing to generate a novel measure of the patient experience of contraceptive counseling within the unique context of maternity care, with a goal of ultimately transforming the ability of health systems and researchers to understand and promote patient-centered, equitable peripartum contraceptive care delivery and thereby improve health outcomes for mothers and infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dementia is a growing healthcare problem and a research priority, yet it remains under-recognized in the community, under-diagnosed by healthcare professionals, and under-coded in claims data. This study aims to address this pressing need by developing a deep learning algorithm to improve the detection of cognitive impairment within electronic medical records and conducting comprehensive validation across multiple healthcare institutions. The study will not only facilitate research but may also aid providers in planning and managing patient care.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide new targets to advance therapies for the early treatment of injury-induced osteoarthritis (OA). Our study provides a novel perspective to study OA pathophysiology in which joints and muscles are both target tissues, and both contribute to the pain associated to this disease. We are proposing two novel drug delivery systems and two potential new therapeutic targets that could be beneficial to limit both joint and muscle damage involved in OA, as well as inflammation and pain, opening new critical insights to treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE- OVERVIEW The Indiana University Melvin and Bren Simon Cancer Center is an NCI-designated Cancer Center whose mission is to create an expanding community of researchers and health professionals who conduct outstanding translational research, provide excellence in education, and deliver high quality patient-centered care. We will foster and promote an environment of cultural awareness, diversity, and inclusion as we contribute to the prevention and cure of cancer in Indiana. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 2 million individuals in the United States live with opioid use disorder. Opioid use disorder is correlated with poor postoperative pain and an increased risk of opioid-related harms, but strategies to improve surgical care for individuals with opioid use disorder are lacking. In this prospective study, we will examine the perioperative experiences of patients with opioid use disorder in order to develop and test a clinical care pathway that integrates care coordination, overdose prevention, peer coaching, and best practices in postoperative pain management to generate the necessary evidence to optimize surgical recovery for patients with opioid use disorder.

PHR: Project Narrative Metastasis is the major cause of cancer mortality, and effective therapies are urgently needed. Histone methyltransferase ASH1L is genetically amplified and overexpressed in metastatic cancers. The proposed project is expected to identify ASH1L as a key epigenetic determinant in priming immunosuppressive metastatic niche and develop effective targeted therapy and combinatorial immunotherapy for metastatic cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Ubiquitin-mediated signaling is involved in the regulation of a wide variety of biological processes including cell development and division, the immune response, and signal transduction. The ubiquitin-proteasome proteolytic pathway, the principal mechanism for turnover of short-lived proteins, has been the target for extensive drug design efforts, as defects in this pathway are associated with numerous diseases, including cancers, neurodegenerative disorders, developmental disorders, immune and inflammatory disorders, and muscle wasting. This research will enhance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying recognition and regulation in ubiquitin-mediated signaling pathways and will guide the design of a novel class of inhibitors targeting ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation and other vital cellular pathways.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Children spend more time than ever using screens — increasingly on portable digital media devices like tablets and smartphones, but our understanding about how these devices impact health is lagging. This project proposes to uncover how patterns of digital media use are formed and maintained and examine how those patterns predict mental health and cardiovascular health risk over time. The novel forms of media measurement used in this project – including passive mobile sampling, ecological momentary assessment and accelerometry – will allow us to uncover the unique and complex ways in which digital media impacts health behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will further develop and continue to maintain the UltraScan software suite, which contributes to the analysis of biophysical solution data with unmatched resolution and efficiency. Among the proposed developments are codes to provide comprehensive and automated reporting to support GMP operation of analytical ultracentrifugation experiments performed with the Beckman-Coulter Optima AUCTM instrument, to offer electronic signatures and audit trails for GMP operation, and automated tools for structure determination. These efforts are highly relevant for many current NIH and NSF investigations, support the development of therapeutics against any disease studied on the molecular level, contribute important tools for studies into the mechanisms of aging, cancer, HIV, and neurodegenerative diseases, improve patient safety through rigorous characterization of drugs, and inform investigations into their interactions with drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: This study will address critical gaps in knowledge, including the mechanisms of inhibitory synapse formation and the role of astrocytes in inhibitory synapse development in the hippocampus. Since impaired inhibition and deficits in inhibitory interneurons are thought to underlie the development of hyperactive neuronal networks in neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder, schizophrenia, and epilepsy, the proposed work may lead to the development of novel therapeutic targets to treat neurodevelopmental disorders. Proposed studies will utilize unique mouse models, state-of-art optophysiological analysis and imaging approaches, biochemical studies and translationally relevant video-EEG monitoring for seizures which we have used to evaluate epileptogenicity during developmental dysregulation of interneuronal circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Most people with schizophrenia suffer from significant disability for most of their adult lives. Impaired cognition has been shown to play an important role in determining the extent of disability that patients experience but is not currently treatable. This research program is designed to increase understanding of the specific cognitive and neural mechanisms that are dysfunctional in schizophrenia to provide more specific targets for treatment development research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Cervical cancer burden represents a major global health disparity, and high coverage of HPV vaccine will be necessary to substantially reduce incidence and ultimately achieve cervical cancer elimination in high-burden settings like Eastern Africa. Although many countries in the region have national programs to offer HPV vaccine for free to preadolescent girls, uptake is low, and little is known about who is getting vaccinated (and who is not). Through mixed methods research to collect and analyze data on the multi-level factors associated with HPV vaccination in Africa, this proposed study seeks to identify where future interventions may be best-targeted to address the specific barriers that are limiting HPV vaccine coverage in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) have identified thousands of common, non-coding variants associated with disease. While integration of GWAS data with gene expression from bulk tissues has uncovered some of the underlying genes and mechanisms, only a fraction of trait heritability can be explained by existing bulk datasets and the majority of GWAS loci do not colocalize with QTLs from bulk expression data. Understanding which cell types and contexts are the most relevant for a given disease – both at the level of individual loci and across the genome – is thus critical to moving from individual variants to an understanding of broader processes and, eventually, to effective interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Over half of adolescents with Down syndrome experience difficulty being understood by others which can lead to social isolation and loneliness which, in turn, leads to poor mental and physical health outcomes. Interventions to improve speech production in adolescents with Down syndrome are rare and yield mixed results because of the lack of empirical information regarding the elements that contribute to successful communication outcomes during daily life activities. By applying a precision medicine approach within a biopsychosocial framework, this proposal will lay the foundation for the creation of interventions that center the patient perspective, address the underlying impairment based on comprehensive speech production profiles, and engage societal structures that contribute to disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Athletes engaged in contact sports can experience hundreds of mild “subconcussive” head hits annually from soccer heading and American football tackles, which may lead to an increased risk for the development of brain disorder in later life. However, there are no protective interventions for subtle brain damage from repetitive mild head hits. We will test whether daily supplementation of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) –two of primary fish oil components– can minimize such brain injury induced by repetitive soccer heading.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence indicates that race/ethnicity-, sexual orientation, and gender-related discrimination is linked to increased harmful cardiometabolic health behaviors (CHB; e.g., sleep, physical activity, and tobacco and alcohol use). However, there is limited research demonstrating the influence of online discrimination, a critical social determinant of health, on CHB among diverse groups of SGM. Our novel multi-method study design will illuminate how discrimination operates in online environments and physical spaces, as well as highlight key protective factors, which can be used to better distill risk and inform targeted mediums for harmful CHB prevention interventions among SGM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal is founded on the critical finding that extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins in peripheral tissues play an active role in modulating Natural Killer (NK) cell effector functions. The central aim of the proposed work is to elucidate the precise mechanisms governing this ECM-mediated regulation of NK cell response in solid cancers. The findings from this work will reveal novel NK cell regulatory mechanisms that can be harnessed to boost NK cell immunity against solid cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative – This highly translational proposal (a) has as a main goal the validation of glycated CD59 (GCD59, the glucose inactivated form of the key complement regulatory protein known as CD59) in human urine, as a novel diabetes biomarker (b) addresses major Public Health priorities, and (c) is based on a robust hypothesis, extensive preliminary data and availability of all assays/reagents needed. The relevance of the proposed studies is highlighted by the following facts 1) diabetes mellitus affects ≈25 million Americans, and diabetic complications are a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the U.S., 2) treatment of diabetic complications costs a staggering 245 billion dollars/year, and is expected to rise to >300 billion by 2034, and 3) pregnancy-induce glucose intolerance is a major cause of maternal-fetal adverse pregnancy outcomes to the point that current standard of care is to screen for this condition all pregnant women who do not have prior diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Though we are unsure how to interpret their function, mutations in genes that read and write DNA methylation marks are associated with neurodevelopmental disease and intellectual disabilty. Our studies will develop new sequencing approaches to understand the mechanisms behind DNA methylation changes in the brain and assess how loss of a key methylation reader, MeCP2, affects neuronal function. In the future, our approaches can be applied by investigators to understand the function of DNA methylation and suggest new therapies to treat neurodevelopmental disorders and intellectual disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The protein α-Synuclein (αS) and lipid membranes are key components of Lewy bodies (LBs), the hallmarks of Parkinson's disease (PD), Lewy body dementia (LBD) and other synucleinopathies. αS interacts with lipids and fatty acids and alters homeostasis, but despite the brain being highly lipid-rich, the role of lipid metabolism in PD and LBD remains largely unresolved. The PI will lead a diverse team with expertise in lipidomics, αS biochemistry and PD genetics in vivo and in vitro to validate LIPE (hormone sensitive lipase) as a candidate therapeutic target in vivo and establish the mechanism of rescue focused on αS:lipid membrane interactions at the synapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Osteoporosis is a major public health burden and a condition characterized by decreased bone strength. Current estimates indicate that 12 million people suffer from osteoporosis in the U.S. Osteoporosis is largely influenced by genetics. This project seeks to identify the genes influencing bone strength using an innovative mouse genetics approach. Successful completion of this project will identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Existing approaches to measuring intersectional discrimination (i.e., racial/ethnic-, sexual orientation, and/or gender-related) and related cardiometabolic health behaviors (CHB; i.e., physical inactivity, dysregulated sleep, and tobacco and alcohol use) lack the ability to capture the real-world context in which intersectional discrimination occurs, the momentary appraisal of such events, and resultant behaviors. To address this limitation, we will use a validated novel geographically-explicit momentary assessment (GEMA) method, which allows for the accurate capturing of the duration and frequency of exposure situated within the context in which these behaviors and exposures occur among young sexual and gender minorities (YSGM) as well as explores risk and protective factors for harmful CHB among diverse YSGM. This study will demonstrate the utility of the predictive models and variable creation for future CHB Just in Time interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Projective Narrative The rising prevalence of obesity within our Veteran and non-Veteran population leads many people to weight cycle, dramatically altering the adipose tissue immune environment and increasing inflammation. The immune system within adipose tissue develops an obesogenic memory to weight cycling, potentiating poor metabolic outcomes. Our goal is to identify mechanisms of immune memory to better define the pathogenesis of obesity associated metabolic disorders. Specifically, we will study the surface protein, CD70, an adaptor protein essential for T cell memory formation. Using gene knockout and antibody studies, we will determine how loss of T cell memory formation during weight gain and weight loss impacts adipose tissue inflammation and metabolic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The tau protein is widely expressed in brain cells and is critical to brain function. In humans, a mutation in the gene encoding for tau (MAPT R406W) changes the protein and makes it easier for tau to abnormally accumulate, ultimately causing frontotemporal dementia (FTD). This proposal aims to study when FTD starts by studying biomarkers of FTD in a family of rhesus monkeys carrying an exact replicate of the human MAPT R406W FTD-related mutation. This project has the potential to aid patients, because to know when FTD starts will help define when to begin future treatments to prevent the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2022, fentanyl overdose was the leading cause of death for US adults aged 18 - 45. This striking statistic underscores the urgent need to discover and characterize the genetic causes of fentanyl addiction, a highly heritable disease. The successful completion of this project, in which we will use genetically diverse mice to better understand the genes that cause individuals to abuse fentanyl, will contribute to the development of novel, more effective addiction treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) are heterogeneous and affect approximately 69 million persons annually worldwide, causing debilitating and enduring complex cognitive and psychosocial impairments regardless of injury location, yet the preclinical research to date has largely overlooked attention and emotional deficits post- TBI, which may be exacerbated by the presence of clinical comorbidities. The overarching aim of this R21 proposal is to remedy the paucity of studies examining comorbidities during the TBI recovery phase, by exploring how adult-onset hypertension (i.e., high blood pressure), a common underlying condition for approximately 50% of the adult United States population, may impact long-term motor, complex cognitive, and anxiety-like alterations subsequent to pediatric or adult injuries. The findings from the proposed preclinical studies, carried out in both male and female rats, will advance our understanding of neurobehavioral and histopathological alterations in survivors of brain trauma living with comorbid hypertension, as well as facilitate identifying mechanisms through which therapeutic and rehabilitative approaches may be targeted to relevant symptoms in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is among the most pressing and costly medical challenges confronting modern society. While neurons that express agouti-related protein (AgRP) are implicated in the regulation of energy balance, our recent work suggests there are distinct subsets of AgRP neurons that mediate different metabolic and behavioral functions. The identification and characterization of distinct subsets of AgRP neurons, and mapping their downstream projections will advance our understanding of energy homeostasis and has the potential to identify novel therapeutic strategies for obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While our knowledge of the effects of climate change on human health is expanding, including evidence that transient changes in local ambient temperatures can lead to acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD, the effects of temperature change on long term respiratory outcomes are unknown. The goal of this proposal is to identify relationships between temperature changes and longitudinal lung function using a cystic fibrosis model. This valuable information will provide additional insight and predictions for the effects of climate change on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES Diabetes is a complex disease is caused by an interaction among genetic, behavioral, and environmental factors. The legacy flame retardants polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) and the current-use flame retardant alternative tetrabromobisphenol A TBBPA (sometimes called “regrettable substitute”) are linked to diabetes in humans and animal models. The proposed study will use genetically modified mouse models to mechanistically investigate how early life flame retardant exposure mediated dysbiosis in the gut microbiome modulates host nuclear receptor signaling and contributes to delayed onset of diabetes phenotype in adulthood, especially following exposure to a secondary risk factor later in life such as a western diet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder (AUD) and related problems kill over 3 million people each year and account for up to 6% of global deaths. We propose to perform genome-wide association studies and use high throughput reporter assays to identify variants and genes related to alcohol sensitivity and tolerance, two key risk factors for AUD; then replicate and validate our findings using diversity outbred mice and gene expression analysis. These results will advance our knowledge of the etiologies of alcohol related problems and facilitate the development of novel treatment and prevention strategies.
