PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) of the knee joint are rising, particularly for the female adolescent population, yet the mechanisms driving age- and sex-specific ACL tissue adaptations that may lead to increase injury risk are unclear. The goal of this proposal is to determine how the timing and level of sex hormones impact ACL bundle size and function. Such information will be critical to provide guidance for patient-specific injury risk and treatment algorithms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with Down syndrome (DS) often present with inflammatory skin diseases such as atopic dermatitis (AD) and alopecia areata (AA). They represent a vulnerable population that is seldom included in clinical trials. We propose a clinical trial to evaluate the long-term safety, efficacy, and mechanisms of two novel JAK1 (abrocitinib) and JAK3/TEC (ritlecitinib) inhibitors, recently FDA-approved for AD and AA respectively, in patients with DS, so that individuals with DS can be appropriately treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The heart’s inability to make new muscle cells and resulting maladaptive remodeling of muscle structure and function is a key driver of heart failure. This project focuses on a factor that [1] prevents cardiac muscle cells from transitioning to pathologic immature states incompetent of mounting a proper growth response to cardiac stress and [2] controls the frequency with which muscle cells transition to stress-induced immature states, as we postulate the number of myocytes recruited into these states predicts the nature and severity of pathologic remodeling and ultimately heart failure. Thus the long-term goal of this project is therapeutically protecting the heart from these maladaptive immature state transitions by redeploying this factor in select cardiac muscle cells.

ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a worldwide health problem that greatly increases the risk for developing hypertension and cardiovascular disease. Despite this impact, the underlying causes and optimal therapeutic tools for obesity- related hypertension are still poorly understood. This proposal will identify mechanisms by which the protective hormone angiotensin-(1-7) may improve cardiovascular and metabolic functions in individuals with obesity hypertension, to hopefully enhance understanding of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative Though placebo treatments are pharmacologically inert, they induce active neurobiological processes related to patients’ expectations, learned associations, perceived care and support, and hope for the future. Studying placebo treatments provides a window into these crucial context variables that will help understand vulnerability and resilience to mental health disorders and beyond. This project continues a successful program of research on the brain mechanisms of placebo effects, taking the work in new directions critical for understanding mental health.

PHR: Metabolic disorders such as obesity, diabetes and insulin resistance involve the communication between metabolic organs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Invasive aspergillosis, caused by the filamentous fungus Aspergillus fumigatus, is a leading cause of death in immunocompromised patients. With the emergence of Azole-resistant A. fumigatus, improving existing therapies and understanding the molecular mechanism of fungal adaptation to antifungals is imperative. Our proposal will specifically study the role of the septin cytoskeleton in A. fumigatus response to the antifungal caspofungin using a combination of proteomics, genetic, molecular, cell biology, and in vivo approaches.

PHR: Expansion and superior functionality are hallmarks of fetal hematopoietic stem cells. The Notch signaling pathway is essential for function and maturation of hematopoietic stem cells while in the fetal liver, and we propose to identify how the signaling in the fetal niche regulates the expression of novel target genes, which lead to expansion of fetal hematopoietic stem cells. We will use this knowledge for the therapeutic expansion of cord blood cells and rejuvenation of adult bone marrow stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Walking impairments are debilitating and common but poorly understood in older persons with asthma (OPWA). This study will examine the effects of brain structure and function, controller medication adherence and asthma control on walking performance in 240 persons with and without asthma age 60-80 years. The expected findings will shed light on underlying asthma-specific brain circuitry disruptions, and modifiable disease management targets that will inform physical, cognitive, and pharmacological treatments to improve walking, prevent mobility impairments, and improve related health outcomes among OPWA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL Compared to patients in the US, Nigerian patients present with colorectal cancer at a younger age and with more advanced disease and worse survival. While the reasons for these disparities are multi-factorial, our NIH-funded studies suggest unique biology and a potential role for immunotherapy in improving outcomes. The Nigerian Immuno-Oncology Research (NOLA) program will synergize our existing strengths in global cancer disparities research and immuno-oncology to address clinically meaningful questions regarding colorectal cancer immunobiology and clinical care of patients with immunotherapy in Nigeria, and how these factors can be leveraged to address colorectal cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in ASNA1 result in human cardiomyopathy, highlighting its importance for cardiac function. However, little is known as to the specific role of ASNA1 in cardiomyocytes, and how mutations in ASNA1 result in cardiomyopathy. Proposed studies are aimed at understanding the function of ASNA1 in cardiac muscle at the molecular, cellular, and physiological levels, and gaining insights into mechanisms by which mutations in ASNA1 cause cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 30 million adults in the U.S. have type 2 diabetes, which can result in devastating complications such as strokes, kidney failure, and amputation if not well-managed. Day-to-day self-management by adults with type 2 diabetes, including glucose monitoring, taking medications, and healthy habits, is essential to avoid diabetes complications, yet, despite the rapidly expanding availability of wearable glucose and activity monitors, successful self-management remains challenging for many. This research aims to develop and test an approach to help adults use their personal diabetes information from wearable devices to achieve and sustain healthy diabetes self-management, which will reduce diabetes complications, and improve health and quality of life for people with type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This project explores the structural basis of key molecular interactions that are responsible for the cellular membrane disruption induced by amyloidosis of b-amyloid peptides. The outcomes will provide insights on the pathological roles of both Ab amyloidogenic aggregates and cellular plasma membranes in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: This project will test whether depression encompasses two distinct subtypes: chronic-intermittent and time- limited. We will leverage a cohort of 550 females who were studied previously from age 14 to 21 and will now follow them to age 26 to learn about causes and consequences of these subtypes. Our findings will help to better guide research and services to address the high burden of depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Demographically, aging and neurodegenerative conditions are projected to steadily rise; individuals with these characteristics and conditions are more likely to require surgical interventions for underlying conditions and are at increased risk for the development of Perioperative Neurocognitive Disorders (PNDs) that will soon reach epidemic proportions. Currently, there are no therapies that can mitigate this inexorable rise in PNDs which results in decreased quality of life, higher mortality and is estimated to incur annual US healthcare costs in the 1st year after diagnosis of ~ $33 billion. By establishing that sgp130Fc, selective IL-6 trans- signaling blocker, can safely reduce the vulnerability of high-risk mouse models for PNDs, a pharmaceutical preparation (olamkicept) currently undergoing successful Phase II trials for inflammatory bowel disease (another IL-6 trans-signaling condition), can be repurposed for randomized clinical trials to prevent and/or treat PNDs in high-risk patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A better understanding of the mechanisms regulating response to anti-HER2 antibodies is critical for the development of improved clinical strategies, and the inclusion of a diverse patient population and consideration of group- and individual-level genetic differences is essential for ensuring that these strategies are equitable. This work will provide the basis for moving towards a more race-inclusive, equity-focused precision medicine approach to the use of immunotherapies to improve overall treatment response, identify novel biomarkers, and reduce racial disparities in outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Administrative Core contributes to the overall efficiency of the P20 by centralizing and leveraging the existing administrative infrastructure of the Karmanos Cancer Institute (KCI), an NCI-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center, thereby streamlining processes and eliminating duplication of effort. This robust administrative infrastructure conserves the resources of KCI’s Research Administration and allows investigators the ability to concentrate on the science of this P20, establish meaningful and productive multidisciplinary collaborations, and develop large-scale extramural grant submissions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Mitochondria are essential for cell survival not only as sources of ATP but also as factors that control intracellular signaling. The role of mitochondrial generated ROS and signaling in regulating bone regeneration is currently unknown. This proposal seeks to identify the role of two novel mitochondrial related factors BNIP3 and NIX in regulating digit regeneration to elucidate mechanisms that can be targeted to enhance bone regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) designated Carbapenem-Resistant Acinetobacter baumannii (CRAb) an “urgent threat pathogen” for which novel therapies are desperately needed. To address this crisis, we propose to design novel inhibitors of the β-lactamases present in CRAb and discern how these inhibitors can gain better entry into the cell. As we determined that overexpressing certain β-lactamase genes (OXA -lactamases) creates unique cellular vulnerabilities by making certain gene products essential for survival, we will look for small molecules to inhibit those gene products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Mutations in the chromatin modifier ASH1L have been associated with autism spectrum disorders and epilepsy. ASH1L regulates large groups of genes simultaneously, including other genes that have been associated with autism and seizures such as FOXP1. We find that there are sex-specific differences in the presentation of the epilepsy and autism in patients with mutations in ASH1L. Our goals in this proposal are 1) clinically characterize patients with ASH1L mutations that variable degrees of phenotypic severity, and 2) identify the cellular defects and molecular signatures associated with ASH1L in stem cell experimental systems derived from a cohort of male and female patients with variable phenotypic severity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Solid tumors are hard to treat with CAR T cells because the antigens they express are heterogenous. We propose the clinical translation of an approach that synergizes clinical imaging with T cell therapy to overcome the current limitations of toxicity, antigen loss variants and cost of engineered T cell therapy through the application of a bio-orthogonal image-enabled adaptable CAR (ImAC) method where CAR T cells can be tracked by imaging after infusion, and delivery of CAR T cells with tailored payloads can be monitored through noninvasive imaging. We will optimize the ImAC method in rigorous preclinical assays and then test feasibility, safety and response in a Phase I clinical trial for women with advanced ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents with type 1 diabetes (T1D) are at increased risk for problems with diabetes management and poor glycemic control. This randomized controlled trial will assess whether a behavioral intervention to improve sleep duration and quality will improve diabetes outcomes and executive function. We will also utilize advanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) methods in a subset of adolescents to understand mechanisms by which sleep duration affects brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rett Syndrome is a severe neurodevelopmental disorder caused by a mutation in the X-linked gene, MECP2, which encodes a chromatin-associated protein crucial for neuronal development. To develop a disease-specific treatment, we have identified an X-reactivating methodology that can restore endogenous MECP2 expression in the brain. In the 1st funding cycle, we achieved an in vivo proof-of-concept for phenotypic rescue in a disease-relevant animal model and now aim to complete PK/PD studies and identify development candidates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the rising incidence of antibiotic resistance and the steady decline in the discovery of new antibiotics, there is a critical need for the development of strategies to preserve the efficacy of existing antibiotics. The objective of this application is to investigate the combination of antimicrobial blue light and antibiotics for a synergistically improved antimicrobial activity and/or for the preservation/potentiation of the potency of current antibiotics. If this strategy can be demonstrated to be both effective and safe, this research will address, at least partially, the serious problem of emerging antibiotic resistance by providing a much-needed innovative strategy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Remarkably, 25% of patients with fatty liver disease (FLD) are lean and compared to non-lean (overweight and obese) individuals with FLD, they have a two-fold increased risk of cardiovascular and liver-related mortality. Our goal is to understand convergent and divergent features of lean and non-lean FLD, by comparing associated clinical and genetic risk factors in those with and without substantial alcohol exposure in the VA Million Veteran Program (MVP). This project will assemble the largest ever multi-ancestry cohort of persons with and without FLD based on the application of Automatic Liver Attenuation Region-of-interest-based Measurement (ALARM), a deep learning tool to clinically obtained non-contrast abdominal CT scans. This work has the potential to substantially improve our understanding of the clinical and genetic drivers of FLD in a quarter of those affected. Given the large number of such patients within the VA health system and their increased mortality, this work has the potential to significantly impact the practice of clinical medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life exposures to neurotoxic metals may disrupt children’s sleep, which may be mediated by circulating extracellular vesicles and their microRNA and metabolite cargoes. We will study the relationship between extracellular vesicle cargo and sleep disruption during the first 10–12 years of life in a well-defined birth cohort. Our focus on early-life exposures has important implications—our study may inform stricter regulations for complex metal mixtures and will help direct public health interventions to specific time windows with high plasticity, i.e., prenatal and early life, when simple interventions could have long-lasting health benefits that impact the entire life course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will investigate the use of bacteriophage, which are viruses that infect and kill bacteria, to treat Mycobacterium abscessus (Mabs) infection. Using a preclinical model, we will study in vivo phage exposure (pharmacokinetics, PK) and its impact on Mabs infection (pharmacodynamics, PD) to build an in silico quantitative systems pharmacology (QSP) model that can be used to design effective phage dosing strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Over the last 5 years, we have finished a “first-in-human” clinical trial of an oncolytic viral immunotherapy in subjects with Glioblastoma (GBM) one of the most lethal cancers. We found that subject survival correlated with viral serology with biologic and immunologic evidence of significant immune activation. Coming back to the lab, we will study in mouse models of GBM if the pre-existent memory immune response to the injected oncolytic virus contributes to tumor rejection, as implied by our clinical trial findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pediatric brain cancers are the most deadly of childhood cancers, and limited treatment options exist. We seek to identify new avenues for treatment by performing analysis of existing pediatric brain tumor datasets using novel approaches that will explore gene networks within these tumors and will interrogate how the tumors communicate with the normal brain around them. Additionally, we will leverage new data generated from the normal, developing human brain to compare and contrast with the tumor data in an effort to more carefully pinpoint how these tumors emerge and what strategies are likely to effectively treat these pediatric brain cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells employ a number of different DNA repair pathways to tolerate chemical agents that damage their genomic DNA. Of particular importance is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) which is the primary pathway in humans that rejoins DNA double strand breaks. This project employs advanced microscopy approaches to understand the mechanism by which the NHEJ pathway functions normally and how its inappropriate use contributes to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO RIO PIEDRAS
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to obtain an electron paramagnetic resonance instrument to boost the research productivity and biomedical educational training in Puerto Rico focused on characterizing paramagnetic species related to human health. In the body, many biomolecules are paramagnetic and their direct study can help to understand abnormalities that can lead to disease, to the discovery of new drugs, or to design optimal delivery of therapeutics or diagnostic agents. The research team of this project has diverse specializations, which will be applied to create new biochemistry course laboratory experiences, develop MRI contrast agents, electronic devices, and metal- based anticancer drugs, and to better understand biomolecular interactions that regulate important proteins and the diseases of cancer, HIV-1, myocardial infarction, and Huntington’s.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall cancer mortality has decreased in the U.S. owing in part to significant progress in novel cancer therapeutics designed around new discoveries of how to harness the body’s immune response to cancer. Unfortunately, not all individuals with cancer have benefited equitably from this success, such as Hispanic/Latino (H/L) patients, in whom disparities in cancer outcomes are rooted, in some respects, in the development of these novel therapeutics. This project enables an integrative analysis of demographic, and clinical data combined with multi-omics approaches using longitudinal blood samples and tumor tissue from H/L patients with breast cancer to identify novel differences in the tumor immune microenvironments which will inform specific cellular immune targets that could significantly improve clinical trial design targeted for H/L patients and affect eligibility criteria for approved immune therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall cancer mortality has decreased in the U.S. owing in part to significant progress in novel cancer therapeutics designed around new discoveries of how to harness the body’s immune response to cancer. Unfortunately, not all individuals with cancer have benefited equitably from this success, such as Hispanic/Latino (H/L) patients, in whom disparities in cancer outcomes are rooted, in some respects, in the development of these novel therapeutics. This project enables an integrative analysis of demographic, and clinical data combined with multi-omics approaches using longitudinal blood samples and tumor tissue from H/L patients with breast cancer to identify novel differences in the tumor immune microenvironments which will inform specific cellular immune targets that could significantly improve clinical trial design targeted for H/L patients and affect eligibility criteria for approved immune therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Corneal collagen crosslinking (CXL) is a cutting-edge therapy for progressive eye disease such as keratoconus, resulting in increased corneal stiffness; however, there are currently no non-contact techniques that quantitatively map corneal anisotropic elastic moduli, making it difficult to build personalized treatment plans and evaluate outcomes. Leveraging results obtained in R01 EY026532, the goal of this project is to develop a non-contact, non-invasive clinical instrument for pre-operative characterization and evaluation of post- operative outcomes in CXL treatment of keratoconus in the cornea based on Optical Coherence Tomography and Elastography. We will simultaneously map geometric (thickness and shape) and elastic properties of the cornea in vivo starting with a CXL rabbit model, continuing in healthy volunteers, and finishing in keratoconus patients pre-operatively, immediately after surgery and longitudinally post-operatively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The public-health significance of the proposed work is an advance in our understanding of the efferent half of the auditory system, or the neurons that carry signals from the brain back to the inner ear. We will use physiological, psychophysical, emissions, and computational modeling strategies to test our hypothesis that the subcortical efferent system “sharpens” or clarifies the perceptions of complex sounds, such as speech. We will also test the impact of sensorineural hearing loss on the function of the efferent system. This work will lead to novel approaches to dynamically control amplification in assistive devices such as hearing aids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is a potential cure for many life-threatening blood diseases but is frequently complicated by chronic graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD). Skin changes are the most common and earliest sign, with disease assessment requiring time-consuming specialist examination. We will validate artificial intelligence technology for the automatic staging and monitoring of cGVHD from patient photographs, which can improve clinical trials and patient outcomes by replacing in-person skin assessments. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression and anxiety during and after pregnancy are common medical complications contributing to a rising maternal mortality rate. Home visiting programs can offer evidence-based interventions to improve mental health outcomes for a vulnerable pregnant population; however, barriers remain to achieving the full potential of these interventions. Our work will explore the impact of context on the implementation of a mental health intervention to provide action-based and impactful data that focuses on the lived experiences of the diverse populations served by home visiting programs in Iowa and Indiana.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in our knowledge of the causes and risk factors associated with periodontitis, it remains widely prevalent. The total expenditure on treating and preventing periodontal diseases is estimated in billions of dollars. Determining microbial changes that lead of periodontitis progression or periodontal stability would better inform clinicians regarding diagnosis, prevention, treatment and monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency (AATD) related chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is an aging sensitive inherited disease with onset and progression resulting from misfolding of variant (mutant) forms of AAT in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) leading to gain-of-toxic aggregation in the liver and subsequent loss-of- function of neutrophil elastase (NE) inhibitory activity in serum and lung tissue- triggering progressive liver and lung failure by mid-to-late decades of life. This proposal addresses how specific branches of the protein folding machinery (proteostasis) involving the unfolded protein response (UPR) ATF6 and IRE1/XBP1s signaling pathways can be manipulated by chemical activators to protect the patient from disease in response to the diverse AAT variants encoded in the genome of the world-wide population by combined chemical, experimental and computational Gaussian process (GP) regression machine learning tools. We hypothesize that ATF6 and IRE1/XBP1s signaling pathways can be used to develop a new class of AAT folding correctors for nearly the entire spectrum of the AAT variant patient population, providing new mechanistic insights into the role of AAT in human liver and lung health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Skeletal muscle atrophy is a serious consequence of many diseases and conditions for which there are no effective pharmaceutical therapies. The E3 ubiquitin ligase, MuRF1, is associated with multiple forms of atrophy and deletion can lead to partial muscle sparing. Identification of the in vivo substrates targeted by MuRF1 for ubiquitylation is a critical next step in advancing our understanding of the mechanisms by which MuRF1 regulates skeletal muscle mass, and could lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is designed to investigate how calcium build-up (calcification) in brain blood vessels produces injury to the brain. Calcified arteries have limited capacity to react normally (constrict and dilate) and this incapacity contributes to impairment of blood flow to the brain. We will delineate the extent of brain injury due to calcified blood vessels in autopsy human brain and in a mouse model by studying a high-risk population (chronic kidney disease in aging) and take the first steps to reduce brain vascular calcification with specific drug treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative This project aims to refine and evaluate EXPO (EXecutive function Play Opportunities), a new caregiver- mediated intervention designed to support the development of executive function in children with Down syndrome. In this R61/33, we will continue the intervention development process by transforming EXPO into an adaptive intervention, with modifications for children who show greater degrees of developmental delay and who may respond more slowly to EXPO. We will then test the restructured EXPO adaptive intervention with a two- arm, Singly Randomized Trial that will evaluate the effectiveness of EXPO pathways.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In collaboration with the Altino Ventura Foundation, RTI International will continue to evaluate the impact of severe congenital Zika syndrome (CZS) on the development and well-being of 187 children and their families as the children enter middle childhood and enroll in school, focusing on the evolution of structural features of CZS (brain, ocular, orthopedic), long-term medical, developmental and mental health outcomes for children and their families, and predictors of these outcomes. Through this research, we will better understand the natural history of CZS and any factors that may be associated with specific health outcomes, which will help inform and prepare the global community to better support children and families currently living with CZS, potential future cases of CZS, and children impacted by other conditions with similar clinical findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Coronary heart disease is the leading cause of death in the U.S, and patients have a high risk for cardiac arrhythmias after surviving a myocardial infarction. Spatial heterogeneity of sympathetic nerves, including denervation, is a major contributor to post-infarct cardiac arrhythmias. The studies proposed here will restore cardiac sympathetic nerves using novel therapeutics and will determine the diverse mechanisms by which reinnervation prevents arrhythmias and alters cardiac inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Treatment of schizophrenia with antipsychotics must be closely monitored to avoid side effects arising from excessive use of medication. We are developing a new PET radiotracer which can be used to determine a patient’s response to antipsychotic treatment. This will ultimately improve patient`s lives, and make a greater impact on drug therapy and management of psychosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic diversity is a key factor underlying heterogenous disease states of tuberculosis. However, current mouse models fail to incorporate both genetic and phenotypic diversity. This proposal leverages diverse but reproducible Collaborative Cross mouse strains, bacterial reporters of infection and novel host-pathogen genetic mapping strategies to mechanistically define loci underlying disease tolerance. Overall, these novel and synergistic strategies will define new models of disease tolerance and set the roadmap for systematically interrogating host-pathogen genetic interactions underlying tuberculosis.

PROJECT_TITLE: Dissecting the genetic basis of protective immunity to tuberculosis in diverse hosts

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE In the last few decades clinical radiation therapy (RT) technology has developed dramatically, with intensity modulated RT (IMRT) representing one of the most significant advances, however, these advancements have not translated to preclinical small animal RT, which largely resembles the state of clinical RT in the 1970s in terms of its use of simple circular/rectangular beam geometries, uniform beam intensities, and lack of high quality 3D target dose conformality. Consequently, small animal RT studies do not allow for accurate 3D dose targeting or simulate the radiobiological, radioimmunological, hypoxic and toxicity environment of modern human RT. The goal of this proposed project is to create a novel 3D printed compensator IMRT (3DPC-IMRT) system that is low cost, easy to implement, and can allow high mouse throughput.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with Down syndrome (DS) experience premature aging and high rates of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and associated declines in physical function which are associated with increased caregiver burden. Interventions to increase physical activity may improve or maintain physical function in aging adults with DS and reduce burden on their caregivers, who are often parents facing their own age-related functional declines. This project will adapt an evidence-based intervention developed for use in typically developed adults with AD which combines physical activity and caregiver training in behavioral symptom management to the needs of those with DS and evaluate the potential for the adapted intervention to improve functional and health parameters in adults with DS and reduce caregiver burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To decrease symptom burden and maximize their quality of life, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients need to master skills that facilitate self-management—the daily behaviors individuals must perform to keep their illness under control, minimize its impact on their physical health, and cope with comorbid or resulting psychological symptoms. In alignment with the National Institute of Health’s mission to improve people’s health and quality of life, this study proposes to develop an intervention that is designed to support patients with active IBD in self- management and improve their care, symptoms, and quality of life. This approach will provide insights for feasible and acceptable self-management interventions with adaptability to diverse IBD populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Short organ preservation time imposes severe constraints on transplantation, contributes to reduced organ availability and high discard rates, diminishes organ quality while exacerbating graft rejection, and limits the length and quality of life for transplant recipients. The overarching goal of this project is to develop means for organ preservation in cryogenic temperature, with a focus on the liver due to its high priority need. This project focuses on an innovative approach of creating more favorable conditions for cryopreservation by elevating the pressure surrounding the organ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-associated Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection is associated with a dysregulated cytokine response (a “cytokine storm”) that is thought to underlie severe disease. While the cell types, genes, and viral factors that initiate this aberrant response are incompletely understood, tools to investigate pulmonary alveolar cell type-specific phenotypes are also limited. To gain a deeper understanding of events precipitating the SARS-CoV-2-associated cytokine storm and other fundamental aspects of alveolar immune responses, we will establish innovative mouse models that integrate cell type-specific targeted gene editing with unbiased pooled CRISPR/Cas9 library screening approaches in both infected respiratory epithelial cells and alveolar macrophages in close proximity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative IPUMS NHGIS data are advancing fundamental knowledge about health and population dynamics. NHGIS directly supports rigorous and reproducible research on health, disease, and development across the lifespan by simplifying access to the geographic census data that are essential for measuring key social determinants of health. NHGIS data provide the denominators required for the spatial analysis of epidemiological and demographic change; it is impossible to interpret the incidence of disease or death without knowing the population at risk.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is a chronic and debilitating psychiatric condition associated with functional impairment and decreased quality of life. Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the gold standard behavioral treatment for OCD. However, few Veterans receive this treatment within the VHA. There is a lack of research evaluating barriers and facilitators to the implementation of ERP in VHA. With respect to the implementation of ERP, mixed-methods economic evaluations can aid stakeholders by evaluating whether implementing ERP is worth the investment in costs both quantitatively, through cost-effectiveness analysis, and qualitatively, via interviews with individuals who can provide context-specific information on the resources required for implementation. The parent trial to this supplement seeks to evaluate the effectiveness of ERP compared to a control condition, Stress Management Training (SMT), on Veteran functioning. The current supplement proposes to add a mixed-methods economic evaluation of ERP for OCD in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hypertension is the leading cause of cardiovascular diseases worldwide. This study aims to investigate the role of endothelial progranulin and its autocrine actions on regulating endothelial function and blood pressure. By using cutting-edge technology such as genetically modified mice, gain and loss-of-function experiments, and best methods to study vascular function and blood pressure, we are expecting to place progranulin as novel therapeutic target for cardiovascular diseases associated with hypertension.

PHR: Project Narrative: Antibiotic treatment failure is a major global public health threat. In addition to acquiring antibiotic resistance, bacteria can transiently reprogram their phenotype, which bolsters their ability to survive high-dose antibiotic treatment. This work will enhance our knowledge of how interactions with a host's microbiome impact bacterial responses and susceptibly to different classes of antibiotics, which can potentially improve our ability to treat recurrent infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotic-resistant bacteria, such as vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) and methicillin- resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), are major causes of hospital-acquired infections and contribute to an escalating healthcare crisis. The research proposed here promises to reveal new insights into the biological processes driving antibiotic resistance that will facilitate the development of new treatments for infections caused by drug-resistant pathogens. In particular, this work promises to define new targets for innovative therapeutics with potentially unique modes of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inequities in access to power, resources, and services based on structural racism and discrimination (SRD), can manifest as policies and practices that can cause psychological distress, elevated allostatic load, and elevated risk of chronic diseases for Black and Latinx populations. While the connection between SRD and health is well documented, few studies provide evidence on strategies to reduce SRD and mitigate consequences on psychological and physiological outcomes. This project uses a randomized, behavioral clinical trial to test racial justice activism (RJA) as an effective intervention to mitigate depression and allostatic load in Black and Latinx adolescents and young adults, impacted by SRD.

PHR: Project Narrative The loud operating room (OR) environment is a distinct threat to unobstructed communication between OR team members that compromises patient safety. The current proposal will develop interventions surrounding overlapping conversations and environmental noise using a systems approach to prevent, mitigate, and recover from miscommunication. These interventions will provide an essential foundation for improving OR team communication and enhancing patient safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The meniscus plays a vital role in knee function and is prone to injury, but the cellular mechanisms regulating its development, maturation and maintenance are poorly understood. This project seeks to fill this knowledge gap by elucidating the role of cellular force generation and mechanosensing in regulating embryonic meniscus patterning, cell fate determination and matrix specialization during embryonic-to-early postnatal growth, and in maintaining cell phenotype in the adult meniscus. Results will establish the mechanobiological basis that regulates the meniscus development and homeostasis, providing new insight to direct regenerative strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T cells are specialized white blood cells that can recognize and destroy tumors in response to cancer immunotherapy treatments. We recently found that a protein called Bhlhe40 is required by T cells for tumor regression in response to immune checkpoint immunotherapy and our goal is to understand how Bhlhe40 regulates T cells to enable them to eliminate tumors under certain conditions. We anticipate this work will provide insights that will lead to development of improved cancer immunotherapies that are needed, as many cancer patients do not experience clinical benefit from current immunotherapy treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes in ion channel biophysics due to mutation or disease-associated remodeling are frequently assessed in isolated cells; yet translation of these findings for therapeutic target development is difficult and often fails due to the inherent lack of tissue-scale regulation in isolated cell experimental models. Our prior work has shown that ion concentration changes in extracellular nanodomains adjacent to gap junctions localized at cell-cell junctions (i.e., the intercalated disc) – which are inherently disrupted in isolated cells – regulate cardiac tissue responses in the setting of sodium channel gain-of-function. In this proposal, we will utilize computational modeling (novel structurally detailed tissue models) and experiments (isolated cells, ex vivo hearts, and in vivo genetically- modified mice and peptide-treated guinea pigs) to test the hypothesis that extracellular ion concentrations can serve as biomarkers for electrophysiological responses that are specifically sensitive in settings of genetic and acquired sodium channel gain-of-function, in contrast with current conventional sentiment that extracellular ion concentrations are broad markers of cardiovascular health independent of potential ion channel dysfunction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women affected by genital fistula experience significant physical and psychosocial morbidity associated with the condition, and nascent evidence suggests subsequent adverse outcomes occur after surgical repair (i.e., fistula repair breakdown or recurrence and incontinence). To identify salient targets for clinical and counselling interventions to improve women’s health and quality of life following fistula repair, we seek to understand the contribution of individual, fistula-related, and post-repair behaviors and exposures to these adverse outcomes. Subsequent and iterative work with key stakeholders will help us develop a road map of intervention strategies likely to be feasible and acceptable within the study population and setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Three important responses that influence the outcome of post-viral bacterial pneumonia are: (1) IFN-I signaling that accompanies viral infection, (2) hyperactive inflammation, and antibacterial effects of macrophages and neutrophils, all of which are influenced by T403 phosphorylation of STAT2 induced by viral infection. We will define how T403 phosphorylation of STAT2 exacerbates the severity of post-viral bacterial pneumonia and facilitate novel therapeutic approaches to rebalance the immune response toward antibacterial clearance and away from pneumonia-associated lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies aim to substantially advance our basic understanding of how word meaning is represented in the brain. They investigate the extent to which different types of information (sensory-motor, affective, taxonomic, distributional) contribute to the representational code underlying word semantics, and how different cortical regions support those representations. Understanding this complex and particularly human brain system is a necessary step for developing principled and effective interventions for patients with semantic language impairments or speech paralysis, including future therapies involving modulatory stimulation, brain-computer interfaces, and biological repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The link between lung health and cardiovascular disease (CVD), the leading cause of death in women in the US, is well-established, and pregnancy is a critical window to intervene on racial-ethnic inequities in lifecourse chronic disease risk in women. Exposure to place-based structural racism may result in a pro-inflammatory state during pregnancy and impair postpartum cardiopulmonary health (CV and lung health) setting the stage for future chronic disease risk. To better understand the mechanisms of action and effect of place-based structural racism during pregnancy on future cardiopulmonary health, we propose Gen C Mamas, a mixed- method longitudinal study of 440 underrepresented and understudied Black, Hispanic, and Asian (Global Majority) women from the Generation C cohort, initially recruited during pregnancy in 2020-2022 in New York City.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project fills 4 crucial public health gaps: 1) how breast milk changes over time and over the day, 2) how milk dynamics effect infant sleep patterns, 3) how milk dynamics effect infant microbiome dynamics, and 4) how all these relationships differ between infants fed directly at-the-breast vs pumped milk. These fundamental insights have been unknown until now, so that families who feed pumped breast milk are completely underserved. These results are critical to optimizing infant feeding and health outcomes for all infants receiving breast milk.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal directly addresses the need for new pharmacological treatments to prevent intellectual disability in Down syndrome. Defining how human chromosome 21 genes interact synergistically to drive abnormal brain development and function will reveal critical underlying pathways and new protein targets. Using the high- throughput larval zebrafish will support systematic characterization of many genetic contributions and discovery of lead molecules through whole-organism compound screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We seek to develop and test in animal models a strategy to prevent metastatic disease from solid tumors and treat existing micrometastatic disease. We are leveraging the new era of systemically administered gene therapy, originally developed for treating genetic disorders, to achieve continuous, long-term expression of an immunotherapy, thus exerting constant pressure on the cancer cells and reducing their chances to develop resistance and escape from therapy. If successful, our work will lead to clinical trials and potential markedly reduce the burden of cancer by leading to prolonged patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Although estrogen decreases in all women during menopause, an increase in blood pressure occurs in many, but not all women. The factors affecting whether and by how much the blood pressure increases during menopause are unknown. This project investigates changes during women’s midlife in a hormonal system called the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, with findings likely to change ideas about optimal treatment of high blood pressure in older women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE We aim to harmonize and link large-scale cross-sectional and panel survey data from a population of underserved service-sector workers during the pandemic with establishment- and area-level data and to make this integrated dataset openly available for research. We will use this linked data to estimate the degree to which the expanded safety net buffered any negative effects of unemployment on health during the pandemic. We also propose to examine the influence of both public and company policies on masking and paid sick leave on adherence to coronavirus mitigation practices, and how these relationships vary by age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypothyroidism is a common disorder that requires lifelong treatment with thyroid hormone replacement. Many patients with hypothyroidism still have hypothyroid symptoms while taking standard-of-care therapy with levothyroxine at recommended doses. This proposal will generate pilot and feasibility data required to design a large randomized, placebo-controlled trial of combination therapy with levothyroxine and liothyronine in patients with hypothyroidism who have residual symptoms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative The goal of this project is to understand the cellular, molecular and mechanical basis of body axis formation during embryonic development. This knowledge is expected to impact our understanding of birth defects of the trunk and limbs and could shed light on the biology of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: High blood pressure, also known as hypertension, is a serious condition that needs to be treated because it can lead to stroke, heart attack, and organ failure. Our research has discovered, for the first time, how certain immune cells called T cells are activated and move into the kidneys during the early stage of hypertension, and become long-lasting memory cells resident in the kidney, which contribute to the progression of hypertension and hypertensive memory of salt-sensitivity. By understanding the important molecules involved in this process, we can identify new targets for developing treatments for hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In spite of the development of new treatments, we still have only a poor understanding of the mechanisms of migraine. One basic question is whether the headache phase of migraine depends on processes occurring in the peripheral or the central nervous system. Clarifying this question has the potential to alter the focus of treatment as well as drug development to central targets in combination with peripherally acting drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Studying model organisms with superior regenerative capacities, such as the newt, could uncover critical mechanisms that have been long-coveted for regenerative therapeutics. In this proposal, we will use cutting- edge techniques to dissect the precise molecular roadmap that enables newt iris cells to replace lost lenses. In doing so, we will reveal regeneration secrets never before disclosed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because this work will provide a new perspective on the molecular pathogenesis of Down syndrome (DS), the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability, which will enable the identification of new drug targets and provide an approach to test candidate therapies to prevent developmental delay and cognitive impairment in individuals with DS. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission “to seek fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems and the applica- tion of that knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.” This work will also help to achieve goals of the NIH INvestigation of Co-occurring conditions across the Lifespan to Understand Down syndrome (INCLUDE) Project to “improve understanding of the biology of Down syndrome and support development of new treatments for health conditions experienced by individuals with Down syndrome.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed studies focus on schistosomiasis, a significant, unmet medical need in 78 endemic countries, with more than 200 million people infected, 20 million with significant morbidity, and more than 200,000 deaths annually. Current schistosomiasis control strategies rely almost exclusively on chemotherapy; there is only one available drug and it is inevitable that drug-resistant parasites will evolve. The proposed research will exploit differences in redox defenses between schistosome worms and humans to discover and optimize small molecule inhibitors to selectively disrupt worm redox for new treatments for schistosomiasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Vagal nerve stimulation therapy has been approved for three central nervous system disorders but large patient trials for heart failure have failed despite promising preclinical evidence of success. We propose that appropriate consideration of vagal afferent central transmission is key to designing optimally effective therapeutic protocols for vagal nerve stimulation. Our preliminary evidence suggests that signals from the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus contribute to therapeutic efficacy in heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little is known about how language and motor skills interact in the early development of infants with Down Syndrome (DS). This project will follow infants (6 to 18 months) with and without DS for 12 months to measure language and motor trajectories using a multiple-method approach. The results from this study will inform intervention priorities and strategies to support early development in DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although parenting interventions can improve the mental health and well-being for both parents and their young children, these intended benefits do not occur for many families. This proposed K23 study will use a prospective, single-arm clinical trial to evaluate potential predictors (i.e., parental executive functioning difficulties and adverse social determinants of health) of suboptimal response and then use mixed methods approaches to identify potential intervention adaptations driven by parent and clinician input. Findings will guide the next R01 proposal testing if adaptations identified within this K23 proposal enhance the effectiveness of parenting interventions at improving parent (e.g., harsh parenting, parenting stress) and child outcomes (e.g., externalizing concerns, irritability).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic rhinosinusitis is estimated to affect 10-12% of American adults and is one of the top ten most costly medical conditions in the United States. It is associated with severe but variable quality of life detriment, and this study’s focus on individualized treatment outcomes will help understand receptiveness to machine learning/artificial intelligence in clinical care, illuminate disease phenotypes, inform personalized clinical decision-making, and improve patient satisfaction. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge that will enhance health, reduce illness and disability, and enhance quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The synaptic vesicle protein 2 (SV2) family is crucial for proper neurotransmission and is the molecular target for two clinical antiepileptic drugs. Mutations in human SV2 are linked to epilepsy, and deletion of the SV2 gene in mice causes severe seizures and death. Understanding the structures, functions and molecular mechanisms of this important protein family will lead to new therapies for epilepsy.

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed work is relevant to NIH’s mission statement because it seeks to dissect the precise mechanisms by which RNA editing enzyme ADAR1 regulates gene expression and contributes to malignant T-cell leukemia initiating cell propagation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The goal of this research study is to examine the biology and efficacy of Siglec-6 in reducing or preventing mast cell activation via several distinct stimulatory pathways and delivering therapeutic cargo selectively to mast cells both in vitro and in several mouse models of mast cell-dependent diseases, incorporating transgenic mice expressing the human Siglec-6 receptor and humanized mice bearing a human mast cell line. Siglec-6, as a receptor found at high levels on human mast cells in the skin, lung, adipose tissue, and colon and on all mast cell lines that we have analyzed and on few other hematopoietic cells, offers critical advantages over the related receptor Siglec-8, which we have studied as a target on eosinophils and mast cells, but which is not as selectively or consistently expressed on mast cells and is not as effective in inhibiting mast cell activation. Knowledge of the signaling and endocytic pathways of the receptor, as well as the efficacy of distinct approaches to mast cell targeting in vitro and in vivo, would provide important insights into potential treatments of diseases and conditions involving mast cells, such as anaphylaxis, pseudoallergic drug reactions, mast cell-dependent cutaneous inflammation, and systemic mastocytosis, for which there is a clinical need for disease-modifying or curative therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative St. Mary’s University is a Hispanic-serving institution in San Antonio, TX that serves students primarily from South Texas. Despite being a resource-limited institution receiving well under $6 million in research funding from the National Institutes of Health, it has a strong record of developing the biomedical workforce and preparing graduates for STEM and health careers. Access to a state-of- the-art scientific flow cytometry instrument that can assess cells or particles for wide range of characteristics, will invigorate current research at St. Mary’s; contribute to opportunities for new research projects; stimulate collaborations; attract, recruit, and retain new faculty to St. Mary’s; develop critical thinking and technical skills in students; and enhance STEM education.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is common, chronic and often difficult to treat disorder that results in prolonged and disabling effects in an estimated 2-3% of the general population, during their lifetime. It manifests in a variety of compulsions and obsessions but the neural mechanisms underlying the disorder or its differentiations remain unclear. In this project, we leverage model-based analysis of behavior and fMRI activity, jointly with brain network analysis, with the aim to provide a more comprehensive understanding of brain dynamics underlying OCD symptom severity and phenotypization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to viral and bacterial infections represents a leading risk factor in asthma exacerbations, but individual variability in response, and the role of multi-omics in this response, is not well-understood, particularly across the life course. Characterization of virulent exposures through PhIP-Seq profiling in well-characterized child and adult asthma cohorts with existing genetic, epigenetic, and metabolomic data provides an ideal opportunity to leverage novel integrative omic methods, specifically cooperative learning, to increase our understanding of the impact of these virulent exposures, their interactions with individual biology reflected by multi-omics, and their consequences for asthma exacerbations. We apply PhIP-Seq in existing cohorts with minimal cost to this proposal, identify virulent and multi-omic factors with the highest contributions to asthma exacerbations, and develop universal and personalized predictive models to understand the interplay between these factors and to assess risk with respect to individual variability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in pediatric oncology treatment and research, our understanding of the genetic etiology of pediatric cancers remains incomplete. We propose to undertake a first-of-its-kind analysis of pediatric cancer pleiotropy, identifying genetic variations that contribute to risks for multiple pediatric cancer types. We will also examine the shared heritability of pediatric cancers with the first comprehensive study of global pleiotropy patterns for pediatric cancer risk, and develop enhanced genetic risk score tools with pleiotropic risk variants to better predict who may develop pediatric cancer and inform personalized treatment, surveillance, and interventions to reduce morbidity and mortality after pediatric cancer diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health  This research in humans will investigate the consequences of chronic neuropathic pain on the cardiovascular health of this ever-growing patient population. We will study mechanisms possibly mediating this impact and the potential of a currently utilized treatment option for neuropathic pain (i.e., spinal cord stimulation, SCS) to improve the cardiovascular health in these patients, particularly in those with high blood pressure (hypertension). If this project can, as suggested by our preliminary findings, confirm a significant impact of chronic pain on the cardiovascular system and that SCS can improve these impairments, particularly in patients with with hypertension, the proposed studies will provide the scientific basis required to associate SCS with significant cardiovascular health benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Accurate insertion of a thin, long needle is crucial for successful biopsy and focal treatment of prostate cancer, though it is a challenging task for physicians as the needle can be easily deflected from the target due to bending in the tissue. This project aims to improve needle placement accuracy by developing a novel shape- sensing needle and needle-guiding manipulator, which adaptively compensates for deflection while a physician inserts a needle. These new technologies will reduce the error in targeting abnormal lesions with the needle and improve outcomes of prostate biopsy and focal treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Age-Related meibomian gland dysfunction (ARMGD) is a common eyelid disorder having a widespread prevalence of 39-50% in the US population and is a major cause of evaporative dry eye disease in the aging population. Our studies suggest a 'meibocyte centric' hypothesis for the development of ARMGD involving mechanisms that regulate meibocyte stem/progenitor cell renewal and differentiation lead to acinar atrophy, while only secondarily affecting the ductal epithelium. 1) That direct loss of Pparg signaling leads to an age and sex dependent loss of meibocyte differentiation, acinar atrophy and dry eye disease; 2) That Pparg signaling transcriptionally regulates meibocyte differentiation that when lost leads to up-regulation of ductal epithelial differentiation in progenitor meibocytes; 3) That loss of meibocyte progenitor cells recapitulates loss of Pparg leading to loss of meibocyte differentiation, acinar atrophy, and dry eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Diseases like diabetic and chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy, and Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), involve the dysfunction and loss of axons, connections with the spinal cord that allow for muscle control and sensation. The cellular machinery that regulates axon destruction also affects nerve inflammation, which contributes to disease. We will explore the relationships between this machinery and cells that participate in inflammation with a goal of developing disease treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Given the persistently stark racial/ethnic disparities in perinatal health outcomes in the U.S. and the increasing utilization of fertility treatment to achieve pregnancy, the overall goal of the MOSART EQUITY study is to apply a health equity framework to investigate the experiences and outcomes of minoritized women who receive fertility treatment and achieve a live birth. Utilizing an explanatory sequential mixed-methods study design, we will employ both quantitative and qualitative methodology to investigate the population-level prevalence and factors associated with racial/ethnic disparities in maternal and infant outcomes after fertility treatment among those who have experienced a live birth in Massachusetts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Eosinophilic Esophagitis is a chronic immune-mediated disorder of the esophagus affecting all ages that has emerged as a common cause of problematic swallowing. Patients with markers of severe disease including stricture/narrowing and esophageal fibrosis have worse symptoms and are more resistant to current treatments. This pilot study aims to compare two available treatments, dupilumab and swallowed fluticasone, in their ability to treat fibrostenotic EoE so as to establish essential data to apply towards pivotal comparative trials with the ensuing goal of informing patients and providers on the comparative benefits and downsides of alternative treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the detailed organization of cortical circuits involving specific neuron types is necessary to obtain a mechanistic understanding of the function of the cerebral cortex. Understanding the specific roles of genetically accessed neuron types in cortical function has important implications for human health, as these cell types and their activities are implicated in the cortical mechanisms that regulate attention and their disruption is implicated in schizophrenia and autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Diabetic retinopathy is a common complication of diabetes and the leading cause of blindness in the working age population. Fenofibrate is the first oral drug ever with proven effects on diabetic retinopathy in type 2 diabetic patients by two independent clinical studies. This project will elucidate the mechanism responsible for the therapeutic effect of fenofibrate on diabetic retinopathy and facilitate the FDA approval of this oral drug treatment for diabetic retinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: R01 – PROJECT NARRATIVE A central objective of this project is to characterize the signal transduction pathways activated by the binding of antibodies to HLAI and HLAII in human primary endothelial cells (ECs) and assess their contribution to the proliferation, migration of these cells and in promoting the recruitment of leukocytes in the context of transplant rejection. The mechanistic studies with ECs will be complemented using a novel mouse model of chronic antibody-mediated rejection (cAMR) and human cardiac allografts with transplant vasculopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dental caries is a complex infectious disease with multiple genetic and environmental risk factors posing a major health burden globally. The goal of this proposal is to provide insight into the structure, dynamic interactions and multifunctionality of ameloblastin protein, and hence to contribute to the fundamental knowledge as relevant to enamel formation, and to understanding of inherited diseases of enamel and genetic factors that affect caries susceptibility. Insight gained from the proposed studies will contribute to biomimetic efforts to regenerate and reconstruct dental hard tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The tooth root is essential for the proper function of the dentition because it anchors the tooth within the jaw bone, transmits occlusal forces, and provides a passageway for nerves and vasculature. However, little is known about how tooth root patterning and development are regulated. We have designed studies to uncover the signaling mechanism that regulates the fate of progenitor cells during tooth root development and patterning, which will advance stem cell-mediated tooth root regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: In this project, we will investigate how health disparities may affect immunotherapy for breast cancer. The Research Project will use a combination of registry data, clinical trials data, matched gene expression and genotype data and single nuclear analysis to investigate various ways that disparities can affect response to immune checkpoint inhibitors across populations. The Administrative Core will support interactions among the investigators and plan future projects leveraging the results from the research project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application conducts basic and translational research aimed at the identification of therapeutic strategies to reduce intestinal failure-associated liver disease (IFALD) that occurs after resection of long stretches of bowel, which may arise in children, for example, that present with necrotizing enterocolitis after birth. Specifically, we will evaluate whether intestinal epithelial activation of the transcription factor LXRα may provide therapeutic benefit toward treating IFALD and, if so, we aim to identify its mechanism of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delirium is a devasting acute confusional state that is common in older adults after surgery or in the hospital, especially with Alzheimer’s disease. This project investigates the molecular mechanisms that link inflammation to impaired metabolism in delirium and Alzheimer’s disease, and how small molecule metabolites with roles in aging might lead to metabolic therapies for delirium.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The risk to benefit ratio of cardiovascular medications can change as people age and develop chronic conditions like Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. This research will evaluate the frequency and outcomes of cardiovascular medication changes among people with and without dementia who enter nursing homes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative My research program is devoted to understanding fundamental mechanisms of genome integrity control and how they impact cancer etiology and response to therapy. We will continue to approach these central questions in cancer biology by utilizing unique systems that we have developed to investigate the molecular basis underlying (1) DNA damage recognition, (2) genomic lesions that activate classical and alternative forms of homology directed DNA repair, and (3) response to targeted agents. These pursuits will provide invaluable insights into cancers that arise as a consequence of altered usage of DNA repair pathways, and their adaptive responses to DNA damaging therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Lungu, Claudiu T. Narrative: The Deep South Center for Occupational Health and Safety (DSC) was established in 1982 as an Education and Research Center with the participation of two major Universities, University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) and Auburn University (AU). The mission of the DSC is to Train and develop professionals who protect and promote the health and safety of workers through interdisciplinary education, training, research and outreach. Recognizing the OSH burden that affects disproportionally racial and ethnic minority groups as well as disadvantaged communities and individuals, the DSC will focus on minimizing this burden while striving to eliminate disparities showing our commitment to DEI. IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR TOXIC SUBSTANCES AND DISEASE REGISTRY
PHR: Project Narrative We will take advantage of a new extremely large linked Department of Defense and Veterans Administration database to examine the association between military experience and both incidence of and survival with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). We will also assess how use of statins relates to ALS incidence and survival and whether their use protects against adverse effects of any military exposures.

ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Occupational safety and health specialists are critical to ensuring the safety and health of the nation’s worksites and workforce. This program addresses the shortage of qualified occupational safety and health professionals by delivering a high-quality program and successful graduates who meet the ever-growing industry demand. Program faculty integrate emerging issues related to workplace health and safety in the training of future OHS leaders.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a top public-health priority. Training the next generation of clinician scientists and translational scholars is critical to tackle the dire consequences of AMR. After building a successful patient-oriented and translational program on AMR with a major training component, I plan to leverage these resources to expand my training, research and leadership capabilities in AMR, contributing to solve this major public health crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social attachments form the basis of human relationships at every level of social organization, and disruptions in attachment occur across the spectrum of mental illness, with severe neuropsychiatric disorders often manifesting with a dramatic collapse of social attachment and cognition. While pioneering work identified the peptide hormones vasopressin (Avp) and oxytocin (Oxt) as critical mediators of pair bonding in socially monogamous prairie voles, and of social cognition and behaviors in humans, until now, we have been unable to understand how the receptors for Oxt (OxtR) and Avp (V1aR) facilitate long term social attachments. We propose to investigate how these receptors control social attachment behaviors, and neuronal activity and gene expression in regions of the brain that mediate social attachment, providing neural and molecular insights that, eventually, will inform new therapeutic approaches across the spectrum of mental illness.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Home health aides (HHAs) are a vital lifeline for older Veterans, improving health outcomes for Veterans and caregivers and delaying or avoiding costly institutional care. This CDA addresses urgent VA and legislative priorities to improve Veterans’ access to and retention of stable HHA care by systematically identifying pathways to receiving and maintaining VA HHA benefits, and adapting and testing an evidence-based VA family caregiver support curriculum (Caregivers FIRST) to fill HHAs’ skills gaps and improve retention. My findings will generate systematic knowledge of how Veterans navigate benefit roadblocks and identify and test potential points of intervention. My extensive research and professional experience with HHAs and my qualitative training prepare me for this work. With mentorship and training in process improvement, intervention development, implementation science, and trial design, I will turn my CDA’s findings into actionable, effective, and scalable interventions that leverage existing VA resources to support high-quality HHA care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing and balance disorders affect a large percentage of our population. About 30-35 percent of adults between the ages of 65 and 75 years have a hearing loss, and it is estimated that about 50 million US citizens experience tinnitus in their lifetime. Balance disorders are also prevalent in the population, particularly amongst the elderly. More than one in three people age 65 years or older fall each year, and falls are the leading cause of hospitalization amongst the elderly. The proposed program will train the next generation of scientists to provide cures for hearing and balance disorders.
PROJECT_TERMS: Auditory;Neurosciences;Training;vestibular system
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Auditory and Vestibular Neuroscience

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The phenomenon of plasticity that is the focus of the proposed research is fundamental to learning, behavioral performance, and to the repair of the nervous system after damage. Our goal is to understand how plasticity manifests itself in the responses of the auditory cortex, and how do the acoustic stimuli interact with the behavioral feedback to influence the changes in the cortex. The findings of this research could have profound consequences for the design and deployment of hearing aids and cochlear implants.
