PHR: Excessive alcohol consumption is third among the causes of preventable death in the United States. This proposal is to train these individuals in an ongoing program that has a history of successfully training researchers in alcohol research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Genetic analyses of lipids have yielded important clinical and therapeutic insights for cardiovascular disease, the persistent leading cause of death worldwide. We now propose genetic analyses in millions of diverse individuals to prioritize new therapeutic targets for lipids and cardiovascular disease, and characterize the diverse clinical consequences of putative targets toward pleiotropic cardiometabolic prevention. We further aim to use our results to identify individuals who are at highest risk of cardiovascular disease earlier in life with the goal of prevention by analyzing genetic data in completed clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Germline genetic testing can change a cancer patient’s treatment and how their family members are cared for, yet many patients are not able to access testing and patients, who live in rural communities, have lower literacy and who do not speak English are especially impacted. We will develop and evaluate whether a multilingual animated computer character, called a relational agent (RA), can be used to provide genetic education to help overcome these barriers at two clinical centers (including a low-resource safety-net hospital). We expect that our work will have a significant clinical impact, both increasing access to timely genetic testing for cancer patients, in cancer and more widely across disease domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A priority focus in oncology and palliative care is preparing the 3.2 million U.S. family caregivers of persons with cancer to effectively partner with patients in health-related decision-making from diagnosis to the end of life, particularly in underserved settings. Over 70% of patients with cancer involve relatives, friends, and partners in healthcare decisions, including choices about cancer treatments, surgery, transitions and location of care, accessing palliative and hospice care, and many others. Patients making healthcare decisions with unprepared family caregivers may experience inadequate family decision support leading to heightened distress and receipt of care/treatments inconsistent with their values and preferences, which may in turn increase distress for family caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE _____ Malaria remains one of the great global health problems today, with nearly half a million deaths and millions of new infections occurring annually. This research will determine how the malaria parasite specially modifies a small number of its most important proteins in order to enhance their function. Understanding these modifications will help to improve the design of vaccines that target these proteins in order to arrest parasite development and prevent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The Integrative Vascular Biology Program was established in 2002 to provide the next generation of scientists with the interdisciplinary and collaborative skills necessary to uncover the mechanisms by which genetic variation and environmental factors influence cardiovascular development and disease. Centered around UNC's McAllister Heart Institute, our 42 well-established, well-funded, and highly diverse faculty will provide state-of- the-art research training as part of a Program that requires trainees to collaborate with secondary mentors outside of their major area of interest. When combined with a well-developed academic program in Cardiovascular Science, well-developed research infrastructure at UNC, and a large pool of well-qualified applicants, our Program offers an outstanding environment for multidisciplinary pre-doctoral training.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The Integrated Networks of Scholars in Global Health Research Training (INSIGHT) consortium formed between the University of Alabama at Birmingham, the Baylor College of Medicine, the University of Maryland Baltimore, and the University of Pittsburgh supports training for the next generation of global health scholars from the US and low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) through mentored research experiences at 24 established partner LMIC institutions across 19 countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America and the Caribbean. Strong emphases are on a broad range of global health research areas, including combatting the global HIV epidemic and associated co-morbidities, emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases, and mental health.

PHR: Sphingolipids can promote or prevent microvascular endothelial dysfunction, which precedes large artery atherosclerosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The overall goal of this application is to change how multiple myeloma, an incurable blood cancer, is understood and treated. We will discover new forms of cancer drug resistance that are driven by fat cell- derived factors. Thus, we will expose new interventions to overcome drug resistance to improve survival and quality of life for myeloma patients and patients with other cancers that grow in the bone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sleep and circadian rhythm disorders, which are highly prevalent and have a major impact on physical and behavioral health, safety, quality of life and longevity, disrupt the lives of an estimated 50-70 million Americans. At the core of the strategic goals laid out in the 2021 NIH Sleep Research Plan is the recognition of the critical need to foster a strong and diverse workforce required to accelerate fundamental scientific discoveries and translate these to clinical practice and population health to advance public health and safety, transform health care and advance well-being for our nation’s diverse population. Our NHLBI-supported Training Program in Sleep, Circadian and Respiratory Neurobiology directly addresses this need by training a diverse generation of investigators, many of whom are already successfully tackling critical questions in biomedical research aimed to understand the pathophysiology, prevention and treatment of sleep and circadian disorders.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Sleep, Circadian, and Respiratory Neurobiology
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(OA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung disease is a leading cause of death and disability in the United States. Despite an expanding understanding of the causes of lung disease, treatments that cure these disorders are lacking and most treatments are symptomatic or supportive. The goal of this program is to train highly qualified individuals in the research disciplines that are necessary to find better treatment and prevention of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health because hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is a severe form of congenital heart disease with 10-year survival of just 40%, and currently only 6% of HLHS patients have a likely genetic cause identified on exome sequencing. As epidemiologic evidence suggests genetic risk contributes to the majority of congenital heart disease, I propose that use of machine learning functional assessment of extensive variants of unknown significance from genomic sequencing and is an important next step in understanding HLHS. Identifying new genetic causes of HLHS can lead to better diagnosis and treatment of HLHS patients, as well as individuals with other congenital anomalies, and thus this proposal is relevant to NIH's goal of fostering fundamental creative discoveries as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most patients with heart failure struggle to adhere to behaviors important for heart health, and existing interventions to encourage these health behaviors have had limited impact and do not focus on psychological factors associated with adherence. In the proposed trial, we aim to determine whether a 12-week, telephone- delivered, behavioral intervention that involves performing simple activities to enhance well-being and setting goals for healthy behaviors—with additional text message support for 24 weeks—helps patients with heart failure take medications, maintain a healthy diet, and be more physically active. If the intervention is successful at improving adherence, we will plan a larger trial to determine whether the intervention reduces hospitalizations and improves survival in this group of high-risk patients.

PHR: Project Narrative This application is for support of a comprehensive training program for postdoctoral trainees to become experts in different aspects of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and spectroscopy (MRS) to be able to contribute to their translational applications. MRI and MRS are very important methods for the non-invasive diagnosis of diseases and monitoring of treatment in clinical practice, and provide vital information for a wide range of other biomedical research applications. This program will address the shortage of suitably qualiﬁed postdoctoral scientists able to contribute to the further development of MR methods or to apply them effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medically underserved patients have the highest burden of multiple chronic conditions and are at increased risk for poor outcomes during and after cancer treatment. As medically underserved complex cancer patients may lack healthcare knowledge and access to supportive care, their health outcomes and care transitions might be improved by enhancing communication and collaboration between their oncologists and primary care providers (PCPs). This study tests and evaluates a novel shared care model for complex cancer survivors called OPTIMISE that shifts the timing of thinking about survivorship to point of diagnosis and seeks to develop a clinical infrastructure to support continuity of care from cancer diagnosis through post-treatment survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative: Understanding the potential health effects of electronic cigarettes is of tremendous interest because: (a) they are the most used tobacco product among youth, and are used by over one third of adult tobacco smokers (dual users); (b) they contain unique constituents that might have unforeseen health consequences; and (c) they might be an important tool for smoking cessation. In this proposal, we will determine how the use of electronic cigarettes by exclusive and dual users modifies DNA damage, mutation rate, and gene expression, factors which increase cancer risk in humans. Our study will provide evidence-based data urgently needed by clinicians to guide their patients and by regulatory agencies to implement specific policies aiming to protect public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The opportunistic fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus poses an increasing health concern for critically ill and immunodeficient patients due to widespread anti-microbial resistance. This proposal seeks to investigate the role of lymph node stromal cells in organizing spatial niches for generating diverse adaptive immune responses to A. fumigatus. Understanding the mechanisms by which lymph node stromal cells orchestrate protective immunity may identify novel strategies for development of therapies and vaccines to mitigate the burden of A. fumigatus and other fungal pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Research in hematology has yield important knowledge about fundamental biological processes and has improved the survival and quality of life for persons with blood diseases. Great strides have been made in the treatment of children with sickle cell disease, hemophilia, bone marrow failure and other blood disorders. Yet the number of well-trained researchers in this field is steadily declining, especially in pediatrics. This T32 Training Grant is designed to address this problem by providing high quality research training to highly motivated and talented post-doctoral MD, MD/PhD, and PhD researchers to enable them to become the next generation of physician scientists and translational investigators in pediatric non-malignant hematology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE The malignant transformation of slow-growing low grade brain tumors into lethal high grade tumors is a devastating event that eventually affects nearly all patients. We discovered that while the mutations in low grade tumors suppress the ability of the local immune system, the mutations that cause malignant transformation might relieve key elements of the suppression, creating an environment that could be more favorable to immune system attack, given the appropriate stimulation by immunotherapy in combination with agents targeting genetic effectors of immunosuppression. We propose to understand how and why the initially immunosuppressed state of the tumor changes during malignant transformation, and use this knowledge to improve immunotherapy, and immunotherapies combined with targeted agents, to prevent, delay or treat malignant transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common acute leukemia in adults with a devastating prognosis for elderly patients. We discovered an unexpected role of selenium metabolism in AML, and we will interrogate this mechanism in animal models and patient samples to examine whether we could therapeutically target this mechanism to treat AML. Our study may lead to a novel combinatorial therapy that could deeply suppress AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Among the different tumor liquid biopsy approaches, extracellular vesicles (EVs) are present in circulation at a relatively early stage of disease of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The long-term goal of this R01 proposal is to develop a new HCC EV purification system (i.e., EV Click Chips) by synergistically integrating four very innovative approaches. The successful development of the proposed EV Click Chips will enable more sensitive and specific HCC EV-based molecular assays for HCC surveillance and will be rapidly translatable to the fields of oncology and cancer biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A clear diagnostic of type 2 diabetes is amyloid deposits in the pancreas. Recent research suggests that it is not the deposits themselves that cause β-cell failure and the loss of insulin production, but rather their formation. The aim of this proposal is to study the transient species that causes cytotoxicity. That knowledge is critical to combat the disease and develop new hormone replacement therapies.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Overall Proposal Project Narrative This project describes activities the California Animal Health and Food Safety Laboratory System’s Toxicology Section will undertake to support an integrated human and animal food safety network system. The Section will support the overall goals of increasing testing capability and sample capacity by committing to participate in food defense activities, by performing the analysis of animal feed products collected by the State of California’s Feed Regulatory Program, and by developing and validating methods for the analysis of hazardous chemicals in human food and animal feed.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative By participating in this cooperative agreement, the Kansas Department of Agriculture Laboratory (KDAL) aims to successfully expand the testing capabilities in both Microbiology and Chemistry as well as increase sample throughput in human and animal product testing. Additionally, KDAL will continue with their existing quality system consistent with the principles and requirements of ISO/IEC 17025:2017. The standard will attest to KDAL’s competency and technical capabilities to perform tasks and support traceability of data generated. This cooperative agreement will allow for the enhancement of both human and animal food product surveillance. Moreover, it will strengthen the relationship between the laboratory and the regulatory programs. By expanding the existing surveillance program KDA aims to ensure a safer food supply for Kansas.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Kansas Department of Agriculture Laboratory's Implementation of a Laboratory Flexible Funding Model

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Overall The NMSU Food Safety Laboratory (NMSU FSL) will work towards achieving FDA FERN objectives by participating in FERN activities such as evaluation of new methodologies, analysis of surveillance and emergency outbreak samples, and whole genome sequencing. We will work to expand our testing capabilities to include molecular detection of Cyclospora. We are committed to food safety in the Indian Nations and will partner with New Mexico Indian Health Services for sample collection. The NMSU FSL will hire a Quality Manager to work with us to achieve and maintain the ISO 17025 accreditation of our lab.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: New Mexico State University Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (U19)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Diabetes mellitus, one of the major leading chronic morbidities worldwide, is continually increasing with a high prevalence in the United States and throughout the world. Cardiovascular complications are mainly responsible for the high morbidity and mortality in people with diabetes. The proposed studies will significantly increase our understanding of molecular mechanisms underlying diabetes-associated coronary endothelial dysfunction and abnormal lipid transport and therefore provide the basis to develop new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes-associate cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Recent progress in the genetics of complex diseases, including neuropsychiatric diseases, has revealed that the bulk of disease heritability is explained by the action of many common non-coding variants. We propose to develop new statistical and computational methods to infer biological function of these variants at different levels of organization. We will apply these methods to genome-scale genotype-phenotype and functional genomics datasets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative Clinician scientists play a critical role in the national biomedical workforce but the number of clinician scientists is at an all time low. The overall goal of this training grant is to attract talented and interested medical students and pharmacy students into careers as clinician scientists by offering students a research fellowship that includes a mentored research project in the broad areas of infectious diseases, microbiology and immunology during the summer between first and second year of professional school. The program includes seminars, professional development, training in the responsible conduct of research, training in enhancing reproducibility of research, and the opportunity for students to present their work in oral and poster format.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The selective infiltration of immunosuppressive tumor-associated myeloid cells (TAMCs) is a hallmark of malignant brain tumors and a major hurdle to the effectiveness of anti-tumor treatments. Our work explores the use of myeloid-targeted nanoparticles to reprogram TAMC functionality as a new approach to promote anti-tumor immunity. The objective of this proposal is to reshape the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment in a clinically relevant manner and to potentiate standard of care therapy for glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The human airway is composed of multiple cell types each with specialized role. Proper balance of the airway cell types, especially between differentiated luminal cells and basal progenitor cells is essential for airway maintenance and function. In this study, we will address the fundamental question of how airway progenitor versus progeny balance is established during lung formation, maintained in the adult during normal turnover, and restored following lung injury such as viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT) using 177Lu-DOTATATE (Lutathera) has recently been approved by the FDA for treatment of somatostatin receptor (SSTR) expressing gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (GEP-NET). However, the effect of PRRT is dependent on SSTR2 expression levels, as those with low to medium-level SSTR2 expression do not benefit from PRRT and are left with limited, marginally beneficial treatment options. Here we propose to develop and test a pulsed modulatory chemotherapy pretreatment approach to re-sensitize GEP-NETs to PRRT by upregulating SSTR2 expression through epigenetic modulators, and potentially improve the management of this difficult-to-treat patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major obstacle to achieving lasting cures for advanced malignancies is the emergence of acquired resistance to treatment, not only due to genetically resistant clones, but also through phenotypic plasticity. This proposal investigates the role of m6A RNA modifications in potentiating drug resistance in bladder cancer. It has the potential to elucidate a novel epitranscriptomic mechanism underlying the phenotypic plasticity that drives cancer progression, and to offer new therapeutic targets to short-circuit drug resistance in bladder cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The life expectancy for individuals with sickle cell disease has improved substantially over the last 50 years; however, there are no validated methods for assessing capabilities and vulnerabilities in this aging population. The goal of this study is to evaluate the validity and reliability of the Sickle Cell Disease Functional Assessment and pilot an exercise intervention for older adults with sickle cell disease. This research will contribute by improving knowledge about management of older adults with sickle cell disease and will provide preliminary data for interventions to ameliorate functional impairment and improve longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Monoclonal antibodies have been one of the largest classes of anti-cancer therapeutics in development over the past decade. While antibodies serve as a versatile platform for both the diagnosis and treatment of various cancers, model systems allowing adequate pre-clinical testing are limited, due, in part, to the lack of binding of human antibodies to their cognate receptors, Fcγ receptors, in mouse or macaque models. These studies aim to develop novel humanized mouse models allowing proper characterization of monoclonal antibodies destined for clinical use (e.g. pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy testing).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are a number of evidence-based strategies to address the serious public health concern of problematic college drinking; yet, the process by which colleges select and implement the strategies is unknown. This project will address this missing link by examining if and how CollegeAIM (a matrix of evidence-based strategies for college drinking developed by NIAAA) is used to by colleges to effectively identify evidence-based strategies that fit the needs of their institutions. This project will result in increased knowledge of what impedes the selection of effective interventions, and will serve as groundwork for the development of support programs to assist colleges in effectively identifying and implementing evidence-based strategies to address risky drinking.

PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE PAR-20-105 In support of an integrated food safety system, the Indiana State Department of Health Laboratories (ISDHL) will enhance the capacity and capabilities of human food testing through increased sample testing in the areas of microbiology, chemistry and radiochemistry. The project will strengthen and improve FDA’s efforts to prevent foodborne illnesses and minimize exposures to hazards through ISDHL’s participation in a nationally integrated laboratory science system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Many clinically used cancer therapies can trigger cellular senescence in tumor cells. Senescence is considered to be a “double-edged sword”: it is a cell autonomous tumor suppressive mechanism and has been shown to trigger potent anti-tumor immune responses, but the presence of senescent cells in the tumor microenvironment has also been shown to promote tumor progression. The studies described here will dissect the interplay between senescent cells and T cells in the tumor microenvironment and identify strategies to enhance endogenous T cell killing of senescent tumor cells.
